dn16:0.2.eng: The Great Discourse on the Buddha’s Extinguishment

dn16:1.1.1.comm: The longest of all early discourses, this dramatic and moving narrative tells the story of the Buddha’s slow journey towards his final passing.

dn16:1.1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
dn16:1.1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.

dn16:1.1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto vajjī abhiyātukāmo hoti.
dn16:1.1.3.eng: Now at that time King Ajātasattu of Magadha, son of the princess of Videha, wanted to invade the Vajjis.
dn16:1.1.3.comm: After the events of DN 2, Ajātasattu retained and consolidated his power. Magadha ultimately conquered the Vajji Federation and continued to expand until almost all of India was under its sway.

dn16:1.1.5.pli: “ahaṃ hime vajjī evaṃmahiddhike evaṃmahānubhāve ucchecchāmi vajjī, vināsessāmi vajjī, anayabyasanaṃ āpādessāmī”ti.
dn16:1.1.5.eng: “I shall wipe out these Vajjis, so mighty and powerful! I shall destroy them, and lay ruin and devastation upon them!”
dn16:1.1.5.comm: According to the commentary, Ajātasattu’s anger was rooted in a dispute on trade routes. Control of shipping on the Ganges was essential for establishing international trade. There was a port on the Ganges extending over a league, split half and half between Magadha and Vajji. Valuable products were sourced from a mountain and brought down for trade, but the Vajjis kept absconding with the whole lot. The place is not identified, but Munger, a strategic port east of Patna, fits the description. The nearby hills have been mined since paleolithic times. It is also likely, as maintained in Jain tradition, that the Vajjis disputed Ajātasattu’s accession after committing regicide. His threatening posture towards the Vajjis is also mentioned in SN 20.8:2.2.

dn16:1.2.1.pli: Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto vassakāraṃ brāhmaṇaṃ magadhamahāmattaṃ āmantesi:
dn16:1.2.1.eng: And then King Ajātasattu addressed Vassakāra the brahmin minister of Magadha,
dn16:1.2.1.comm: Vassakāra appears in the suttas as a devoted follower of the Buddha.

dn16:1.2.2.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā mama vacanena bhagavato pāde sirasā vandāhi, appābādhaṃ appātaṅkaṃ lahuṭṭhānaṃ balaṃ phāsuvihāraṃ puccha:
dn16:1.2.2.eng: “Please, brahmin, go to the Buddha, and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Ask him if he is healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.

dn16:1.2.3.pli: ‘rājā, bhante, māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto bhagavato pāde sirasā vandati, appābādhaṃ appātaṅkaṃ lahuṭṭhānaṃ balaṃ phāsuvihāraṃ pucchatī’ti.

dn16:1.2.5.pli: ‘rājā, bhante, māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto vajjī abhiyātukāmo.
dn16:1.2.5.eng: ‘Sir, King Ajātasattu of Magadha, son of the princess of Videha, wants to invade the Vajjis.

dn16:1.2.7.pli: “ahaṃ hime vajjī evaṃmahiddhike evaṃmahānubhāve ucchecchāmi vajjī, vināsessāmi vajjī, anayabyasanaṃ āpādessāmī”’ti.
dn16:1.2.7.eng: “I shall wipe out these Vajjis, so mighty and powerful! I shall destroy them, and lay ruin and devastation upon them!”’
dn16:1.2.7.comm: The Vajji Federation harks back to an early settlement founded by the legendary Nābhānediṣṭha in the Vedic period. It built its wealth on its extensive fertile plains and the trading possibilities opened up by the Gandak and Ganges rivers.

dn16:1.2.8.pli: Yathā te bhagavā byākaroti, taṃ sādhukaṃ uggahetvā mama āroceyyāsi.
dn16:1.2.8.eng: Remember well how the Buddha answers and tell it to me.

dn16:1.2.9.eng: For Realized Ones say nothing that is not so.”
dn16:1.2.9.comm: While it may seem strange to consult the Buddha on such a violent plan, Ajātasattu knows from his experience in DN 2 that the Buddha will not hesitate to tell him the truth, even if it is bad news. It seems he is trying to avoid the downfall of tyrants who are surrounded only with yes men.

dn16:1.3.1.pli: “Evaṃ, bho”ti kho vassakāro brāhmaṇo magadhamahāmatto rañño māgadhassa ajātasattussa vedehiputtassa paṭissutvā bhaddāni bhaddāni yānāni yojetvā bhaddaṃ bhaddaṃ yānaṃ abhiruhitvā bhaddehi bhaddehi yānehi rājagahamhā niyyāsi, yena gijjhakūṭo pabbato tena pāyāsi.
dn16:1.3.1.eng: “Yes, worthy sir,” Vassakāra replied. He had the finest carriages harnessed. Then he mounted a fine carriage and, along with other fine carriages, set out from Rājagaha for the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
dn16:1.3.1.comm: Reading yojapetvā (“had them harnessed”), which is found in the Mahāsaṅgīti in similar passages, and in this passage in the PTS edition.

dn16:1.3.2.pli: Yāvatikā yānassa bhūmi, yānena gantvā, yānā paccorohitvā pattikova yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
dn16:1.3.2.eng: He went by carriage as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and approached the Buddha on foot, and exchanged greetings with him.

dn16:1.3.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho vassakāro brāhmaṇo magadhamahāmatto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn16:1.3.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha,

dn16:1.3.4.pli: “rājā, bho gotama, māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto bhoto gotamassa pāde sirasā vandati, appābādhaṃ appātaṅkaṃ lahuṭṭhānaṃ balaṃ phāsuvihāraṃ pucchati.
dn16:1.3.4.eng: “Worthy Gotama, King Ajātasattu of Magadha, son of the princess of Videha, bows with his head to your feet. He asks if you are healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.

dn16:1.3.5.pli: Rājā, bho gotama, māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto vajjī abhiyātukāmo.
dn16:1.3.5.eng: Worthy Gotama, King Ajātasattu wants to invade the Vajjis.

dn16:1.3.7.pli: ‘ahaṃ hime vajjī evaṃmahiddhike evaṃmahānubhāve ucchecchāmi vajjī, vināsessāmi vajjī, anayabyasanaṃ āpādessāmī’”ti.
dn16:1.3.7.eng: ‘I shall wipe out these Vajjis, so mighty and powerful! I shall destroy them, and lay ruin and devastation upon them!’”

dn16:1.4.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā ānando bhagavato piṭṭhito ṭhito hoti bhagavantaṃ bījayamāno.
dn16:1.4.1.eng: Now at that time Venerable Ānanda was standing behind the Buddha fanning him.
dn16:1.4.1.comm: Ānanda cares for the Buddha in his old age. Shortly after these events, Ānanda was entrusted with reciting the suttas at the First Council. This discourse would have been composed by him in the years following his Master’s death. More than a simple interlocutor, Ānanda shapes the story as its second lead, a relatable character with an empathetic point of view. He imbues the discourse with his emotional struggles as he deals with the Buddha’s passing and helps ensure the future survival of the Dhamma, while still developing his own meditation practice.

dn16:1.4.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
dn16:1.4.2.eng: Then the Buddha said to him,

dn16:1.4.3.pli: “kinti te, ānanda, sutaṃ, ‘vajjī abhiṇhaṃ sannipātā sannipātabahulā’”ti?
dn16:1.4.3.eng: “Ānanda, have you heard that the Vajjis meet frequently and have many meetings?”

dn16:1.4.5.pli: “Yāvakīvañca, ānanda, vajjī abhiṇhaṃ sannipātā sannipātabahulā bhavissanti, vuddhiyeva, ānanda, vajjīnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.
dn16:1.4.5.eng: “As long as the Vajjis meet frequently and have many meetings, they can expect growth, not decline.

dn16:1.4.6.pli: Kinti te, ānanda, sutaṃ, ‘vajjī samaggā sannipatanti, samaggā vuṭṭhahanti, samaggā vajjikaraṇīyāni karontī’”ti?
dn16:1.4.6.eng: Ānanda, have you heard that the Vajjis meet in harmony, leave in harmony, and carry on their business in harmony?”
dn16:1.4.6.comm: Harmony is especially important as the Vajji Federation was comprised of several different clans, among them the Licchavis of Vesālī, the Ñātikas just south of Vesālī, the Uggas of Hatthigāma (Elephant Village), and the Bhogas of Bhoganagara. Some sources say the Vajjis proper were another tribe within the alliance. The Videhans of Mithilā are also sometimes included, but several sources indicate that they remained an independent, if reduced, kingdom until they were conquered by Magadha some years later. The Mallas of Pāvā and Kusinārā formed a closely allied independent republic (MN 35:12.8).

dn16:1.4.7.pli: “Sutaṃ metaṃ, bhante: ‘vajjī samaggā sannipatanti, samaggā vuṭṭhahanti, samaggā vajjikaraṇīyāni karontī’”ti.

dn16:1.4.8.pli: “Yāvakīvañca, ānanda, vajjī samaggā sannipatissanti, samaggā vuṭṭhahissanti, samaggā vajjikaraṇīyāni karissanti, vuddhiyeva, ānanda, vajjīnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.
dn16:1.4.8.eng: “As long as the Vajjis meet in harmony, leave in harmony, and carry on their business in harmony, they can expect growth, not decline.

dn16:1.4.9.pli: Kinti te, ānanda, sutaṃ, ‘vajjī apaññattaṃ na paññapenti, paññattaṃ na samucchindanti, yathāpaññatte porāṇe vajjidhamme samādāya vattantī’”ti?
dn16:1.4.9.eng: Ānanda, have you heard that the Vajjis don’t make new decrees or abolish existing decrees, but proceed having undertaken the ancient Vajjian traditions as they have been decreed?”
dn16:1.4.9.comm: The “ancient Vajjian traditions” (porāṇe vajjidhamme) would have been established with the founding of the Vajji Federation some centuries earlier, which ensured that the members of the federation would have a voice in the Licchavi-dominated union. Compare with the “ancient traditions of the brahmins” (porāṇā brāhmaṇadhammā at AN 5.191 and Snp 2.7), the falling away from which is said to be the cause of Brahmanical decline. Similarly, the Buddha elsewhere scolds the Vajjis for their indulgence (AN 5.143), suggesting that the decline may have already set in.

dn16:1.4.10.pli: “Sutaṃ metaṃ, bhante: ‘vajjī apaññattaṃ na paññapenti, paññattaṃ na samucchindanti, yathāpaññatte porāṇe vajjidhamme samādāya vattantī’”ti.

dn16:1.4.11.pli: “Yāvakīvañca, ānanda, vajjī apaññattaṃ na paññapessanti, paññattaṃ na samucchindissanti, yathāpaññatte porāṇe vajjidhamme samādāya vattissanti, vuddhiyeva, ānanda, vajjīnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.
dn16:1.4.11.eng: “As long as the Vajjis don’t make new decrees or abolish existing decrees, but proceed having undertaken the ancient Vajjian traditions as they have been decreed, they can expect growth, not decline.

dn16:1.4.12.pli: Kinti te, ānanda, sutaṃ, ‘vajjī ye te vajjīnaṃ vajjimahallakā, te sakkaronti garuṃ karonti mānenti pūjenti, tesañca sotabbaṃ maññantī’”ti?
dn16:1.4.12.eng: Ānanda, have you heard that the Vajjis honor, respect, esteem, and venerate Vajjian elders, and think them worth listening to?”

dn16:1.4.13.pli: “Sutaṃ metaṃ, bhante: ‘vajjī ye te vajjīnaṃ vajjimahallakā, te sakkaronti garuṃ karonti mānenti pūjenti, tesañca sotabbaṃ maññantī’”ti.

dn16:1.4.14.pli: “Yāvakīvañca, ānanda, vajjī ye te vajjīnaṃ vajjimahallakā, te sakkarissanti garuṃ karissanti mānessanti pūjessanti, tesañca sotabbaṃ maññissanti, vuddhiyeva, ānanda, vajjīnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.
dn16:1.4.14.eng: “As long as the Vajjis honor, respect, esteem, and venerate Vajjian elders, and think them worth listening to, they can expect growth, not decline.

dn16:1.4.15.pli: Kinti te, ānanda, sutaṃ, ‘vajjī yā tā kulitthiyo kulakumāriyo, tā na okkassa pasayha vāsentī’”ti?
dn16:1.4.15.eng: Ānanda, have you heard that the Vajjis don’t forcibly abduct the women or girls of the clans and make them live with them?”
dn16:1.4.15.comm: This advocates for legal protection for women from sexual violence. | For various legal regulations regarding women and sex, see Kauṭilya’s Arthaśāstra 12.

dn16:1.4.16.pli: “Sutaṃ metaṃ, bhante: ‘vajjī yā tā kulitthiyo kulakumāriyo tā na okkassa pasayha vāsentī’”ti.

dn16:1.4.17.pli: “Yāvakīvañca, ānanda, vajjī yā tā kulitthiyo kulakumāriyo, tā na okkassa pasayha vāsessanti, vuddhiyeva, ānanda, vajjīnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.
dn16:1.4.17.eng: “As long as the Vajjis don’t forcibly abduct the women or girls of the clans and make them live with them, they can expect growth, not decline.

dn16:1.4.18.pli: Kinti te, ānanda, sutaṃ, ‘vajjī yāni tāni vajjīnaṃ vajjicetiyāni abbhantarāni ceva bāhirāni ca, tāni sakkaronti garuṃ karonti mānenti pūjenti, tesañca dinnapubbaṃ katapubbaṃ dhammikaṃ baliṃ no parihāpentī’”ti?
dn16:1.4.18.eng: Ānanda, have you heard that the Vajjis honor, respect, esteem, and venerate the Vajjian shrines, whether inner or outer, not neglecting the proper spirit-offerings that were given and made in the past?”
dn16:1.4.18.comm: The Buddha will stay at several of these shrines later in this discourse. They were sacred groves, maintained by the people in reverence for the powerful spirits of nature. | “Spirit-offerings” is bali. | The commentary explains “inner or outer” as inside or outside the town.

dn16:1.4.19.pli: “Sutaṃ metaṃ, bhante: ‘vajjī yāni tāni vajjīnaṃ vajjicetiyāni abbhantarāni ceva bāhirāni ca, tāni sakkaronti garuṃ karonti mānenti pūjenti tesañca dinnapubbaṃ katapubbaṃ dhammikaṃ baliṃ no parihāpentī’”ti.

dn16:1.4.20.pli: “Yāvakīvañca, ānanda, vajjī yāni tāni vajjīnaṃ vajjicetiyāni abbhantarāni ceva bāhirāni ca, tāni sakkarissanti garuṃ karissanti mānessanti pūjessanti, tesañca dinnapubbaṃ katapubbaṃ dhammikaṃ baliṃ no parihāpessanti, vuddhiyeva, ānanda, vajjīnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.
dn16:1.4.20.eng: “As long as the Vajjis honor, respect, esteem, and venerate the Vajjian shrines, whether inner or outer, not neglecting the proper spirit-offerings that were given and made in the past, they can expect growth, not decline.

dn16:1.4.21.pli: Kinti te, ānanda, sutaṃ, ‘vajjīnaṃ arahantesu dhammikā rakkhāvaraṇagutti susaṃvihitā, kinti anāgatā ca arahanto vijitaṃ āgaccheyyuṃ, āgatā ca arahanto vijite phāsu vihareyyun’”ti?
dn16:1.4.21.eng: Ānanda, have you heard that the Vajjis organize proper protection, shelter, and security for perfected ones, so that more perfected ones might come to the realm and those already here may live in comfort?”
dn16:1.4.21.comm: It is an old Indian belief that the presence of holy persons provides a kind of umbrella effect that protects the realm.

dn16:1.4.22.pli: “Sutaṃ metaṃ, bhante ‘vajjīnaṃ arahantesu dhammikā rakkhāvaraṇagutti susaṃvihitā kinti anāgatā ca arahanto vijitaṃ āgaccheyyuṃ, āgatā ca arahanto vijite phāsu vihareyyun’”ti.

dn16:1.4.23.pli: “Yāvakīvañca, ānanda, vajjīnaṃ arahantesu dhammikā rakkhāvaraṇagutti susaṃvihitā bhavissati, kinti anāgatā ca arahanto vijitaṃ āgaccheyyuṃ, āgatā ca arahanto vijite phāsu vihareyyunti. Vuddhiyeva, ānanda, vajjīnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihānī”ti.
dn16:1.4.23.eng: “As long as the Vajjis organize proper protection, shelter, and security for perfected ones, so that more perfected ones might come to the realm and those already here may live in comfort, they can expect growth, not decline.”

dn16:1.5.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā vassakāraṃ brāhmaṇaṃ magadhamahāmattaṃ āmantesi:
dn16:1.5.1.eng: Then the Buddha said to Vassakāra,

dn16:1.5.2.pli: “ekamidāhaṃ, brāhmaṇa, samayaṃ vesāliyaṃ viharāmi sārandade cetiye.
dn16:1.5.2.eng: “Brahmin, this one time I was staying near Vesālī at the Sārandada Shrine.
dn16:1.5.2.comm: This event is recorded at AN 7.21, where the Buddha addresses the Licchavis. That chapter of the Aṅguttara mostly consists of the teachings found here presented as separate suttas. | The Sārandada shrine was short walk from Vesālī (AN 5.143).

dn16:1.5.3.pli: Tatrāhaṃ vajjīnaṃ ime satta aparihāniye dhamme desesiṃ.
dn16:1.5.3.eng: There I taught the Vajjis these seven principles that prevent decline.
dn16:1.5.3.comm: There is a certain tension here: the Buddha taught these principles to the Vajjis, one of which is that the Vajjis should not adopt new decrees. It seems that a “decree” (paññatta) is more like constitutional law, whereas a “principle” (dhamma) is more like a behavioral guideline.

dn16:1.5.4.pli: Yāvakīvañca, brāhmaṇa, ime satta aparihāniyā dhammā vajjīsu ṭhassanti, imesu ca sattasu aparihāniyesu dhammesu vajjī sandississanti, vuddhiyeva, brāhmaṇa, vajjīnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihānī”ti.
dn16:1.5.4.eng: As long as these seven principles that prevent decline last among the Vajjis, and as long as the Vajjis are seen following them, they can expect growth, not decline.”

dn16:1.5.5.pli: Evaṃ vutte, vassakāro brāhmaṇo magadhamahāmatto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn16:1.5.5.eng: When the Buddha had spoken, Vassakāra said to him,

dn16:1.5.6.pli: “ekamekenapi, bho gotama, aparihāniyena dhammena samannāgatānaṃ vajjīnaṃ vuddhiyeva pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.
dn16:1.5.6.eng: “Worthy Gotama, if the Vajjis follow even a single one of these principles they can expect growth, not decline.

dn16:1.5.7.pli: Ko pana vādo sattahi aparihāniyehi dhammehi.
dn16:1.5.7.eng: How much more so all seven!

dn16:1.5.8.pli: Akaraṇīyāva, bho gotama, vajjī raññā māgadhena ajātasattunā vedehiputtena yadidaṃ yuddhassa, aññatra upalāpanāya aññatra mithubhedā.
dn16:1.5.8.eng: King Ajātasattu cannot defeat the Vajjis in war, unless by bribery or by sowing dissension.
dn16:1.5.8.comm: Upalāpana is used a number of times in the Vinaya, where it always has the sense of giving someone something to get them to do what you want. It has the same sense at SN 3.25:4.13, where an enemy king may be bribed with gold from the royal treasury. | The commentary says that Vassakāra himself was assigned with the task of weakening the Vajjis in this way.

dn16:1.5.9.pli: Handa ca dāni mayaṃ, bho gotama, gacchāma, bahukiccā mayaṃ bahukaraṇīyā”ti.
dn16:1.5.9.eng: Well, now, worthy Gotama, I must go. I have many duties, and much to do.”

dn16:1.5.11.pli: Atha kho vassakāro brāhmaṇo magadhamahāmatto bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi.
dn16:1.5.11.eng: Then Vassakāra the brahmin, having approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, got up from his seat and left.

dn16:1.6.0.eng: 3. Principles That Prevent Decline Among the Mendicants

dn16:1.6.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā acirapakkante vassakāre brāhmaṇe magadhamahāmatte āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
dn16:1.6.1.eng: Soon after he had left, the Buddha said to Ānanda,

dn16:1.6.2.pli: “gaccha tvaṃ, ānanda, yāvatikā bhikkhū rājagahaṃ upanissāya viharanti, te sabbe upaṭṭhānasālāyaṃ sannipātehī”ti.
dn16:1.6.2.eng: “Go, Ānanda, gather all the mendicants staying in the vicinity of Rājagaha together in the assembly hall.”
dn16:1.6.2.comm: There were several monasteries and hermitages around Rājagaha (Kd 2:11.1.1).

dn16:1.6.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paṭissutvā yāvatikā bhikkhū rājagahaṃ upanissāya viharanti, te sabbe upaṭṭhānasālāyaṃ sannipātetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn16:1.6.3.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied Ānanda. He did what the Buddha asked. Then he went back, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him,

dn16:1.6.4.pli: “sannipatito, bhante, bhikkhusaṅgho, yassadāni, bhante, bhagavā kālaṃ maññatī”ti.
dn16:1.6.4.eng: “Sir, the mendicant Saṅgha has assembled. Please, sir, go at your convenience.”

dn16:1.6.5.pli: Atha kho bhagavā uṭṭhāyāsanā yena upaṭṭhānasālā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
dn16:1.6.5.eng: Then the Buddha went to the assembly hall, where he sat on the seat spread out

dn16:1.6.7.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you these seven principles that prevent decline.

dn16:1.6.8.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

dn16:1.6.9.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

dn16:1.6.11.pli: “Yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhū abhiṇhaṃ sannipātā sannipātabahulā bhavissanti, vuddhiyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.
dn16:1.6.11.eng: “As long as the mendicants meet frequently and have many meetings, they can expect growth, not decline.
dn16:1.6.11.comm: This especially refers to the fortnightly uposatha. Despite the dangers faced in the rugged hills around Rājagaha (Kd 2:12.1.1), the Buddha insisted that all monks of the locality attended the uposatha (Kd 2:5.3.1).

dn16:1.6.12.pli: Yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhū samaggā sannipatissanti, samaggā vuṭṭhahissanti, samaggā saṅghakaraṇīyāni karissanti, vuddhiyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.
dn16:1.6.12.eng: As long as the mendicants meet in harmony, leave in harmony, and carry on their business in harmony, they can expect growth, not decline.
dn16:1.6.12.comm: The Buddha encouraged the mendicants to recite the Dhamma in harmony (MN 103:3.2), to resolve issues in harmony (MN 104:14.3), and on the uposatha to recite and train in the pātimokkha in harmony (Bu As 7:4.11).

dn16:1.6.13.pli: Yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhū apaññattaṃ na paññapessanti, paññattaṃ na samucchindissanti, yathāpaññattesu sikkhāpadesu samādāya vattissanti, vuddhiyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.
dn16:1.6.13.eng: As long as the mendicants don’t make new decrees or abolish existing decrees, but undertake and follow the training rules as they have been decreed, they can expect growth, not decline.
dn16:1.6.13.comm: Picking up from the similar injunction to the Vajjis, this kicks off a long narrative arc that binds together the Buddha’s invitation to abolish the minor rules (DN 16:6.3.1) with the bad monk Subhadda’s seizing on the Buddha’s death as an excuse to give up the rules, which was the direct motivation for the First Council (DN 16:6.20.3 = Kd 21:1.1.24), at the end of which the Sangha agreed not to abolish any rules (Kd 21:1.9.20), a decision that was affirmed a century later at the Second Council (Kd 22).

dn16:1.6.14.pli: Yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhū ye te bhikkhū therā rattaññū cirapabbajitā saṅghapitaro saṅghapariṇāyakā, te sakkarissanti garuṃ karissanti mānessanti pūjessanti, tesañca sotabbaṃ maññissanti, vuddhiyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.
dn16:1.6.14.eng: As long as the mendicants honor, respect, esteem, and venerate the senior mendicants—of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha—and think them worth listening to, they can expect growth, not decline.
dn16:1.6.14.comm: The nature of seniority in the Saṅgha is often misunderstood. There is no “hierarchy” (literally “rule of priests”) in the sense of power-based relationships: no monastic has the authority to command another monk or nun. Seniority is owed respect, not obedience.

dn16:1.6.15.pli: Yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhū uppannāya taṇhāya ponobbhavikāya na vasaṃ gacchissanti, vuddhiyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.
dn16:1.6.15.eng: As long as the mendicants don’t fall under the sway of arisen craving for future lives, they can expect growth, not decline.
dn16:1.6.15.comm: This stands in place of the injunction against sexual violence, both principles being concerned with the harmful effects of desire.

dn16:1.6.16.pli: Yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhū āraññakesu senāsanesu sāpekkhā bhavissanti, vuddhiyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.
dn16:1.6.16.eng: As long as the mendicants take care to live in wilderness lodgings, they can expect growth, not decline.
dn16:1.6.16.comm: This stands in place of the injunction to maintain the shrines, where mendicants would frequently stay.

dn16:1.6.17.pli: Yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhū paccattaññeva satiṃ upaṭṭhapessanti: ‘kinti anāgatā ca pesalā sabrahmacārī āgaccheyyuṃ, āgatā ca pesalā sabrahmacārī phāsu vihareyyun’ti. Vuddhiyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.
dn16:1.6.17.eng: As long as the mendicants individually establish mindfulness, so that more good-hearted spiritual companions might come, and those that have already come may live comfortably, they can expect growth, not decline.
dn16:1.6.17.comm: This stands in place of the injunction to look after arahants.

dn16:1.6.18.pli: Yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, ime satta aparihāniyā dhammā bhikkhūsu ṭhassanti, imesu ca sattasu aparihāniyesu dhammesu bhikkhū sandississanti, vuddhiyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.
dn16:1.6.18.eng: As long as these seven principles that prevent decline last among the mendicants, and as long as the mendicants are seen following them, they can expect growth, not decline.

dn16:1.7.1.pli: Aparepi vo, bhikkhave, satta aparihāniye dhamme desessāmi, taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasikarotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
dn16:1.7.1.eng: I will teach you seven more principles that prevent decline. …

dn16:1.7.2.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

dn16:1.7.4.pli: “Yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhū na kammārāmā bhavissanti na kammaratā na kammārāmatamanuyuttā, vuddhiyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.
dn16:1.7.4.eng: As long as the mendicants don’t relish work, loving it and liking to relish it, they can expect growth, not decline.
dn16:1.7.4.comm: “Work” is kamma, which especially means “building work”. Of course it is essential to do work, but one should not get too caught up in it. The Buddha did not believe that working hard was ennobling in and of itself.

dn16:1.7.5.pli: Yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhū na bhassārāmā bhavissanti na bhassaratā na bhassārāmatamanuyuttā, vuddhiyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.
dn16:1.7.5.eng: As long as they don’t relish talk …

dn16:1.7.6.pli: Yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhū na niddārāmā bhavissanti na niddāratā na niddārāmatamanuyuttā, vuddhiyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.

dn16:1.7.7.pli: Yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhū na saṅgaṇikārāmā bhavissanti na saṅgaṇikaratā na saṅgaṇikārāmatamanuyuttā, vuddhiyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.

dn16:1.7.8.pli: Yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhū na pāpicchā bhavissanti na pāpikānaṃ icchānaṃ vasaṃ gatā, vuddhiyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.
dn16:1.7.8.eng: they don’t have corrupt wishes, falling under the sway of corrupt wishes …
dn16:1.7.8.comm: “Corrupt wishes” (pāpicchā) is defined as when a faithless person wishes to be known as faithful, or person otherwise lacking good qualities wishes to be known as having them (AN 10.23:6.2).

dn16:1.7.9.pli: Yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhū na pāpamittā bhavissanti na pāpasahāyā na pāpasampavaṅkā, vuddhiyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.
dn16:1.7.9.eng: they don’t have bad friends, companions, and associates …

dn16:1.7.10.pli: Yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhū na oramattakena visesādhigamena antarāvosānaṃ āpajjissanti, vuddhiyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.
dn16:1.7.10.eng: they don’t stop half-way after achieving some trifling distinction, they can expect growth, not decline.
dn16:1.7.10.comm: This item and the preceding two were the downfall of Devadatta (Iti 89).

dn16:1.8.1.pli: Yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, ime satta aparihāniyā dhammā bhikkhūsu ṭhassanti, imesu ca sattasu aparihāniyesu dhammesu bhikkhū sandississanti, vuddhiyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.
dn16:1.8.1.eng: As long as these seven principles that prevent decline last among the mendicants, and as long as the mendicants are seen following them, they can expect growth, not decline.

dn16:1.8.2.pli: Aparepi vo, bhikkhave, satta aparihāniye dhamme desessāmi …pe….
dn16:1.8.2.eng: I will teach you seven more principles that prevent decline. …

dn16:1.8.3.eng: As long as the mendicants are faithful …

dn16:1.8.9.pli: paññavanto bhavissanti, vuddhiyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.
dn16:1.8.9.eng: wise, they can expect growth, not decline.

dn16:1.8.10.pli: Yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, ime satta aparihāniyā dhammā bhikkhūsu ṭhassanti, imesu ca sattasu aparihāniyesu dhammesu bhikkhū sandississanti, vuddhiyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.
dn16:1.8.10.eng: As long as these seven principles that prevent decline last among the mendicants, and as long as the mendicants are seen following them, they can expect growth, not decline.

dn16:1.8.11.pli: Aparepi vo, bhikkhave, satta aparihāniye dhamme desessāmi, taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasikarotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
dn16:1.8.11.eng: I will teach you seven more principles that prevent decline. …

dn16:1.8.12.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

dn16:1.9.1.eng: As long as the mendicants develop the awakening factors of mindfulness …

dn16:1.9.7.pli: upekkhāsambojjhaṅgaṃ bhāvessanti, vuddhiyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.
dn16:1.9.7.eng: equanimity, they can expect growth, not decline.

dn16:1.10.1.pli: Yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, ime satta aparihāniyā dhammā bhikkhūsu ṭhassanti, imesu ca sattasu aparihāniyesu dhammesu bhikkhū sandississanti, vuddhiyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā no parihāni.
dn16:1.10.1.eng: As long as these seven principles that prevent decline last among the mendicants, and as long as the mendicants are seen following them, they can expect growth, not decline.

dn16:1.10.2.pli: Aparepi vo, bhikkhave, satta aparihāniye dhamme desessāmi, taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasikarotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
dn16:1.10.2.eng: I will teach you seven more principles that prevent decline. …
dn16:1.10.2.comm: As at AN 7.27. These “perceptions” are all meditation practices which are described at AN 10.60.

dn16:1.10.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

dn16:1.10.5.eng: As long as the mendicants develop the perceptions of impermanence …

dn16:1.10.11.pli: nirodhasaññaṃ bhāvessanti, vuddhiyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.
dn16:1.10.11.eng: cessation, they can expect growth, not decline.

dn16:1.10.12.pli: Yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, ime satta aparihāniyā dhammā bhikkhūsu ṭhassanti, imesu ca sattasu aparihāniyesu dhammesu bhikkhū sandississanti, vuddhiyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.
dn16:1.10.12.eng: As long as these seven principles that prevent decline last among the mendicants, and as long as the mendicants are seen following them, they can expect growth, not decline.

dn16:1.11.1.pli: Cha vo, bhikkhave, aparihāniye dhamme desessāmi, taṃ suṇātha, sādhukaṃ manasikarotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
dn16:1.11.1.eng: I will teach you six principles that prevent decline. …
dn16:1.11.1.comm: These six principles are found in several places, but they are not elsewhere called “principles that prevent decline”; for example at AN 6.11 they are called “warm-hearted qualities” (dhammā sāraṇīyā). At AN 6.22, however, a different six qualities are called “principles that prevent decline”: not relishing work, talk, sleep, and company, being easy to admonish, and having good friends.

dn16:1.11.2.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

dn16:1.11.4.pli: “Yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhū mettaṃ kāyakammaṃ paccupaṭṭhāpessanti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ceva raho ca, vuddhiyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.
dn16:1.11.4.eng: As long as the mendicants consistently treat their spiritual companions with bodily kindness …

dn16:1.11.5.pli: Yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhū mettaṃ vacīkammaṃ paccupaṭṭhāpessanti …pe…

dn16:1.11.6.pli: mettaṃ manokammaṃ paccupaṭṭhāpessanti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ceva raho ca, vuddhiyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.
dn16:1.11.6.eng: and mental kindness both in public and in private, they can expect growth, not decline.

dn16:1.11.7.pli: Yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhū, ye te lābhā dhammikā dhammaladdhā antamaso pattapariyāpannamattampi tathārūpehi lābhehi appaṭivibhattabhogī bhavissanti sīlavantehi sabrahmacārīhi sādhāraṇabhogī, vuddhiyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.
dn16:1.11.7.eng: As long as the mendicants share without reservation any material things they have gained by legitimate means, even the food placed in the alms-bowl, using them in common with their ethical spiritual companions, they can expect growth, not decline.

dn16:1.11.8.pli: Yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhū yāni tāni sīlāni akhaṇḍāni acchiddāni asabalāni akammāsāni bhujissāni viññūpasatthāni aparāmaṭṭhāni samādhisaṃvattanikāni tathārūpesu sīlesu sīlasāmaññagatā viharissanti sabrahmacārīhi āvi ceva raho ca, vuddhiyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.
dn16:1.11.8.eng: As long as the mendicants live according to the precepts shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private—such precepts as are intact, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to immersion—they can expect growth, not decline.

dn16:1.11.9.pli: Yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhū yāyaṃ diṭṭhi ariyā niyyānikā, niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya, tathārūpāya diṭṭhiyā diṭṭhisāmaññagatā viharissanti sabrahmacārīhi āvi ceva raho ca, vuddhiyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihāni.
dn16:1.11.9.eng: As long as the mendicants live according to the view shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private—the view that is noble and emancipating, and delivers one who practices it to the complete end of suffering—they can expect growth, not decline.
dn16:1.11.9.comm: This is the right view of the noble eightfold path, in other words, the four noble truths.

dn16:1.11.10.pli: Yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, ime cha aparihāniyā dhammā bhikkhūsu ṭhassanti, imesu ca chasu aparihāniyesu dhammesu bhikkhū sandississanti, vuddhiyeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihānī”ti.
dn16:1.11.10.eng: As long as these six principles that prevent decline last among the mendicants, and as long as the mendicants are seen following them, they can expect growth, not decline.”

dn16:1.12.1.pli: Tatra sudaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharanto gijjhakūṭe pabbate etadeva bahulaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ dhammiṃ kathaṃ karoti:
dn16:1.12.1.eng: And while staying there at the Vulture’s Peak the Buddha often gave this Dhamma talk to the mendicants:
dn16:1.12.1.comm: This epitome of the Dhamma is repeated eight times in this discourse, summarizing the teachings in the Gradual Training. It is not found in this exact form elsewhere.

dn16:1.12.2.eng: “Such is ethics, such is immersion, such is wisdom.

dn16:1.12.3.eng: When immersion is imbued with ethics it’s very fruitful and beneficial.
dn16:1.12.3.comm: “Imbued” (paribhāvita) as a mother hen imbues her eggs with warmth by sitting on them (AN 7.71:2.2). See also SN 55.21:2.3.

dn16:1.12.4.eng: When wisdom is imbued with immersion it’s very fruitful and beneficial.

dn16:1.12.5.pli: Paññāparibhāvitaṃ cittaṃ sammadeva āsavehi vimuccati, seyyathidaṃ—
dn16:1.12.5.eng: When the mind is imbued with wisdom it is rightly freed from the defilements, namely,

dn16:1.12.6.eng: the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.”
dn16:1.12.6.comm: Some editions add diṭṭhāsava (“defilement of views”), but since that appears to be a late interpolation I follow the Mahāsaṅgīti in omitting it.

dn16:1.13.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā rājagahe yathābhirantaṃ viharitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
dn16:1.13.1.eng: When the Buddha had stayed in Rājagaha as long as he pleased, he addressed Venerable Ānanda,

dn16:1.13.2.comm: This is the same rest-house at which the Buddha sojourned on his way from Rājagaha to Nāḷandā in the Brahmajālasutta (DN 1).

dn16:1.13.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paccassosi.

dn16:1.13.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ yena ambalaṭṭhikā tadavasari.
dn16:1.13.4.eng: Then the Buddha together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants arrived at Ambalaṭṭhikā,

dn16:1.14.1.pli: Tatra sudaṃ bhagavā ambalaṭṭhikāyaṃ viharati rājāgārake.
dn16:1.14.1.eng: where he stayed in the royal rest-house.

dn16:1.14.2.pli: Tatrāpi sudaṃ bhagavā ambalaṭṭhikāyaṃ viharanto rājāgārake etadeva bahulaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ dhammiṃ kathaṃ karoti:
dn16:1.14.2.eng: And while staying there, too, he often gave this Dhamma talk to the mendicants:

dn16:1.14.3.eng: “Such is ethics, such is immersion, such is wisdom.

dn16:1.14.4.eng: When immersion is imbued with ethics it’s very fruitful and beneficial.

dn16:1.14.5.eng: When wisdom is imbued with immersion it’s very fruitful and beneficial.

dn16:1.14.6.pli: Paññāparibhāvitaṃ cittaṃ sammadeva āsavehi vimuccati, seyyathidaṃ—
dn16:1.14.6.eng: When the mind is imbued with wisdom it is rightly freed from the defilements, namely,

dn16:1.14.7.eng: the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.”

dn16:1.15.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā ambalaṭṭhikāyaṃ yathābhirantaṃ viharitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
dn16:1.15.1.eng: When the Buddha had stayed in Ambalaṭṭhikā as long as he pleased, he addressed Venerable Ānanda,

dn16:1.15.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paccassosi.

dn16:1.15.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ yena nāḷandā tadavasari,
dn16:1.15.4.eng: Then the Buddha together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants arrived at Nāḷandā,

dn16:1.15.5.pli: tatra sudaṃ bhagavā nāḷandāyaṃ viharati pāvārikambavane.
dn16:1.15.5.eng: where he stayed in Pāvārika’s mango grove.

dn16:1.16.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā sāriputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn16:1.16.1.eng: Then Sāriputta went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
dn16:1.16.1.comm: This was apparently the last time that the Buddha met Sāriputta. This encounter is recorded in an independent sutta at SN 47.12 and expanded into a long discourse at DN 28. The Saṁyutta follows this meeting with the record of Sāriputta’s passing at SN 47.13, and then the lament for the absence of both Sāriputta and Moggallāna at SN 47.14 . For some reason these events were omitted from the present discourse, even though they fit well thematically.

dn16:1.16.2.eng: “Sir, I have such confidence in the Buddha that

dn16:1.16.3.pli: na cāhu na ca bhavissati na cetarahi vijjati añño samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā bhagavatā bhiyyobhiññataro yadidaṃ sambodhiyan”ti.
dn16:1.16.3.eng: I believe there’s no other ascetic or brahmin—whether past, future, or present—whose direct knowledge is superior to the Buddha when it comes to awakening.”

dn16:1.16.4.pli: “Uḷārā kho te ayaṃ, sāriputta, āsabhī vācā bhāsitā, ekaṃso gahito, sīhanādo nadito:
dn16:1.16.4.eng: “That’s a grand and bold statement, Sāriputta. You’ve roared a definitive, categorical lion’s roar, saying:

dn16:1.16.5.eng: ‘I have such confidence in the Buddha that

dn16:1.16.6.pli: na cāhu na ca bhavissati na cetarahi vijjati añño samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā bhagavatā bhiyyobhiññataro yadidaṃ sambodhiyan’ti.
dn16:1.16.6.eng: I believe there’s no other ascetic or brahmin—whether past, future, or present—whose direct knowledge is superior to the Buddha when it comes to awakening.’

dn16:1.16.7.pli: Kiṃ te, sāriputta, ye te ahesuṃ atītamaddhānaṃ arahanto sammāsambuddhā, sabbe te bhagavanto cetasā ceto paricca viditā:
dn16:1.16.7.eng: What about all the perfected ones, the fully awakened Buddhas who lived in the past? Have you encompassed their minds to know that

dn16:1.16.8.pli: ‘evaṃsīlā te bhagavanto ahesuṃ itipi, evaṃdhammā evaṃpaññā evaṃvihārī evaṃvimuttā te bhagavanto ahesuṃ itipī’”ti?
dn16:1.16.8.eng: those Buddhas had such ethics, or such qualities, or such wisdom, or such meditation, or such freedom?”

dn16:1.16.10.pli: “Kiṃ pana te, sāriputta, ye te bhavissanti anāgatamaddhānaṃ arahanto sammāsambuddhā, sabbe te bhagavanto cetasā ceto paricca viditā:
dn16:1.16.10.eng: “And what about all the perfected ones, the fully awakened Buddhas who will live in the future? Have you encompassed their minds to know that

dn16:1.16.11.pli: ‘evaṃsīlā te bhagavanto bhavissanti itipi, evaṃdhammā evaṃpaññā evaṃvihārī evaṃvimuttā te bhagavanto bhavissanti itipī’”ti?
dn16:1.16.11.eng: those Buddhas will have such ethics, or such qualities, or such wisdom, or such meditation, or such freedom?”

dn16:1.16.13.pli: “Kiṃ pana te, sāriputta, ahaṃ etarahi arahaṃ sammāsambuddho cetasā ceto paricca vidito:
dn16:1.16.13.eng: “And what about me, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha at present? Have you encompassed my mind to know that

dn16:1.16.14.pli: ‘evaṃsīlo bhagavā itipi, evaṃdhammo evaṃpañño evaṃvihārī evaṃvimutto bhagavā itipī’”ti?
dn16:1.16.14.eng: I have such ethics, or such qualities, or such wisdom, or such meditation, or such freedom?”

dn16:1.16.16.pli: “Ettha ca hi te, sāriputta, atītānāgatapaccuppannesu arahantesu sammāsambuddhesu cetopariyañāṇaṃ natthi.
dn16:1.16.16.eng: “In that case, Sāriputta, given that you don’t encompass the minds of Buddhas past, future, or present,

dn16:1.16.17.pli: Atha kiñcarahi te ayaṃ, sāriputta, uḷārā āsabhī vācā bhāsitā, ekaṃso gahito, sīhanādo nadito:
dn16:1.16.17.eng: what then are you doing, making such a grand and bold statement, roaring such a definitive, categorical lion’s roar?”

dn16:1.16.18.pli: ‘evaṃpasanno ahaṃ, bhante, bhagavati; na cāhu na ca bhavissati na cetarahi vijjati añño samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā bhagavatā bhiyyobhiññataro yadidaṃ sambodhiyan’”ti?

dn16:1.17.1.pli: “Na kho me, bhante, atītānāgatapaccuppannesu arahantesu sammāsambuddhesu cetopariyañāṇaṃ atthi,
dn16:1.17.1.eng: “Sir, though I don’t encompass the minds of Buddhas past, future, and present,

dn16:1.17.2.eng: still I understand this by inference from the teaching.
dn16:1.17.2.comm: As at DN 14:1.37.4, inference (anvaya) is regarded as a valid form of knowledge. The Buddha himself is said to rely on inference using the same simile at AN 10.95:10.4. See SN 12.33 and notes for discussion.

dn16:1.17.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, rañño paccantimaṃ nagaraṃ daḷhuddhāpaṃ daḷhapākāratoraṇaṃ ekadvāraṃ,
dn16:1.17.3.eng: Suppose there was a king’s frontier citadel with fortified embankments, ramparts, and arches, and a single gate.

dn16:1.17.4.pli: tatrassa dovāriko paṇḍito viyatto medhāvī aññātānaṃ nivāretā ñātānaṃ pavesetā.
dn16:1.17.4.eng: And it has a gatekeeper who is astute, competent, and intelligent. He keeps strangers out and lets known people in.

dn16:1.17.5.pli: So tassa nagarassa samantā anupariyāyapathaṃ anukkamamāno na passeyya pākārasandhiṃ vā pākāravivaraṃ vā, antamaso biḷāranikkhamanamattampi.
dn16:1.17.5.eng: As he walks around the patrol path, he doesn’t see a hole or cleft in the wall, not even one big enough for a cat to slip out.

dn16:1.17.7.pli: ‘ye kho keci oḷārikā pāṇā imaṃ nagaraṃ pavisanti vā nikkhamanti vā, sabbe te imināva dvārena pavisanti vā nikkhamanti vā’ti.
dn16:1.17.7.eng: ‘Whatever sizable creatures enter or leave the citadel, all of them do so via this gate.’

dn16:1.17.8.pli: Evameva kho me, bhante, dhammanvayo vidito:
dn16:1.17.8.eng: In the same way, I understand this by inference from the teaching:

dn16:1.17.9.pli: ‘ye te, bhante, ahesuṃ atītamaddhānaṃ arahanto sammāsambuddhā, sabbe te bhagavanto pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu supatiṭṭhitacittā sattabojjhaṅge yathābhūtaṃ bhāvetvā anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambujjhiṃsu.
dn16:1.17.9.eng: ‘All the perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas—whether past, future, or present—give up the five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom. Their mind is firmly established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. They correctly develop the seven awakening factors. And they awaken to the supreme perfect awakening.’”

dn16:1.17.10.pli: Yepi te, bhante, bhavissanti anāgatamaddhānaṃ arahanto sammāsambuddhā, sabbe te bhagavanto pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu supatiṭṭhitacittā satta bojjhaṅge yathābhūtaṃ bhāvetvā anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambujjhissanti.

dn16:1.17.11.pli: Bhagavāpi, bhante, etarahi arahaṃ sammāsambuddho pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu supatiṭṭhitacitto satta bojjhaṅge yathābhūtaṃ bhāvetvā anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddho’”ti.

dn16:1.18.1.pli: Tatrapi sudaṃ bhagavā nāḷandāyaṃ viharanto pāvārikambavane etadeva bahulaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ dhammiṃ kathaṃ karoti:
dn16:1.18.1.eng: And while staying at Nāḷandā, too, the Buddha often gave this Dhamma talk to the mendicants:

dn16:1.18.2.eng: “Such is ethics, such is immersion, such is wisdom.

dn16:1.18.3.eng: When immersion is imbued with ethics it’s very fruitful and beneficial.

dn16:1.18.4.eng: When wisdom is imbued with immersion it’s very fruitful and beneficial.

dn16:1.18.5.pli: Paññāparibhāvitaṃ cittaṃ sammadeva āsavehi vimuccati, seyyathidaṃ—
dn16:1.18.5.eng: When the mind is imbued with wisdom it is rightly freed from the defilements, namely,

dn16:1.18.6.eng: the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.”

dn16:1.19.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā nāḷandāyaṃ yathābhirantaṃ viharitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
dn16:1.19.1.eng: When the Buddha had stayed in Nāḷandā as long as he pleased, he addressed Venerable Ānanda,

dn16:1.19.2.eng: “Come, Ānanda, let’s go to Pāṭali Village.”
dn16:1.19.2.comm: This is modern Patna. In this account we see how it was developed from the simple riverside village of Pāṭaligāma to the citadel of Pāṭaliputta. Ajātasattu ultimately moved the capital of Magadha from the defensively-postured Rājagaha surrounded by hills to this trading center on open waters. Under Ashoka it became one of the greatest cities of the ancient world. It was named after the pāṭalī tree (Stereospermum chelonoides), known as patala in Hindi.

dn16:1.19.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paccassosi.

dn16:1.19.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ yena pāṭaligāmo tadavasari.
dn16:1.19.4.eng: Then the Buddha together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants arrived at Pāṭali Village.

dn16:1.20.1.pli: Assosuṃ kho pāṭaligāmikā upāsakā: “bhagavā kira pāṭaligāmaṃ anuppatto”ti.
dn16:1.20.1.eng: The lay followers of Pāṭali Village heard that he had arrived.

dn16:1.20.2.pli: Atha kho pāṭaligāmikā upāsakā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho pāṭaligāmikā upāsakā bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
dn16:1.20.2.eng: So they went to see him, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

dn16:1.20.3.eng: “Sir, please consent to come to our guest house.”

dn16:1.21.1.pli: Atha kho pāṭaligāmikā upāsakā bhagavato adhivāsanaṃ viditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā yena āvasathāgāraṃ tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā sabbasanthariṃ āvasathāgāraṃ santharitvā āsanāni paññapetvā udakamaṇikaṃ patiṭṭhāpetvā telapadīpaṃ āropetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho pāṭaligāmikā upāsakā bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
dn16:1.21.1.eng: Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, the lay followers of Pāṭali Village got up from their seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right. Then they went to the guest house, where they spread carpets all over, prepared seats, set up a water jar, and placed an oil lamp. Then they went back to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and told him of their preparations, saying:

dn16:1.21.2.pli: “sabbasantharisanthataṃ, bhante, āvasathāgāraṃ, āsanāni paññattāni, udakamaṇiko patiṭṭhāpito, telapadīpo āropito;

dn16:1.22.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghena yena āvasathāgāraṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā pāde pakkhāletvā āvasathāgāraṃ pavisitvā majjhimaṃ thambhaṃ nissāya puratthābhimukho nisīdi.
dn16:1.22.1.eng: In the morning, the Buddha robed up and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the guest house together with the Saṅgha of mendicants. Having washed his feet he entered the guest house and sat against the central column facing east.

dn16:1.22.2.pli: Bhikkhusaṅghopi kho pāde pakkhāletvā āvasathāgāraṃ pavisitvā pacchimaṃ bhittiṃ nissāya puratthābhimukho nisīdi bhagavantameva purakkhatvā.
dn16:1.22.2.eng: The Saṅgha of mendicants also washed their feet, entered the guest house, and sat against the west wall facing east, with the Buddha right in front of them.

dn16:1.22.3.pli: Pāṭaligāmikāpi kho upāsakā pāde pakkhāletvā āvasathāgāraṃ pavisitvā puratthimaṃ bhittiṃ nissāya pacchimābhimukhā nisīdiṃsu bhagavantameva purakkhatvā.
dn16:1.22.3.eng: The lay followers of Pāṭali Village also washed their feet, entered the guest house, and sat against the east wall facing west, with the Buddha right in front of them.

dn16:1.23.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pāṭaligāmike upāsake āmantesi:

dn16:1.23.2.eng: “Householders, there are these five drawbacks for an unethical person because of their failure in ethics.
dn16:1.23.2.comm: Also at AN 5.213, Ud 8.6:4.1, DN 33:2.1.36, and Kd 1:28.4.1.

dn16:1.23.4.pli: Idha, gahapatayo, dussīlo sīlavipanno pamādādhikaraṇaṃ mahatiṃ bhogajāniṃ nigacchati.
dn16:1.23.4.eng: Firstly, an unethical person loses great wealth on account of negligence.
dn16:1.23.4.comm: The Buddha begins with the things most obvious and pertinent to the audience.

dn16:1.23.5.eng: This is the first drawback for an unethical person because of their failure in ethics.

dn16:1.23.6.pli: Puna caparaṃ, gahapatayo, dussīlassa sīlavipannassa pāpako kittisaddo abbhuggacchati.
dn16:1.23.6.eng: Furthermore, an unethical person gets a bad reputation.

dn16:1.23.8.pli: Puna caparaṃ, gahapatayo, dussīlo sīlavipanno yaññadeva parisaṃ upasaṅkamati—yadi khattiyaparisaṃ yadi brāhmaṇaparisaṃ yadi gahapatiparisaṃ yadi samaṇaparisaṃ—avisārado upasaṅkamati maṅkubhūto.
dn16:1.23.8.eng: Furthermore, an unethical person enters any kind of assembly timid and embarrassed, whether it’s an assembly of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or ascetics.

dn16:1.23.10.pli: Puna caparaṃ, gahapatayo, dussīlo sīlavipanno sammūḷho kālaṃ karoti.
dn16:1.23.10.eng: Furthermore, an unethical person feels lost when they die.

dn16:1.23.12.pli: Puna caparaṃ, gahapatayo, dussīlo sīlavipanno kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati.
dn16:1.23.12.eng: Furthermore, an unethical person, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

dn16:1.23.14.pli: Ime kho, gahapatayo, pañca ādīnavā dussīlassa sīlavipattiyā.
dn16:1.23.14.eng: These are the five drawbacks for an unethical person because of their failure in ethics.

dn16:1.24.1.eng: There are these five benefits for an ethical person because of their accomplishment in ethics.

dn16:1.24.3.pli: Idha, gahapatayo, sīlavā sīlasampanno appamādādhikaraṇaṃ mahantaṃ bhogakkhandhaṃ adhigacchati.
dn16:1.24.3.eng: Firstly, an ethical person gains great wealth on account of diligence.

dn16:1.24.5.pli: Puna caparaṃ, gahapatayo, sīlavato sīlasampannassa kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggacchati.
dn16:1.24.5.eng: Furthermore, an ethical person gets a good reputation.

dn16:1.24.7.pli: Puna caparaṃ, gahapatayo, sīlavā sīlasampanno yaññadeva parisaṃ upasaṅkamati—yadi khattiyaparisaṃ yadi brāhmaṇaparisaṃ yadi gahapatiparisaṃ yadi samaṇaparisaṃ visārado upasaṅkamati amaṅkubhūto.
dn16:1.24.7.eng: Furthermore, an ethical person enters any kind of assembly bold and self-assured, whether it’s an assembly of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or ascetics.

dn16:1.24.9.pli: Puna caparaṃ, gahapatayo, sīlavā sīlasampanno asammūḷho kālaṃ karoti.
dn16:1.24.9.eng: Furthermore, an ethical person dies not feeling lost.

dn16:1.24.11.pli: Puna caparaṃ, gahapatayo, sīlavā sīlasampanno kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
dn16:1.24.11.eng: Furthermore, when an ethical person’s body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

dn16:1.24.13.pli: Ime kho, gahapatayo, pañca ānisaṃsā sīlavato sīlasampadāyā”ti.
dn16:1.24.13.eng: These are the five benefits for an ethical person because of their accomplishment in ethics.”

dn16:1.25.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pāṭaligāmike upāsake bahudeva rattiṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandassetvā samādapetvā samuttejetvā sampahaṃsetvā uyyojesi:
dn16:1.25.1.eng: The Buddha spent much of the night educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the lay followers of Pāṭali Village with a Dhamma talk. Then he sent them off,

dn16:1.25.2.pli: “abhikkantā kho, gahapatayo, ratti, yassadāni tumhe kālaṃ maññathā”ti.
dn16:1.25.2.eng: “The night is getting late, householders. Please go at your convenience.”

dn16:1.25.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho pāṭaligāmikā upāsakā bhagavato paṭissutvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkamiṃsu.
dn16:1.25.3.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied the lay followers of Pāṭali Village. They got up from their seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right, before leaving.

dn16:1.25.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā acirapakkantesu pāṭaligāmikesu upāsakesu suññāgāraṃ pāvisi.
dn16:1.25.4.eng: Soon after they left the Buddha entered a private cubicle.
dn16:1.25.4.comm: Suññāgāra normally means an “empty dwelling”, but here the commentary describes it as a curtained-off cubicle.

dn16:1.26.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sunidhavassakārā magadhamahāmattā pāṭaligāme nagaraṃ māpenti vajjīnaṃ paṭibāhāya.
dn16:1.26.1.eng: Now at that time the Magadhan ministers Sunidha and Vassakāra were building a citadel at Pāṭali Village to keep the Vajjis out.
dn16:1.26.1.comm: Vassakāra was no dawdler, as he preceded the Buddha to Pāṭaligāma. And not long after, he returned to Rājagaha to build more fortifications there (MN 108:6.2). | Nagara here means “citadel, fortress”, not “city”. It has the same sense as pura. The construction is defensive and may well have begun before Ajātasattu began thinking of invading.

dn16:1.26.2.pli: Tena samayena sambahulā devatāyo sahasseva pāṭaligāme vatthūni pariggaṇhanti.
dn16:1.26.2.eng: At that time thousands of deities were taking possession of building sites in Pāṭali Village.
dn16:1.26.2.comm: The relation between deities and building sites (vatthu) appears only in this passage in the early texts (repeated at Ud 8.6:15.2 and Kd 1:28.7.3). Divination and geomancy (vatthuvijjā) for building sites is said to be a wrong livelihood at DN 1:1.21.2.

dn16:1.26.3.pli: Yasmiṃ padese mahesakkhā devatā vatthūni pariggaṇhanti, mahesakkhānaṃ tattha raññaṃ rājamahāmattānaṃ cittāni namanti nivesanāni māpetuṃ.
dn16:1.26.3.eng: Illustrious rulers or royal ministers inclined to build houses at sites possessed by illustrious deities.

dn16:1.27.1.pli: Yasmiṃ padese majjhimā devatā vatthūni pariggaṇhanti, majjhimānaṃ tattha raññaṃ rājamahāmattānaṃ cittāni namanti nivesanāni māpetuṃ.
dn16:1.27.1.eng: Middling rulers or royal ministers inclined to build houses at sites possessed by middling deities.

dn16:1.27.2.pli: Yasmiṃ padese nīcā devatā vatthūni pariggaṇhanti, nīcānaṃ tattha raññaṃ rājamahāmattānaṃ cittāni namanti nivesanāni māpetuṃ.
dn16:1.27.2.eng: Lesser rulers or royal ministers inclined to build houses at sites possessed by lesser deities.

dn16:1.27.3.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena tā devatāyo sahasseva pāṭaligāme vatthūni pariggaṇhantiyo.
dn16:1.27.3.eng: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, the Buddha saw those deities taking possession of building sites in Pāṭali Village.

dn16:1.27.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā rattiyā paccūsasamayaṃ paccuṭṭhāya āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
dn16:1.27.4.eng: The Buddha rose at the crack of dawn and addressed Ānanda,

dn16:1.27.5.pli: “Ke nu kho, ānanda, pāṭaligāme nagaraṃ māpentī”ti?
dn16:1.27.5.eng: “Ānanda, who is building a citadel at Pāṭali Village?”

dn16:1.27.6.pli: “Sunidhavassakārā, bhante, magadhamahāmattā pāṭaligāme nagaraṃ māpenti vajjīnaṃ paṭibāhāyā”ti.
dn16:1.27.6.eng: “Sir, the Magadhan ministers Sunidha and Vassakāra are building a citadel to keep the Vajjis out.”

dn16:1.28.1.eng: “It’s as if they were building the citadel in consultation with the gods of the thirty-three.

dn16:1.28.2.pli: evameva kho, ānanda, sunidhavassakārā magadhamahāmattā pāṭaligāme nagaraṃ māpenti vajjīnaṃ paṭibāhāya.

dn16:1.28.3.pli: Idhāhaṃ, ānanda, addasaṃ dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena sambahulā devatāyo sahasseva pāṭaligāme vatthūni pariggaṇhantiyo.
dn16:1.28.3.eng: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I saw those deities taking possession of building sites.

dn16:1.28.4.pli: Yasmiṃ, ānanda, padese mahesakkhā devatā vatthūni pariggaṇhanti, mahesakkhānaṃ tattha raññaṃ rājamahāmattānaṃ cittāni namanti nivesanāni māpetuṃ.
dn16:1.28.4.eng: Illustrious rulers or royal ministers inclined to build houses at sites possessed by illustrious deities.

dn16:1.28.5.pli: Yasmiṃ padese majjhimā devatā vatthūni pariggaṇhanti, majjhimānaṃ tattha raññaṃ rājamahāmattānaṃ cittāni namanti nivesanāni māpetuṃ.
dn16:1.28.5.eng: Middling rulers or royal ministers inclined to build houses at sites possessed by middling deities.

dn16:1.28.6.pli: Yasmiṃ padese nīcā devatā vatthūni pariggaṇhanti, nīcānaṃ tattha raññaṃ rājamahāmattānaṃ cittāni namanti nivesanāni māpetuṃ.
dn16:1.28.6.eng: Lesser rulers or royal ministers inclined to build houses at sites possessed by lesser deities.

dn16:1.28.7.pli: Yāvatā, ānanda, ariyaṃ āyatanaṃ yāvatā vaṇippatho idaṃ agganagaraṃ bhavissati pāṭaliputtaṃ puṭabhedanaṃ.
dn16:1.28.7.eng: As far as the civilized region extends, as far as the trading zone extends, this will be the chief city: the Pāṭaliputta trade center.
dn16:1.28.7.comm: From this point, later texts always refer to Pāṭaliputta, but the reason for the change of name from Pāṭaligāma is not explained in the commentary. Putta is a suffix indicating the people of a certain clan or place, so pāṭaliputta means “a person from Pāṭalī (village)” or as we might say, “Pāṭalian”. As the city became well known and its identity as a village receded, it must have become known as the “city of the Pāṭaliputtas” and hence simply Pāṭaliputta. Compare the uses of ñātika below. | The commentary explains that puṭabhedanaṁ refers to the “opening of packages”, signifying that it was a center of trade. This usage is attested as late as the 13th century Jain Vividhatīrthakalpa of Jinaprabhasūri. | “Civilized region” is ariyaṁ āyatanaṁ, the cultural region defined by use of the Ariyaka language (cf. AN 6.96:1.3, Ud 8.6:17.9 and note to DN 26:4.8).

dn16:1.28.8.pli: Pāṭaliputtassa kho, ānanda, tayo antarāyā bhavissanti—
dn16:1.28.8.eng: But Pāṭaliputta will face three threats:

dn16:1.28.9.pli: aggito vā udakato vā mithubhedā vā”ti.
dn16:1.28.9.comm: Excavations reveal that Pāṭaliputta was constructed of wood, so the danger of fire was real. It is situated on a low-lying flood plain of the Ganges, so flooding would also have been an obvious danger. As for dissension (mithubheda), Vassakāra had indicated that this was a means of bringing down the Vajjis, so it would seem that kamma was lying in wait for them.

dn16:1.29.1.pli: Atha kho sunidhavassakārā magadhamahāmattā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu,
dn16:1.29.1.eng: Then the Magadhan ministers Sunidha and Vassakāra approached the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

dn16:1.29.2.pli: sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu, ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho sunidhavassakārā magadhamahāmattā bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
dn16:1.29.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they stood to one side and said,

dn16:1.29.3.pli: “adhivāsetu no bhavaṃ gotamo ajjatanāya bhattaṃ saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghenā”ti.
dn16:1.29.3.eng: “Would the worthy Gotama together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept today’s meal from me?”

dn16:1.30.1.pli: Atha kho sunidhavassakārā magadhamahāmattā bhagavato adhivāsanaṃ viditvā yena sako āvasatho tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā sake āvasathe paṇītaṃ khādanīyaṃ bhojanīyaṃ paṭiyādāpetvā bhagavato kālaṃ ārocāpesuṃ:
dn16:1.30.1.eng: Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, they went to their own guest house, where they had delicious fresh and cooked foods prepared. Then they had the Buddha informed of the time, saying,

dn16:1.30.2.eng: “It’s time, worthy Gotama, the meal is ready.”

dn16:1.30.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghena yena sunidhavassakārānaṃ magadhamahāmattānaṃ āvasatho tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
dn16:1.30.3.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to their guest house together with the mendicant Saṅgha, where he sat on the seat spread out.

dn16:1.30.4.pli: Atha kho sunidhavassakārā magadhamahāmattā buddhappamukhaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappesuṃ sampavāresuṃ.
dn16:1.30.4.eng: Then Sunidha and Vassakāra served and satisfied the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha with their own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.

dn16:1.30.5.pli: Atha kho sunidhavassakārā magadhamahāmattā bhagavantaṃ bhuttāviṃ onītapattapāṇiṃ aññataraṃ nīcaṃ āsanaṃ gahetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.
dn16:1.30.5.eng: When the Buddha had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, Sunidha and Vassakāra took a low seat and sat to one side.

dn16:1.31.1.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinne kho sunidhavassakāre magadhamahāmatte bhagavā imāhi gāthāhi anumodi:
dn16:1.31.1.eng: The Buddha expressed his appreciation with these verses:
dn16:1.31.1.comm: This is the anumodanā recited for the meal offering. Other examples are found at Snp 3.7:34.3 = MN 92:25.6, SN 55.26:20.1, Kd 1:15.14.4, and Kd 1:1.5.1. | It is worth noting that no early anomodanā uses the imperative verb form -tu signifying giving a blessing (eg. bhavatu sabbamaṅgalaṁ, “may all blessings be”). They strictly use the indicative -ti to teach cause and effect: if you do this, that happens.

dn16:1.31.2.eng: “In the place he makes his dwelling,

dn16:1.31.6.comm: Buddhism promotes good neighborliness with all beings, seen and unseen. Making an offering to the local spirits helps create a positive and healthy sense of place.

dn16:1.31.10.eng: After that they have sympathy for him,

dn16:1.31.11.eng: like a mother for the child at her breast.

dn16:1.31.12.eng: A man beloved of the deities

dn16:1.31.13.comm: At AN 4.67:8.3 a similar sentiment is expressed for animals.

dn16:1.31.14.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sunidhavassakāre magadhamahāmatte imāhi gāthāhi anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi.
dn16:1.31.14.eng: When the Buddha had expressed his appreciation to Sunidha and Vassakāra with these verses, he got up from his seat and left.

dn16:1.32.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sunidhavassakārā magadhamahāmattā bhagavantaṃ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandhā honti:
dn16:1.32.1.eng: Sunidha and Vassakāra followed behind the Buddha, thinking,

dn16:1.32.2.pli: “yenajja samaṇo gotamo dvārena nikkhamissati, taṃ gotamadvāraṃ nāma bhavissati.
dn16:1.32.2.eng: “The gate through which the ascetic Gotama exits today shall be named the Gotama Gate.

dn16:1.32.3.pli: Yena titthena gaṅgaṃ nadiṃ tarissati, taṃ gotamatitthaṃ nāma bhavissatī”ti.
dn16:1.32.3.eng: The ford at which he crosses the Ganges River shall be named the Gotama Ford.”
dn16:1.32.3.comm: The “ford” (tittha) is symbolic; those who forge a path to salvation are called titthakara, such as the six leading ascetics of DN 2. Today there is a 5.7 km bridge at this crossing, which is appropriately called the Mahatma Gandhi Setu.

dn16:1.32.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā yena dvārena nikkhami, taṃ gotamadvāraṃ nāma ahosi.
dn16:1.32.4.eng: Then the gate through which the Buddha exited was named the Gotama Gate.

dn16:1.32.5.pli: Atha kho bhagavā yena gaṅgā nadī tenupasaṅkami.
dn16:1.32.5.eng: Then the Buddha came to the Ganges River.

dn16:1.33.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena gaṅgā nadī pūrā hoti samatittikā kākapeyyā.
dn16:1.33.1.eng: Now at that time the Ganges was full to the brim so a crow could drink from it.

dn16:1.33.2.pli: Appekacce manussā nāvaṃ pariyesanti, appekacce uḷumpaṃ pariyesanti, appekacce kullaṃ bandhanti apārā, pāraṃ gantukāmā.
dn16:1.33.2.eng: Wanting to cross from the near to the far shore, some people were seeking a boat, some a dinghy, while some were tying up a raft.

dn16:1.33.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṃ vā bāhaṃ pasāreyya, pasāritaṃ vā bāhaṃ samiñjeyya; evameva—gaṅgāya nadiyā orimatīre antarahito pārimatīre paccuṭṭhāsi saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghena.
dn16:1.33.3.eng: But, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, the Buddha, together with the mendicant Saṅgha, vanished from the near shore and landed on the far shore.
dn16:1.33.3.comm: In this stock phrase, we sometimes find paccuṭṭhāsi (“landed”) and sometimes pāturahosi (“reappeared”).

dn16:1.34.1.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā te manusse appekacce nāvaṃ pariyesante appekacce uḷumpaṃ pariyesante appekacce kullaṃ bandhante apārā pāraṃ gantukāme.
dn16:1.34.1.eng: He saw all those humans wanting to cross over.

dn16:1.34.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
dn16:1.34.2.eng: Knowing the meaning of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

dn16:1.34.3.eng: “Those who cross a deluge or stream
dn16:1.34.3.comm: Aṇṇavaṁ cannot mean “sea” here, since it is to be crossed with a bridge.

dn16:1.34.4.eng: have built a bridge and left the marshes behind.

dn16:1.34.5.eng: While some people are still tying a raft,

dn16:2.1.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
dn16:2.1.1.eng: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Ānanda,

dn16:2.1.2.eng: “Come, Ānanda, let’s go to the village of Koṭi.”
dn16:2.1.2.comm: Koṭigāma lay a short distance from the Ganges. The Buddha’s stay here must therefore have followed the events of SN 47.14 at Ukkacelā on the Vajjian bank of the Ganges, where he laments the passing of Sāriputta and Moggallāna. He would have heard of Sāriputta’s passing before then, while on the road from Nāḷandā to Pāṭaligāma, even though that is implausibly said to have happened at Sāvatthī (SN 47.13).

dn16:2.1.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paccassosi.

dn16:2.1.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ yena koṭigāmo tadavasari.
dn16:2.1.4.eng: Then the Buddha together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants arrived at the village of Koṭi,

dn16:2.2.2.pli: “Catunnaṃ, bhikkhave, ariyasaccānaṃ ananubodhā appaṭivedhā evamidaṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ sandhāvitaṃ saṃsaritaṃ mamañceva tumhākañca.
dn16:2.2.2.eng: “Mendicants, due to not understanding and not penetrating four noble truths, both you and I have wandered and transmigrated for such a very long time.

dn16:2.2.4.pli: Dukkhassa, bhikkhave, ariyasaccassa ananubodhā appaṭivedhā evamidaṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ sandhāvitaṃ saṃsaritaṃ mamañceva tumhākañca.

dn16:2.2.5.pli: Dukkhasamudayassa, bhikkhave, ariyasaccassa ananubodhā appaṭivedhā evamidaṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ sandhāvitaṃ saṃsaritaṃ mamañceva tumhākañca.

dn16:2.2.6.pli: Dukkhanirodhassa, bhikkhave, ariyasaccassa ananubodhā appaṭivedhā evamidaṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ sandhāvitaṃ saṃsaritaṃ mamañceva tumhākañca.

dn16:2.2.7.pli: Dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya, bhikkhave, ariyasaccassa ananubodhā appaṭivedhā evamidaṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ sandhāvitaṃ saṃsaritaṃ mamañceva tumhākañca.
dn16:2.2.7.eng: and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.

dn16:2.2.8.pli: Tayidaṃ, bhikkhave, dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ anubuddhaṃ paṭividdhaṃ, dukkhasamudayaṃ ariyasaccaṃ anubuddhaṃ paṭividdhaṃ, dukkhanirodhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ anubuddhaṃ paṭividdhaṃ, dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccaṃ anubuddhaṃ paṭividdhaṃ, ucchinnā bhavataṇhā, khīṇā bhavanetti, natthi dāni punabbhavo”ti.
dn16:2.2.8.eng: These noble truths of suffering, origin, cessation, and the path have been understood and comprehended. Craving for continued existence has been cut off; the leash to existence is ended; now there’ll be no more future lives.”

dn16:2.3.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

dn16:2.3.2.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
dn16:2.3.2.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

dn16:2.3.5.eng: we have transmigrated for a long time

dn16:2.3.6.eng: from one rebirth to the next.

dn16:2.3.7.eng: But now that these truths have been seen,

dn16:2.3.8.eng: the leash to existence is eradicated.

dn16:2.3.9.eng: The root of suffering is cut off,

dn16:2.3.10.eng: now there’ll be no more future lives.”

dn16:2.4.1.pli: Tatrapi sudaṃ bhagavā koṭigāme viharanto etadeva bahulaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ dhammiṃ kathaṃ karoti:
dn16:2.4.1.eng: And while staying at the village of Koṭi, too, the Buddha often gave this Dhamma talk to the mendicants:

dn16:2.4.2.eng: “Such is ethics, such is immersion, such is wisdom.

dn16:2.4.3.eng: When immersion is imbued with ethics it’s very fruitful and beneficial.

dn16:2.4.4.eng: When wisdom is imbued with immersion it’s very fruitful and beneficial.

dn16:2.4.5.pli: Paññāparibhāvitaṃ cittaṃ sammadeva āsavehi vimuccati, seyyathidaṃ—
dn16:2.4.5.eng: When the mind is imbued with wisdom it is rightly freed from the defilements, namely,

dn16:2.4.6.eng: the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.”

dn16:2.5.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā koṭigāme yathābhirantaṃ viharitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
dn16:2.5.1.eng: When the Buddha had stayed in the village of Koṭi as long as he pleased, he said to Ānanda,

dn16:2.5.2.eng: “Come, Ānanda, let’s go to the land of the Ñātikas.”
dn16:2.5.2.comm: Ñātika (also spelled nātika, or nādika; Sanskrit jñātṛka; Prākrit nāyika) was the clan to which the Jain leader Mahāvīra (called Nāṭaputta, i.e. Ñātiputta) belonged. Here it is unusually spelled in plural, which means “the land of the Ñātika clan”.

dn16:2.5.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paccassosi.

dn16:2.5.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ yena nātikā tadavasari.
dn16:2.5.4.eng: Then the Buddha together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants arrived in the land of the Ñātikas,

dn16:2.5.5.pli: Tatrapi sudaṃ bhagavā nātike viharati giñjakāvasathe.
dn16:2.5.5.eng: where he stayed in the brick house at Ñātika.
dn16:2.5.5.comm: Here Ñātika is in singular and appears to be the name of a town. Thus Ñātika is first of all a name of a clan, then the land they live in, then their chief town. | Over a millennium previously, the Indus Valley Civilization had built cities of fired brick with standardized size and construction methods, but in the Buddha’s day most buildings were wood. This is the only brick building mentioned in the suttas; brick construction is also discussed in the Vinaya.

dn16:2.6.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn16:2.6.1.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

dn16:2.6.2.pli: “sāḷho nāma, bhante, bhikkhu nātike kālaṅkato, tassa kā gati, ko abhisamparāyo?
dn16:2.6.2.eng: “Sir, the monk named Sāḷha has passed away in Ñātika. Where has he been reborn in his next life?
dn16:2.6.2.comm: It is unprecedented to discuss the spiritual destinies of an entire town like this. Normally this question is only asked when specific individuals known to the Buddha have passed away. Likely the passage was created in the wake of the passing of Mahāvīra to show that even his own people were enthusiastic Buddhists. This portion of the text is also found at SN 55.8.

dn16:2.6.3.pli: Nandā nāma, bhante, bhikkhunī nātike kālaṅkatā, tassā kā gati, ko abhisamparāyo?

dn16:2.6.4.pli: Sudatto nāma, bhante, upāsako nātike kālaṅkato, tassa kā gati, ko abhisamparāyo?

dn16:2.6.5.pli: Sujātā nāma, bhante, upāsikā nātike kālaṅkatā, tassā kā gati, ko abhisamparāyo?
dn16:2.6.5.eng: and the laywoman named Sujātā have passed away in Ñātika. Where have they been reborn in the next life?
dn16:2.6.5.comm: SN 55.9 inserts another series on a monk, nun, layman, and laywoman all called Asoka.

dn16:2.6.6.pli: Kukkuṭo nāma, bhante, upāsako nātike kālaṅkato, tassa kā gati, ko abhisamparāyo?
dn16:2.6.6.comm: This portion of the text is at SN 55.10. I spell names consistently with there.

dn16:2.6.13.pli: subhaddo nāma, bhante, upāsako nātike kālaṅkato, tassa kā gati, ko abhisamparāyo”ti?
dn16:2.6.13.eng: Subhadda have passed away in Ñātika. Where have they been reborn in the next life?”

dn16:2.7.1.pli: “Sāḷho, ānanda, bhikkhu āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
dn16:2.7.1.eng: “Ānanda, the monk Sāḷha had realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, having realized it with his own insight due to the ending of defilements.

dn16:2.7.2.pli: Nandā, ānanda, bhikkhunī pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā opapātikā tattha parinibbāyinī anāvattidhammā tasmā lokā.
dn16:2.7.2.eng: The nun Nandā had ended the five lower fetters. She’s been reborn spontaneously, and will be extinguished there, not liable to return from that world.

dn16:2.7.3.pli: Sudatto, ānanda, upāsako tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṃ tanuttā sakadāgāmī sakideva imaṃ lokaṃ āgantvā dukkhassantaṃ karissati.
dn16:2.7.3.eng: The layman Sudatta had ended three fetters, and weakened greed, hate, and delusion. He’s a once-returner; he will come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering.

dn16:2.7.4.pli: Sujātā, ānanda, upāsikā tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā sotāpannā avinipātadhammā niyatā sambodhiparāyaṇā.
dn16:2.7.4.eng: The laywoman Sujātā had ended three fetters. She’s a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.

dn16:2.7.5.pli: Kukkuṭo, ānanda, upāsako pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā opapātiko tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā.

dn16:2.7.12.pli: subhaddo, ānanda, upāsako pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā opapātiko tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā.
dn16:2.7.12.eng: and Subhadda had ended the five lower fetters. They’ve been reborn spontaneously, and will be extinguished there, not liable to return from that world.
dn16:2.7.12.comm: The suttas consistently depict lay folk as attaining the third stage of awakening, non-return, but not the highest stage of arahantship, except in rare cases on the deathbed. The tradition extended this by saying that if a lay person becomes an arahant, they must ordain or die that day, but this is not supported in the early texts. The point is not whether you receive an ordination, but whether you let go of attachments.

dn16:2.7.13.pli: Paropaññāsaṃ, ānanda, nātike upāsakā kālaṅkatā, pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā opapātikā tattha parinibbāyino anāvattidhammā tasmā lokā.
dn16:2.7.13.eng: Over fifty laymen in Ñātika have passed away having ended the five lower fetters. They’ve been reborn spontaneously, and will be extinguished there, not liable to return from that world.

dn16:2.7.14.pli: Sādhikā navuti, ānanda, nātike upāsakā kālaṅkatā tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṃ tanuttā sakadāgāmino sakideva imaṃ lokaṃ āgantvā dukkhassantaṃ karissanti.
dn16:2.7.14.eng: More than ninety laymen in Ñātika have passed away having ended three fetters, and weakened greed, hate, and delusion. They’re once-returners, who will come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering.

dn16:2.7.15.pli: Sātirekāni, ānanda, pañcasatāni nātike upāsakā kālaṅkatā, tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā sotāpannā avinipātadhammā niyatā sambodhiparāyaṇā.
dn16:2.7.15.eng: More than five hundred laymen in Ñātika have passed away having ended three fetters. They’re stream-enterers, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.
dn16:2.7.15.comm: The commentary to the Saṁyutta attributes the large number of deaths to a recent plague (ahivātaroga, “viper’s breath disease”). This deadly contagion was known to kill off entire families (Kd 1:50.1.1). According to the commentaries, the same disease once afflicted Vesālī, prompting the teaching of the Ratanasutta (Snp 2.1, Kp 6).

dn16:2.8.1.pli: Anacchariyaṃ kho panetaṃ, ānanda, yaṃ manussabhūto kālaṃ kareyya.
dn16:2.8.1.eng: It’s no wonder that a human being should pass away.

dn16:2.8.2.pli: Tasmiṃyeva kālaṅkate tathāgataṃ upasaṅkamitvā etamatthaṃ pucchissatha, vihesā hesā, ānanda, tathāgatassa.
dn16:2.8.2.eng: But if you should come and ask me about it each and every time someone passes away, that would be a bother for me.

dn16:2.8.3.pli: Tasmātihānanda, dhammādāsaṃ nāma dhammapariyāyaṃ desessāmi, yena samannāgato ariyasāvako ākaṅkhamāno attanāva attānaṃ byākareyya:
dn16:2.8.3.eng: So Ānanda, I will teach you the explanation of the Dhamma named ‘the mirror of the teaching’. A noble disciple who has this may declare of themselves:
dn16:2.8.3.comm: Mirrors are for doing makeup (DN 1:1.16.2) or admiring oneself (MN 77:33.18), which a mendicant should not do (Kd 15:2.4.1). In the Dhamma a mirror is for self-reflection (MN 61:8.2), while the mind is purified like polishing a mirror (AN 3.70:13.4).

dn16:2.8.4.pli: ‘khīṇanirayomhi khīṇatiracchānayoni khīṇapettivisayo khīṇāpāyaduggativinipāto, sotāpannohamasmi avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo’ti.
dn16:2.8.4.eng: ‘I’ve finished with rebirth in hell, the animal realm, and the ghost realm. I’ve finished with all places of loss, bad places, the underworld. I am a stream-enterer! I’m not liable to be reborn in the underworld, and am destined for awakening.’

dn16:2.9.1.pli: Katamo ca so, ānanda, dhammādāso dhammapariyāyo, yena samannāgato ariyasāvako ākaṅkhamāno attanāva attānaṃ byākareyya:
dn16:2.9.1.eng: And what is that mirror of the teaching?
dn16:2.9.1.comm: The four principles that follow are elsewhere identified as four factors of stream-entry (AN 9.27). At SN 12.41, understanding of dependent origination is included.

dn16:2.9.2.pli: ‘khīṇanirayomhi khīṇatiracchānayoni khīṇapettivisayo khīṇāpāyaduggativinipāto, sotāpannohamasmi avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo’ti?

dn16:2.9.3.pli: Idhānanda, ariyasāvako buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato hoti:
dn16:2.9.3.eng: It’s when a noble disciple has experiential confidence in the Buddha:
dn16:2.9.3.comm: “Experiential” is avecca, literally “having undergone”. “Experiential confidence” is the faith of a stream-enterer, who has seen for themselves.

dn16:2.9.4.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti.
dn16:2.9.4.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
dn16:2.9.4.comm: They have experiential confidence in the Buddha as a teacher because they have followed his path and realized the results that he speaks of.

dn16:2.9.5.eng: They have experiential confidence in the teaching:

dn16:2.9.6.pli: ‘svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo sandiṭṭhiko akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhī’ti.
dn16:2.9.6.eng: ‘The teaching is well explained by the Buddha—apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.’
dn16:2.9.6.comm: A stream-enterer has direct experience of the four noble truths, so they have confirmed that the teaching is indeed realizable in this very life.

dn16:2.9.7.eng: They have experiential confidence in the Saṅgha:

dn16:2.9.8.pli: ‘suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, ujuppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, ñāyappaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, sāmīcippaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho yadidaṃ cattāri purisayugāni aṭṭha purisapuggalā, esa bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho āhuneyyo pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassā’ti.
dn16:2.9.8.eng: ‘The Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples is practicing the way that’s good, direct, systematic, and proper. It consists of the four pairs, the eight individual persons. This is the Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples that is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.’
dn16:2.9.8.comm: The suttas distinguish between two senses of Saṅgha. The “mendicant Saṅgha” (bhikkhusaṅgha) is the conventional community of monks and nuns. The “Saṅgha of disciples” (sāvakasaṅgha) is classified as fourfold according to the stages of awakening: stream-entry, once-return, non-return, and perfection. Each of these stages is further subdivided into those of the path who are practicing for realization and those of the fruit who have realized.
