These are referred to as “noble disciples”, four of the path and four of the fruit, making eight individuals in total.

dn16:2.9.9.pli: Ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato hoti akhaṇḍehi acchiddehi asabalehi akammāsehi bhujissehi viññūpasatthehi aparāmaṭṭhehi samādhisaṃvattanikehi.
dn16:2.9.9.eng: And a noble disciple’s ethical conduct is loved by the noble ones, unbroken, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to immersion.
dn16:2.9.9.comm: This entails keeping the five precepts at a minimum.

dn16:2.9.10.pli: Ayaṃ kho so, ānanda, dhammādāso dhammapariyāyo, yena samannāgato ariyasāvako ākaṅkhamāno attanāva attānaṃ byākareyya:
dn16:2.9.10.eng: This is that mirror of the teaching.”

dn16:2.9.11.pli: ‘khīṇanirayomhi khīṇatiracchānayoni khīṇapettivisayo khīṇāpāyaduggativinipāto, sotāpannohamasmi avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo’”ti.

dn16:2.10.1.pli: Tatrapi sudaṃ bhagavā nātike viharanto giñjakāvasathe etadeva bahulaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ dhammiṃ kathaṃ karoti:
dn16:2.10.1.eng: And while staying there in Ñātika the Buddha often gave this Dhamma talk to the mendicants:

dn16:2.10.2.eng: “Such is ethics, such is immersion, such is wisdom.

dn16:2.10.3.eng: When immersion is imbued with ethics it’s very fruitful and beneficial.

dn16:2.10.4.eng: When wisdom is imbued with immersion it’s very fruitful and beneficial.

dn16:2.10.5.pli: Paññāparibhāvitaṃ cittaṃ sammadeva āsavehi vimuccati, seyyathidaṃ—
dn16:2.10.5.eng: When the mind is imbued with wisdom it is rightly freed from the defilements, namely,

dn16:2.10.6.eng: the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.”

dn16:2.11.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā nātike yathābhirantaṃ viharitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
dn16:2.11.1.eng: When the Buddha had stayed in Ñātika as long as he pleased, he addressed Venerable Ānanda,

dn16:2.11.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paccassosi.

dn16:2.11.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ yena vesālī tadavasari.
dn16:2.11.4.eng: Then the Buddha together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants arrived at Vesālī,

dn16:2.11.5.pli: Tatra sudaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati ambapālivane.
dn16:2.11.5.eng: where he stayed in Ambapālī’s mango grove.
dn16:2.11.5.comm: Ambapālī means “protector of mangoes”. Here the text just says she had a “grove”, but it is identified as a mango grove below (DN 16:2.14.1).

dn16:2.12.1.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

dn16:2.12.2.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant should live mindful and aware.
dn16:2.12.2.comm: In some versions, the Buddha is said to have taught the monks mindfulness in anticipation of the arrival of the beautiful courtesan.

dn16:2.12.3.eng: This is my instruction to you.

dn16:2.12.4.eng: And how is a mendicant mindful?
dn16:2.12.4.comm: In the Gradual Training the mendicant “establishes mindfulness” to begin meditation. Here this practice is expanded, and in DN 22 it is expanded even further.

dn16:2.12.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
dn16:2.12.5.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
dn16:2.12.5.comm: The locative idiom kāye kāyānupassī indicates that the meditator focuses on a particular aspect of body contemplation, such as observing the breath, awareness of the body parts, or reflection on the four elements. | “Rid of desire and aversion for the world” refers to clearing the mind through the previous practice of sense restraint.

dn16:2.12.6.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

dn16:2.12.8.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
dn16:2.12.8.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
dn16:2.12.8.comm: Dhammā here refers to the “principles” of cause and effect and the four noble truths which are understood by reflecting on the psychology of meditation itself. In this context dhammā does not mean “mental objects” or “phenomena” or “mental qualities”.

dn16:2.12.9.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sato hoti.
dn16:2.12.9.eng: That’s how a mendicant is mindful.

dn16:2.13.1.eng: And how is a mendicant aware?

dn16:2.13.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu abhikkante paṭikkante sampajānakārī hoti, ālokite vilokite sampajānakārī hoti, samiñjite pasārite sampajānakārī hoti, saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇe sampajānakārī hoti, asite pīte khāyite sāyite sampajānakārī hoti, uccārapassāvakamme sampajānakārī hoti, gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgarite bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī hoti.
dn16:2.13.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant acts with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.

dn16:2.13.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sampajāno hoti.
dn16:2.13.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant is aware.

dn16:2.13.4.eng: A mendicant should live mindful and aware.

dn16:2.13.5.eng: This is my instruction to you.”

dn16:2.14.1.pli: Assosi kho ambapālī gaṇikā: “bhagavā kira vesāliṃ anuppatto vesāliyaṃ viharati mayhaṃ ambavane”ti.
dn16:2.14.1.eng: Ambapālī the courtesan heard that the Buddha had arrived and was staying in her mango grove.
dn16:2.14.1.comm: A gaṇikā was a trained entertainer and escort whose company commanded a high fee (Kd 8:1.1.7). It was a respected position, as we see the city guild of Rājagaha, with King Bimbisāra’s blessing, appoint the young woman Sālavatī in a similar position (Kd 8:1.2.13).

dn16:2.14.2.pli: Atha kho ambapālī gaṇikā bhaddāni bhaddāni yānāni yojāpetvā bhaddaṃ bhaddaṃ yānaṃ abhiruhitvā bhaddehi bhaddehi yānehi vesāliyā niyyāsi. Yena sako ārāmo tena pāyāsi.
dn16:2.14.2.eng: She had the finest carriages harnessed. Then she mounted a fine carriage and, along with other fine carriages, set out from Vesālī for her own park.

dn16:2.14.3.pli: Yāvatikā yānassa bhūmi, yānena gantvā, yānā paccorohitvā pattikāva yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
dn16:2.14.3.eng: She went by carriage as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and approached the Buddha on foot. She bowed and sat down to one side.

dn16:2.14.4.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho ambapāliṃ gaṇikaṃ bhagavā dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi.
dn16:2.14.4.eng: The Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired her with a Dhamma talk.

dn16:2.14.5.pli: Atha kho ambapālī gaṇikā bhagavatā dhammiyā kathāya sandassitā samādapitā samuttejitā sampahaṃsitā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn16:2.14.5.eng: Then she said to the Buddha,

dn16:2.14.6.pli: “adhivāsetu me, bhante, bhagavā svātanāya bhattaṃ saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghenā”ti.
dn16:2.14.6.eng: “Sir, may the Buddha together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me.”

dn16:2.14.8.pli: Atha kho ambapālī gaṇikā bhagavato adhivāsanaṃ viditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
dn16:2.14.8.eng: Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, Ambapālī got up from her seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on her right, before leaving.

dn16:2.15.1.pli: Assosuṃ kho vesālikā licchavī: “bhagavā kira vesāliṃ anuppatto vesāliyaṃ viharati ambapālivane”ti.
dn16:2.15.1.eng: The Licchavis of Vesālī also heard that the Buddha had arrived and was staying in Ambapālī’s mango grove.

dn16:2.15.2.pli: Atha kho te licchavī bhaddāni bhaddāni yānāni yojāpetvā bhaddaṃ bhaddaṃ yānaṃ abhiruhitvā bhaddehi bhaddehi yānehi vesāliyā niyyiṃsu.
dn16:2.15.2.eng: They had the finest carriages harnessed. Then they mounted a fine carriage and, along with other fine carriages, set out from Vesālī.

dn16:2.15.3.pli: Tatra ekacce licchavī nīlā honti nīlavaṇṇā nīlavatthā nīlālaṅkārā, ekacce licchavī pītā honti pītavaṇṇā pītavatthā pītālaṅkārā, ekacce licchavī lohitā honti lohitavaṇṇā lohitavatthā lohitālaṅkārā, ekacce licchavī odātā honti odātavaṇṇā odātavatthā odātālaṅkārā.
dn16:2.15.3.eng: Some of the Licchavis were in blue, of blue color, clad in blue, adorned with blue. And some were similarly colored in yellow, red, or white.
dn16:2.15.3.comm: The text spends more time on the Vajjis’ appearance than on Ambapālī’s. At Thig 15.1:12.1 the nun Isidāsī recalls how she used to do the makeup for her husband every day, like his own personal beautician.

dn16:2.16.1.pli: Atha kho ambapālī gaṇikā daharānaṃ daharānaṃ licchavīnaṃ akkhena akkhaṃ cakkena cakkaṃ yugena yugaṃ paṭivaṭṭesi.
dn16:2.16.1.eng: Then Ambapālī the courtesan collided with those Licchavi youths, axle to axle, wheel to wheel, yoke to yoke.
dn16:2.16.1.comm: There are various reading for paṭivaṭṭesi. The commentary glosses with pahari (“struck, collided”).

dn16:2.16.2.pli: Atha kho te licchavī ambapāliṃ gaṇikaṃ etadavocuṃ:

dn16:2.16.3.pli: “kiṃ, je ambapāli, daharānaṃ daharānaṃ licchavīnaṃ akkhena akkhaṃ cakkena cakkaṃ yugena yugaṃ paṭivaṭṭesī”ti?
dn16:2.16.3.eng: “What, you wench Ambapālī, are you doing colliding with us axle to axle, wheel to wheel, yoke to yoke?”
dn16:2.16.3.comm: The derogatory indeclinable vocative je is otherwise used of the “naughty maid” Kāḷī at MN 21:9.13. “Wench” is a term meant to insult on the basis of servitude or promiscuity, so it seems appropriate. The Licchavis are not distinguishing themselves here; given their youth, wealth, licentiousness, and evident familiarity with Ambapālī, it seems safe to conclude that they had been her clients.

dn16:2.16.4.pli: “Tathā hi pana me, ayyaputtā, bhagavā nimantito svātanāya bhattaṃ saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghenā”ti.
dn16:2.16.4.eng: “Well, masters, it’s because I’ve invited the Buddha for tomorrow’s meal together with the mendicant Saṅgha.”

dn16:2.16.5.eng: “Wench, give us that meal for a hundred thousand!”

dn16:2.16.6.pli: “Sacepi me, ayyaputtā, vesāliṃ sāhāraṃ dassatha, evamahaṃ taṃ bhattaṃ na dassāmī”ti.
dn16:2.16.6.eng: “Masters, even if you were to give me Vesālī with her provinces, I still wouldn’t give that meal to you.”
dn16:2.16.6.comm: Dassatha is second future plural of dadāti. The Vinaya parallel at Kd 6:30.4.5 uses optative forms instead. | “With provinces” is sāhāraṁ (literally “with food”, commentary: sajanapadaṁ) refers to the holdings around the city that supplied food and other necessities.

dn16:2.16.7.pli: Atha kho te licchavī aṅguliṃ phoṭesuṃ:
dn16:2.16.7.eng: Then the Licchavis snapped their fingers, saying,

dn16:2.16.8.pli: “jitamha vata bho ambakāya, jitamha vata bho ambakāyā”ti.
dn16:2.16.8.eng: “We’ve been beaten by the aunty! We’ve been beaten by the aunty!”
dn16:2.16.8.comm: Despite the context, ambakā has no etymological relation to amba (“mango”) but is a term for “woman, mother”, used here as a play on words.

dn16:2.16.9.pli: Atha kho te licchavī yena ambapālivanaṃ tena pāyiṃsu.
dn16:2.16.9.eng: Then they continued on to Ambapālī’s mango grove.

dn16:2.17.1.pli: Addasā kho bhagavā te licchavī dūratova āgacchante.
dn16:2.17.1.eng: The Buddha saw them coming off in the distance,

dn16:2.17.3.pli: “yesaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhūnaṃ devā tāvatiṃsā adiṭṭhapubbā, oloketha, bhikkhave, licchaviparisaṃ;
dn16:2.17.3.eng: “Any of the mendicants who’ve never seen the gods of the thirty-three before, just have a look at the assembly of Licchavis.

dn16:2.18.1.pli: Atha kho te licchavī yāvatikā yānassa bhūmi, yānena gantvā, yānā paccorohitvā pattikāva yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.
dn16:2.18.1.eng: The Licchavis went by carriage as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and approached the Buddha on foot. They bowed to the Buddha, sat down to one side,

dn16:2.18.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinne kho te licchavī bhagavā dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi.
dn16:2.18.2.eng: and the Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired them with a Dhamma talk.

dn16:2.18.3.pli: Atha kho te licchavī bhagavatā dhammiyā kathāya sandassitā samādapitā samuttejitā sampahaṃsitā bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
dn16:2.18.3.eng: Then they said to the Buddha,

dn16:2.18.4.pli: “adhivāsetu no, bhante, bhagavā svātanāya bhattaṃ saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghenā”ti.
dn16:2.18.4.eng: “Sir, may the Buddha together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from us.”

dn16:2.18.5.pli: Atha kho bhagavā te licchavī etadavoca:
dn16:2.18.5.eng: Then the Buddha said to the Licchavis,

dn16:2.18.6.pli: “adhivutthaṃ kho me, licchavī, svātanāya ambapāliyā gaṇikāya bhattan”ti.
dn16:2.18.6.eng: “I have already accepted tomorrow’s meal from Ambapālī the courtesan.”

dn16:2.18.7.pli: Atha kho te licchavī aṅguliṃ phoṭesuṃ:
dn16:2.18.7.eng: Then the Licchavis snapped their fingers, saying,

dn16:2.18.8.pli: “jitamha vata bho ambakāya, jitamha vata bho ambakāyā”ti.
dn16:2.18.8.eng: “We’ve been beaten by the aunty! We’ve been beaten by the aunty!”

dn16:2.18.9.pli: Atha kho te licchavī bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkamiṃsu.
dn16:2.18.9.eng: And then those Licchavis approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. They got up from their seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right, before leaving.

dn16:2.19.1.pli: Atha kho ambapālī gaṇikā tassā rattiyā accayena sake ārāme paṇītaṃ khādanīyaṃ bhojanīyaṃ paṭiyādāpetvā bhagavato kālaṃ ārocāpesi:
dn16:2.19.1.eng: And when the night had passed Ambapālī had delicious fresh and cooked foods prepared in her own park. Then she had the Buddha informed of the time, saying,

dn16:2.19.2.eng: “Sir, it’s time. The meal is ready.”

dn16:2.19.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghena yena ambapāliyā gaṇikāya nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
dn16:2.19.3.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the home of Ambapālī together with the mendicant Saṅgha, where he sat on the seat spread out.

dn16:2.19.4.pli: Atha kho ambapālī gaṇikā buddhappamukhaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappesi sampavāresi.
dn16:2.19.4.eng: Then Ambapālī served and satisfied the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha with her own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.

dn16:2.19.5.pli: Atha kho ambapālī gaṇikā bhagavantaṃ bhuttāviṃ onītapattapāṇiṃ aññataraṃ nīcaṃ āsanaṃ gahetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
dn16:2.19.5.eng: When the Buddha had eaten and washed his hands and bowl, Ambapālī took a low seat, sat to one side,

dn16:2.19.6.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho ambapālī gaṇikā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

dn16:2.19.7.eng: “Sir, I present this park to the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha.”
dn16:2.19.7.comm: This demonstrates that a woman of Ambapālī’s profession could own land and control significant resources.

dn16:2.19.8.comm: An ārāma is a tended and pleasant ground, a “park”. Here it has previously been referred to as “grove” (vana) and “mango grove”. Usually in the suttas, however, it is a name for a place where monastics live. In English, monastics don’t live in parks, they live in monasteries. So once a place has been dedicated for the Saṅgha, I translate ārāma as “monastery”.

dn16:2.19.9.pli: Atha kho bhagavā ambapāliṃ gaṇikaṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandassetvā samādapetvā samuttejetvā sampahaṃsetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi.
dn16:2.19.9.eng: Then the Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired her with a Dhamma talk, after which he got up from his seat and left.

dn16:2.20.1.pli: Tatrapi sudaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharanto ambapālivane etadeva bahulaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ dhammiṃ kathaṃ karoti:
dn16:2.20.1.eng: And while staying at Vesālī, too, the Buddha often gave this Dhamma talk to the mendicants:

dn16:2.20.2.eng: “Such is ethics, such is immersion, such is wisdom.

dn16:2.20.3.eng: When immersion is imbued with ethics it’s very fruitful and beneficial.

dn16:2.20.4.eng: When wisdom is imbued with immersion it’s very fruitful and beneficial.

dn16:2.20.5.pli: Paññāparibhāvitaṃ cittaṃ sammadeva āsavehi vimuccati, seyyathidaṃ—
dn16:2.20.5.eng: When the mind is imbued with wisdom it is rightly freed from the defilements, namely,

dn16:2.20.6.eng: the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.”

dn16:2.21.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā ambapālivane yathābhirantaṃ viharitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
dn16:2.21.1.eng: When the Buddha had stayed in Ambapālī’s mango grove as long as he pleased, he addressed Venerable Ānanda,

dn16:2.21.2.eng: “Come, Ānanda, let’s go to the little village of Beluva.”
dn16:2.21.2.comm: Pali texts waver between beluva (“wood-apple”) and veḷuva (from veḷuvant, “full of bamboo”).

dn16:2.21.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paccassosi.

dn16:2.21.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ yena veḷuvagāmako tadavasari.
dn16:2.21.4.eng: Then the Buddha together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants arrived at the little village of Beluva,

dn16:2.22.1.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

dn16:2.22.2.pli: “etha tumhe, bhikkhave, samantā vesāliṃ yathāmittaṃ yathāsandiṭṭhaṃ yathāsambhattaṃ vassaṃ upetha.
dn16:2.22.2.eng: “Mendicants, please enter the rainy season residence with whatever friends or acquaintances you have around Vesālī.
dn16:2.22.2.comm: The Buddha was travelling with a large retinue, which could become burdensome on a small village if they were to stay the three months of the rains residence. The texts note several monasteries and places to stay around Vesālī.

dn16:2.22.3.pli: Ahaṃ pana idheva veḷuvagāmake vassaṃ upagacchāmī”ti.
dn16:2.22.3.eng: I’ll commence the rainy season residence right here in the little village of Beluva.”

dn16:2.22.4.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paṭissutvā samantā vesāliṃ yathāmittaṃ yathāsandiṭṭhaṃ yathāsambhattaṃ vassaṃ upagacchiṃsu.
dn16:2.22.4.eng: “Yes, sir,” those mendicants replied. They did as the Buddha said,

dn16:2.22.5.pli: Bhagavā pana tattheva veḷuvagāmake vassaṃ upagacchi.
dn16:2.22.5.eng: while the Buddha commenced the rainy season residence right there in the little village of Beluva.

dn16:2.23.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavato vassūpagatassa kharo ābādho uppajji, bāḷhā vedanā vattanti māraṇantikā.
dn16:2.23.1.eng: After the Buddha had commenced the rainy season residence, he fell severely ill, struck by dreadful pains, close to death.

dn16:2.23.2.pli: Tā sudaṃ bhagavā sato sampajāno adhivāsesi avihaññamāno.
dn16:2.23.2.eng: But he endured unbothered, with mindfulness and situational awareness.

dn16:2.23.3.eng: Then it occurred to the Buddha,

dn16:2.23.4.pli: “na kho metaṃ patirūpaṃ, yvāhaṃ anāmantetvā upaṭṭhāke anapaloketvā bhikkhusaṅghaṃ parinibbāyeyyaṃ.
dn16:2.23.4.eng: “It would not be appropriate for me to be fully extinguished before informing my supporters and taking leave of the mendicant Saṅgha.
dn16:2.23.4.comm: Here upaṭṭhāka refers to the lay devotees. | Apaloketi (“take leave”) also has a literal sense of “glance back”; both senses are found in the sutta (see DN 16:4.1.2).

dn16:2.23.5.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ imaṃ ābādhaṃ vīriyena paṭipaṇāmetvā jīvitasaṅkhāraṃ adhiṭṭhāya vihareyyan”ti.
dn16:2.23.5.eng: Why don’t I forcefully suppress this illness, stabilize the life force, and live on?”
dn16:2.23.5.comm: “Life force” is jīvitasaṅkhāra whereas below we find āyusaṅkhāra (DN 16:3.10.1). They are evidently synonyms; Ps 1.6:4.3 refers to the three jīvitasaṅkhāras from MN 43:24.2, but there the text has āyusaṅkhāra. The sense is not “will to live” but “life force”, i.e. the vital energy that sustains life  (SN 20.6:3.2, MN 43:23.1). This leans on the old use of Sanskrit samas kurva or saṁskāra for the “reviving” or “rejuvenation” of the god Pajāpati when he is depleted by the act of creation, like a fire run low or a man after sex (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 7.2.1.5 et passim).

dn16:2.24.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā taṃ ābādhaṃ vīriyena paṭipaṇāmetvā jīvitasaṅkhāraṃ adhiṭṭhāya vihāsi.
dn16:2.24.1.eng: So that is what he did.

dn16:2.24.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavato so ābādho paṭippassambhi.
dn16:2.24.2.eng: Then the Buddha’s illness died down.

dn16:2.24.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā gilānā vuṭṭhito aciravuṭṭhito gelaññā vihārā nikkhamma vihārapacchāyāyaṃ paññatte āsane nisīdi.
dn16:2.24.3.eng: Soon after the Buddha had recovered from that sickness, he came out from his dwelling and sat in the shade of the porch on the seat spread out.

dn16:2.24.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn16:2.24.4.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

dn16:2.24.5.pli: “diṭṭho me, bhante, bhagavato phāsu; diṭṭhaṃ me, bhante, bhagavato khamanīyaṃ, api ca me, bhante, madhurakajāto viya kāyo, disāpi me na pakkhāyanti, dhammāpi maṃ na paṭibhanti bhagavato gelaññena.
dn16:2.24.5.eng: “Sir, it’s fantastic that the Buddha is comfortable and well. Because when the Buddha was sick, my body felt like it was drugged. I was disorientated, and the teachings weren’t clear to me.
dn16:2.24.5.comm: This is the first indication of Ānanda’s fragile emotional state in the days to come. | Read diṭṭhā (= Sanskrit diṣṭyā), “fantastic, how fortunate”, per DN 26:21.9 and Ja 81:1.4.

dn16:2.24.6.pli: Api ca me, bhante, ahosi kācideva assāsamattā:
dn16:2.24.6.eng: Still, at least I was consoled by the thought that

dn16:2.24.7.pli: ‘na tāva bhagavā parinibbāyissati, na yāva bhagavā bhikkhusaṅghaṃ ārabbha kiñcideva udāharatī’”ti.
dn16:2.24.7.eng: the Buddha won’t be fully extinguished without bringing something up regarding the Saṅgha of mendicants.”
dn16:2.24.7.comm: Previously the Buddha had spoken of “taking leave” of the Saṅgha, but here something more specific is meant. Udāharati is typically used when a previously-mentioned matter (often unpleasant) is “brought up”, as at the monastic procedures for confession or invitation to admonish (Kd 1:16.2.5, Kd 1:2.1.9). Ānanda is implying that there is some unfinished disciplinary business that needs attention. Despite the Buddha’s response, he did in fact go on to make a number of statements and rulings.

dn16:2.25.1.eng: “But what could the mendicant Saṅgha expect from me, Ānanda?
dn16:2.25.1.comm: For forty-five years he had been teaching and supporting the community.

dn16:2.25.2.pli: Desito, ānanda, mayā dhammo anantaraṃ abāhiraṃ karitvā.
dn16:2.25.2.eng: I’ve taught the Dhamma without making any distinction between secret and public teachings.
dn16:2.25.2.comm: A principle not followed by some contemporary Buddhist schools that harbor “secret teachings”.

dn16:2.25.3.eng: The Realized One doesn’t have the closed fist of a tutor when it comes to the teachings.
dn16:2.25.3.comm: “Closed fist of a tutor” is ācariyamuṭṭhi. Compare Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 6.2.4: “I have taught you all that I know.”

dn16:2.25.5.pli: ‘ahaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ pariharissāmī’ti vā ‘mamuddesiko bhikkhusaṅgho’ti vā, so nūna, ānanda, bhikkhusaṅghaṃ ārabbha kiñcideva udāhareyya.
dn16:2.25.5.eng: ‘I shall lead the mendicant Saṅgha,’ or ‘the Saṅgha of mendicants is meant for me,’ let them bring something up regarding the Saṅgha.

dn16:2.25.6.pli: Tathāgatassa kho, ānanda, na evaṃ hoti:
dn16:2.25.6.eng: But the Realized One doesn’t think like this,

dn16:2.25.8.pli: Sakiṃ, ānanda, tathāgato bhikkhusaṅghaṃ ārabbha kiñcideva udāharissati.
dn16:2.25.8.eng: so why should he bring something up regarding the Saṅgha?
dn16:2.25.8.comm: Pariharissāmi needs careful parsing with regard to tenses. The general meaning is to “carry about” or “maintain, nurture”. The Buddha elsewhere said that he “leads” the Saṅgha (DN 26:25.6: pariharāmi). When the Buddha was about to go on retreat, Moggallāna said that he and Sāriputta “shall lead” (pariharissāmi), to which the Buddha said they “should lead” (MN 67:13.7: parihareyyaṁ). Devadatta, on the other hand, ensured his downfall when he determined that he “shall lead” the Saṅgha, having taken over from the Buddha (AN 5.100:2.3, Kd 1:2.1.23). Thus the future tense indicates the determination to lead. But at this point, the Buddha’s mind is already set on letting go. He is not saying that no-one should lead the Saṅgha, but that it is up to whoever leads it to address the issues.

dn16:2.25.9.pli: Ahaṃ kho panānanda, etarahi jiṇṇo vuddho mahallako addhagato vayo anuppatto.
dn16:2.25.9.eng: I’m now old, elderly and senior. I’m advanced in years and have reached the final stage of life.

dn16:2.25.11.eng: Just as a decrepit old cart is kept going by a rope,
dn16:2.25.11.comm: The reading and derivation of veṭhamissakena are unclear. As a form of violence we find veṭhamissena at Thag 2.12:1.1, notably also in instrumental. Veṭha means “twist, strap, turban”. Missa means “mixed” or “plaited” (Bu Ss 2:2.1.21). Thus it probably refers to a kind of strong twisted material used to tie or bind, i.e. rope.

dn16:2.25.12.pli: evameva kho, ānanda, veṭhamissakena maññe tathāgatassa kāyo yāpeti.
dn16:2.25.12.eng: in the same way, the Realized One’s body is kept going as if by a rope.
dn16:2.25.12.comm: Compare Rig Veda 8.48.5: “As leather binds a chariot, soma knits my joints together.” Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.3.35 compares the labored breathing of one near death with the creaking of a heavily-laden cart. Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 13.2.7.8 says a handsome cart is well-finished with ropes. Indian carts were bound with ropes down to modern times.

dn16:2.25.13.pli: Yasmiṃ, ānanda, samaye tathāgato sabbanimittānaṃ amanasikārā ekaccānaṃ vedanānaṃ nirodhā animittaṃ cetosamādhiṃ upasampajja viharati, phāsutaro, ānanda, tasmiṃ samaye tathāgatassa kāyo hoti.
dn16:2.25.13.eng: Sometimes the Realized One, not focusing on any signs, and with the cessation of certain feelings, enters and remains in the signless immersion of the heart. Only then does the Realized One’s body become more comfortable.
dn16:2.25.13.comm: The suttas say little about this signless (animitta) meditation. Its defining characteristic is that consciousness does not “follow after signs” (nimittānusāri viññāṇaṁ, eg. AN 6.13:5.3). This is explained in MN 138:10.2 as not being distracted or affected by the features of sense impressions, as the “signs” are created by greed, hate, and delusion (MN 43:37.1). It is distinguished from the four kinds of mindfulness meditation (SN 22.80:8.4). The mental unification (ekattaṁ) based on this practice is listed after the form (and formless) jhānas, so it is very advanced. It is nonetheless a conditioned state (MN 121:11.4), so it is possible that a mendicant might fall from it and disrobe (AN 6.60:8.10). However it may also be used to describe the meditation of an arahant (SN 41.7:6.12). It is clear from MN 121:10.5 that the six senses are still functioning, unlike in deep serenity meditations. It seems that in such a state, the Buddha was able to function normally while seeing through the pain in his body.

dn16:2.26.1.pli: Tasmātihānanda, attadīpā viharatha attasaraṇā anaññasaraṇā, dhammadīpā dhammasaraṇā anaññasaraṇā.
dn16:2.26.1.eng: So Ānanda, live as your own island, your own refuge, with no other refuge. Let the teaching be your island and your refuge, with no other refuge.
dn16:2.26.1.comm: This central theme of the Buddha’s teaching—that each of us is responsible for our own salvation—becomes even more important as the Buddha’s days grow short.

dn16:2.26.2.pli: Kathañcānanda, bhikkhu attadīpo viharati attasaraṇo anaññasaraṇo, dhammadīpo dhammasaraṇo anaññasaraṇo?
dn16:2.26.2.eng: And how does a mendicant do this?

dn16:2.26.3.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati atāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
dn16:2.26.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

dn16:2.26.4.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

dn16:2.26.6.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
dn16:2.26.6.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

dn16:2.26.7.pli: Evaṃ kho, ānanda, bhikkhu attadīpo viharati attasaraṇo anaññasaraṇo, dhammadīpo dhammasaraṇo anaññasaraṇo.
dn16:2.26.7.eng: That’s how a mendicant is their own island, their own refuge, with no other refuge. That’s how the teaching is their island and their refuge, with no other refuge.

dn16:2.26.8.pli: Ye hi keci, ānanda, etarahi vā mama vā accayena attadīpā viharissanti attasaraṇā anaññasaraṇā, dhammadīpā dhammasaraṇā anaññasaraṇā, tamatagge me te, ānanda, bhikkhū bhavissanti ye keci sikkhākāmā”ti.
dn16:2.26.8.eng: Whether now or after I have passed, any who shall live as their own island, their own refuge, with no other refuge; with the teaching as their island and their refuge, with no other refuge—those mendicants of mine who want to train shall be among the best of the best.”
dn16:2.26.8.comm: Read tama(t)agge with tama as superlative, literally “at the peak of the best”.

dn16:3.1.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya vesāliṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
dn16:3.1.1.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Vesālī for alms.

dn16:3.1.2.pli: Vesāliyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
dn16:3.1.2.eng: Then, after the meal, on his return from almsround, he addressed Venerable Ānanda:

dn16:3.1.3.comm: This detail is often mentioned in texts of the Sarvāstivāda school, but rarely in Pali.

dn16:3.1.4.pli: yena cāpālaṃ cetiyaṃ tenupasaṅkamissāma divā vihārāyā”ti.
dn16:3.1.4.eng: Let’s go to the Cāpāla Shrine for the day’s meditation.”

dn16:3.1.5.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paṭissutvā nisīdanaṃ ādāya bhagavantaṃ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandhi.
dn16:3.1.5.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied Ānanda. Taking his sitting cloth he followed behind the Buddha.

dn16:3.2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā yena cāpālaṃ cetiyaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
dn16:3.2.1.eng: Then the Buddha went up to the Cāpāla Shrine, where he sat on the seat spread out.

dn16:3.2.2.pli: Āyasmāpi kho ānando bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
dn16:3.2.2.eng: Ānanda bowed to the Buddha and sat down to one side.

dn16:3.2.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:

dn16:3.2.4.pli: “ramaṇīyā, ānanda, vesālī, ramaṇīyaṃ udenaṃ cetiyaṃ, ramaṇīyaṃ gotamakaṃ cetiyaṃ, ramaṇīyaṃ sattambaṃ cetiyaṃ, ramaṇīyaṃ bahuputtaṃ cetiyaṃ, ramaṇīyaṃ sārandadaṃ cetiyaṃ, ramaṇīyaṃ cāpālaṃ cetiyaṃ.
dn16:3.2.4.eng: “Ānanda, Vesālī is lovely. And the Udena, Gotamaka, Seven Maidens, Many Sons, Sārandada, and Cāpāla Shrines are all lovely.

dn16:3.3.1.pli: Yassa kassaci, ānanda, cattāro iddhipādā bhāvitā bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā, so ākaṅkhamāno kappaṃ vā tiṭṭheyya kappāvasesaṃ vā.
dn16:3.3.1.eng: Whoever has developed and cultivated the four bases of psychic power—made them a vehicle and a basis, kept them up, consolidated them, and properly implemented them—may, if they wish, live for the proper lifespan or what’s left of it.
dn16:3.3.1.comm: Normally kappa as a period of time means “eon”, but the late canonical texts Kathāvatthu (Kv 11.5) and Milindapañha (Mil 5.1.10) argue that it means the “lifespan”, an interpretation followed by the commentaries. Support for this comes from DN 26:28.3, which says that “long life” for a mendicant is the four bases of psychic power which enable you to remain for the kappa. Here it is surely talking about a full lifespan. Underlying this is the idea that in different epochs the “proper lifespan” varies; in the Buddha’s day it was one hundred years (DN 14:1.7.7). We can resolve the problem if we read kappa here, not as a period of time, but as “proper, fitting”, i.e. the “proper” lifespan of a hundred years.

dn16:3.3.2.pli: Tathāgatassa kho, ānanda, cattāro iddhipādā bhāvitā bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā, so ākaṅkhamāno, ānanda, tathāgato kappaṃ vā tiṭṭheyya kappāvasesaṃ vā”ti.
dn16:3.3.2.eng: The Realized One has developed and cultivated the four bases of psychic power, made them a vehicle and a basis, kept them up, consolidated them, and properly implemented them. If he wished, the Realized One could live for the proper lifespan or what’s left of it.”

dn16:3.4.1.pli: Evampi kho āyasmā ānando bhagavatā oḷārike nimitte kayiramāne oḷārike obhāse kayiramāne nāsakkhi paṭivijjhituṃ;
dn16:3.4.1.eng: But Ānanda didn’t get it, even though the Buddha dropped such an obvious hint, such a clear sign.

dn16:3.4.3.pli: “tiṭṭhatu, bhante, bhagavā kappaṃ, tiṭṭhatu sugato kappaṃ bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānan”ti, yathā taṃ mārena pariyuṭṭhitacitto.
dn16:3.4.3.eng: “Sir, may the Blessed One please remain for the proper lifespan! May the Holy One please remain for the proper lifespan! That would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.” For his mind was as if possessed by Māra.
dn16:3.4.3.comm: Here Ānanda’s mind is “as if” possessed (yathā), but in the Vinaya yathā is missing: he is possessed (Kd 1:1.10.17). Remember, Ānanda is telling this story about himself.

dn16:3.5.2.pli: tatiyampi kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
dn16:3.5.2.eng: And for a third time, the Buddha said to Ānanda:

dn16:3.5.3.pli: “ramaṇīyā, ānanda, vesālī, ramaṇīyaṃ udenaṃ cetiyaṃ, ramaṇīyaṃ gotamakaṃ cetiyaṃ, ramaṇīyaṃ sattambaṃ cetiyaṃ, ramaṇīyaṃ bahuputtaṃ cetiyaṃ, ramaṇīyaṃ sārandadaṃ cetiyaṃ, ramaṇīyaṃ cāpālaṃ cetiyaṃ.
dn16:3.5.3.eng: “Ānanda, Vesālī is lovely. And the Udena, Gotamaka, Seven Maidens, Many Sons, Sārandada, and Cāpāla Shrines are all lovely.

dn16:3.5.4.pli: Yassa kassaci, ānanda, cattāro iddhipādā bhāvitā bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā, so ākaṅkhamāno kappaṃ vā tiṭṭheyya kappāvasesaṃ vā.
dn16:3.5.4.eng: Whoever has developed and cultivated the four bases of psychic power—made them a vehicle and a basis, kept them up, consolidated them, and properly implemented them—may, if they wish, live for the proper lifespan or what’s left of it.

dn16:3.5.5.pli: Tathāgatassa kho, ānanda, cattāro iddhipādā bhāvitā bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā, so ākaṅkhamāno, ānanda, tathāgato kappaṃ vā tiṭṭheyya kappāvasesaṃ vā”ti.
dn16:3.5.5.eng: The Realized One has developed and cultivated the four bases of psychic power, made them a vehicle and a basis, kept them up, consolidated them, and properly implemented them. If he wished, the Realized One could live for the proper lifespan or what’s left of it.”

dn16:3.5.6.pli: Evampi kho āyasmā ānando bhagavatā oḷārike nimitte kayiramāne oḷārike obhāse kayiramāne nāsakkhi paṭivijjhituṃ;
dn16:3.5.6.eng: But Ānanda didn’t get it, even though the Buddha dropped such an obvious hint, such a clear sign.

dn16:3.5.8.pli: “tiṭṭhatu, bhante, bhagavā kappaṃ, tiṭṭhatu sugato kappaṃ bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānan”ti, yathā taṃ mārena pariyuṭṭhitacitto.
dn16:3.5.8.eng: “Sir, may the Blessed One please remain for the proper lifespan! May the Holy One please remain for the proper lifespan! That would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.” For his mind was as if possessed by Māra.

dn16:3.6.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
dn16:3.6.1.eng: Then the Buddha got up and said to Venerable Ānanda,

dn16:3.6.4.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paṭissutvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā avidūre aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle nisīdi.
dn16:3.6.4.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied Ānanda. He rose from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before sitting at the root of a tree close by.

dn16:3.7.1.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā acirapakkante āyasmante ānande yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho māro pāpimā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn16:3.7.1.eng: And then, not long after Ānanda had left, Māra the Wicked went up to the Buddha, stood to one side, and said to him:
dn16:3.7.1.comm: Māra is the Buddhist deity of death, sex, and delusion; his aim is to trap beings in transmigration. He appears in many guises, both real and metaphorical, throughout the canon, but this sequence is his only direct appearance in the Dīghanikāya. Here he feigns compassion, urging the Buddha to find his final peace; but he has an ulterior motive, for with the Buddha’s passing Māra’s job will be much easier.

dn16:3.7.2.pli: “parinibbātu dāni, bhante, bhagavā, parinibbātu sugato, parinibbānakālo dāni, bhante, bhagavato.
dn16:3.7.2.eng: “Sir, may the Blessed One now be fully extinguished! May the Holy One now be fully extinguished! Now is the time for the full extinguishment of the Buddha.
dn16:3.7.2.comm: Parinibbāna means “extinguishment”, as of a flame. Here it appears as both noun (“extinguishment”) and verb (“become extinguished”). It is not a particularly difficult term to translate. Linguistically it has nothing to do with “attachment”, so renderings such as “unbinding” are untenable. It should be translated rather than just keeping “Nibbāna”, not least because English resists verbifying adopted words, resulting in such constructions as “enter Nibbāna”, which reifies it in a way that the Pali does not.

dn16:3.7.3.pli: Bhāsitā kho panesā, bhante, bhagavatā vācā:
dn16:3.7.3.eng: Sir, you once made this statement:

dn16:3.7.4.pli: ‘na tāvāhaṃ, pāpima, parinibbāyissāmi, yāva me bhikkhū na sāvakā bhavissanti viyattā vinītā visāradā bahussutā dhammadharā dhammānudhammappaṭipannā sāmīcippaṭipannā anudhammacārino, sakaṃ ācariyakaṃ uggahetvā ācikkhissanti desessanti paññapessanti paṭṭhapessanti vivarissanti vibhajissanti uttānīkarissanti, uppannaṃ parappavādaṃ sahadhammena suniggahitaṃ niggahetvā sappāṭihāriyaṃ dhammaṃ desessantī’ti.
dn16:3.7.4.eng: ‘Wicked One, I shall not be fully extinguished until I have monk disciples who are competent, educated, assured, learned, have memorized the teachings, and practice in line with the teaching. Not until they practice properly, living in line with the teaching. Not until they’ve learned their tradition, and explain, teach, assert, establish, disclose, analyze, and make it clear. Not until they can legitimately and completely refute the doctrines of others that come up, and teach with a demonstrable basis.’
dn16:3.7.4.comm: Māra is citing the Buddha’s words for his own purpose. The Pali tradition does not say when this encounter took place, but the Sanskrit Sarvāstivāda Catuṣparisatsūtra places it shortly after the Buddha’s awakening.

dn16:3.8.1.pli: Etarahi kho pana, bhante, bhikkhū bhagavato sāvakā viyattā vinītā visāradā bahussutā dhammadharā dhammānudhammappaṭipannā sāmīcippaṭipannā anudhammacārino, sakaṃ ācariyakaṃ uggahetvā ācikkhanti desenti paññapenti paṭṭhapenti vivaranti vibhajanti uttānīkaronti, uppannaṃ parappavādaṃ sahadhammena suniggahitaṃ niggahetvā sappāṭihāriyaṃ dhammaṃ desenti.
dn16:3.8.1.eng: Today you do have such monk disciples.

dn16:3.8.2.pli: Parinibbātu dāni, bhante, bhagavā, parinibbātu sugato, parinibbānakālo dāni, bhante, bhagavato.
dn16:3.8.2.eng: May the Blessed One now be fully extinguished! May the Holy One now be fully extinguished! Now is the time for the full extinguishment of the Buddha.

dn16:3.8.3.pli: Bhāsitā kho panesā, bhante, bhagavatā vācā:
dn16:3.8.3.eng: Sir, you once made this statement:

dn16:3.8.4.pli: ‘na tāvāhaṃ, pāpima, parinibbāyissāmi, yāva me bhikkhuniyo na sāvikā bhavissanti viyattā vinītā visāradā bahussutā dhammadharā dhammānudhammappaṭipannā sāmīcippaṭipannā anudhammacāriniyo, sakaṃ ācariyakaṃ uggahetvā ācikkhissanti desessanti paññapessanti paṭṭhapessanti vivarissanti vibhajissanti uttānīkarissanti, uppannaṃ parappavādaṃ sahadhammena suniggahitaṃ niggahetvā sappāṭihāriyaṃ dhammaṃ desessantī’ti.
dn16:3.8.4.eng: ‘Wicked One, I shall not be fully extinguished until I have nun disciples who are competent, educated, assured, learned …’
dn16:3.8.4.comm: This passage makes it clear that it was the Buddha’s intention from the beginning to establish an order of nuns (bhikkhunī).

dn16:3.8.5.pli: Etarahi kho pana, bhante, bhikkhuniyo bhagavato sāvikā viyattā vinītā visāradā bahussutā dhammadharā dhammānudhammappaṭipannā sāmīcippaṭipannā anudhammacāriniyo, sakaṃ ācariyakaṃ uggahetvā ācikkhanti desenti paññapenti paṭṭhapenti vivaranti vibhajanti uttānīkaronti, uppannaṃ parappavādaṃ sahadhammena suniggahitaṃ niggahetvā sappāṭihāriyaṃ dhammaṃ desenti.
dn16:3.8.5.eng: Today you do have such nun disciples.

dn16:3.8.6.pli: Parinibbātu dāni, bhante, bhagavā, parinibbātu sugato, parinibbānakālo dāni, bhante, bhagavato.
dn16:3.8.6.eng: May the Blessed One now be fully extinguished! May the Holy One now be fully extinguished! Now is the time for the full extinguishment of the Buddha.

dn16:3.8.7.pli: Bhāsitā kho panesā, bhante, bhagavatā vācā:
dn16:3.8.7.eng: Sir, you once made this statement:

dn16:3.8.8.pli: ‘na tāvāhaṃ, pāpima, parinibbāyissāmi, yāva me upāsakā na sāvakā bhavissanti viyattā vinītā visāradā bahussutā dhammadharā dhammānudhammappaṭipannā sāmīcippaṭipannā anudhammacārino, sakaṃ ācariyakaṃ uggahetvā ācikkhissanti desessanti paññapessanti paṭṭhapessanti vivarissanti vibhajissanti uttānīkarissanti, uppannaṃ parappavādaṃ sahadhammena suniggahitaṃ niggahetvā sappāṭihāriyaṃ dhammaṃ desessantī’ti.
dn16:3.8.8.eng: ‘Wicked One, I shall not be fully extinguished until I have layman disciples who are competent, educated, assured, learned …’

dn16:3.8.9.pli: Etarahi kho pana, bhante, upāsakā bhagavato sāvakā viyattā vinītā visāradā bahussutā dhammadharā dhammānudhammappaṭipannā sāmīcippaṭipannā anudhammacārino, sakaṃ ācariyakaṃ uggahetvā ācikkhanti desenti paññapenti paṭṭhapenti vivaranti vibhajanti uttānīkaronti, uppannaṃ parappavādaṃ sahadhammena suniggahitaṃ niggahetvā sappāṭihāriyaṃ dhammaṃ desenti.
dn16:3.8.9.eng: Today you do have such layman disciples.

dn16:3.8.10.pli: Parinibbātu dāni, bhante, bhagavā, parinibbātu sugato, parinibbānakālo dāni, bhante, bhagavato.
dn16:3.8.10.eng: May the Blessed One now be fully extinguished! May the Holy One now be fully extinguished! Now is the time for the full extinguishment of the Buddha.

dn16:3.8.11.pli: Bhāsitā kho panesā, bhante, bhagavatā vācā:
dn16:3.8.11.eng: Sir, you once made this statement:

dn16:3.8.12.pli: ‘na tāvāhaṃ, pāpima, parinibbāyissāmi, yāva me upāsikā na sāvikā bhavissanti viyattā vinītā visāradā bahussutā dhammadharā dhammānudhammappaṭipannā sāmīcippaṭipannā anudhammacāriniyo, sakaṃ ācariyakaṃ uggahetvā ācikkhissanti desessanti paññapessanti paṭṭhapessanti vivarissanti vibhajissanti uttānīkarissanti, uppannaṃ parappavādaṃ sahadhammena suniggahitaṃ niggahetvā sappāṭihāriyaṃ dhammaṃ desessantī’ti.
dn16:3.8.12.eng: ‘Wicked One, I shall not be fully extinguished until I have laywoman disciples who are competent, educated, assured, learned …’

dn16:3.8.13.pli: Etarahi kho pana, bhante, upāsikā bhagavato sāvikā viyattā vinītā visāradā bahussutā dhammadharā dhammānudhammappaṭipannā sāmīcippaṭipannā anudhammacāriniyo, sakaṃ ācariyakaṃ uggahetvā ācikkhanti desenti paññapenti paṭṭhapenti vivaranti vibhajanti uttānīkaronti, uppannaṃ parappavādaṃ sahadhammena suniggahitaṃ niggahetvā sappāṭihāriyaṃ dhammaṃ desenti.
dn16:3.8.13.eng: Today you do have such laywoman disciples.

dn16:3.8.14.pli: Parinibbātu dāni, bhante, bhagavā, parinibbātu sugato, parinibbānakālo dāni, bhante, bhagavato.
dn16:3.8.14.eng: May the Blessed One now be fully extinguished! May the Holy One now be fully extinguished! Now is the time for the full extinguishment of the Buddha.

dn16:3.8.15.pli: Bhāsitā kho panesā, bhante, bhagavatā vācā:
dn16:3.8.15.eng: Sir, you once made this statement:

dn16:3.8.16.pli: ‘na tāvāhaṃ, pāpima, parinibbāyissāmi, yāva me idaṃ brahmacariyaṃ na iddhañceva bhavissati phītañca vitthārikaṃ bāhujaññaṃ puthubhūtaṃ yāva devamanussehi suppakāsitan’ti.
dn16:3.8.16.eng: ‘Wicked One, I will not be fully extinguished until my spiritual path is successful and prosperous, extensive, popular, widespread, and well proclaimed wherever there are gods and humans.’

dn16:3.8.17.pli: Etarahi kho pana, bhante, bhagavato brahmacariyaṃ iddhañceva phītañca vitthārikaṃ bāhujaññaṃ puthubhūtaṃ, yāva devamanussehi suppakāsitaṃ.
dn16:3.8.17.eng: Today your spiritual path is successful and prosperous, extensive, popular, widespread, and well proclaimed wherever there are gods and humans.

dn16:3.8.18.pli: Parinibbātu dāni, bhante, bhagavā, parinibbātu sugato, parinibbānakālo dāni, bhante, bhagavato”ti.
dn16:3.8.18.eng: May the Blessed One now be fully extinguished! May the Holy One now be fully extinguished! Now is the time for the full extinguishment of the Buddha.”

dn16:3.9.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhagavā māraṃ pāpimantaṃ etadavoca:
dn16:3.9.1.eng: When this was said, the Buddha said to Māra,

dn16:3.9.2.pli: “appossukko tvaṃ, pāpima, hohi, na ciraṃ tathāgatassa parinibbānaṃ bhavissati.
dn16:3.9.2.eng: “Relax, Wicked One. The full extinguishment of the Realized One will be soon.
dn16:3.9.2.comm: This passage is the narrative inverse of the occasion when Brahmā begged the Buddha to teach (SN 6.1:5.5, etc.). Throughout, the sutta artfully preserves a degree of narrative ambiguity. Here it almost appears as if the Buddha assents to passing away because of Māra’s request, although his intent was clear earlier. Māra’s reasoning, moreover, is based on the Buddha’s own words.

dn16:3.9.3.pli: Ito tiṇṇaṃ māsānaṃ accayena tathāgato parinibbāyissatī”ti.
dn16:3.9.3.eng: Three months from now the Realized One will be fully extinguished.”
dn16:3.9.3.comm: It seems that at this point, the Buddha is still spending the rains in Beluva village, from where he would sometimes go to nearby Vesālī for alms, or to a local shrine for meditation. He left Vesālī only after holding a meeting for all the Saṅgha, which probably signified the completion of the rains (DN 16:4.1.2). If this reasoning is correct—and the text is not explicit—then he made this statement during the rains retreat. If, however, this reasoning is incorrect and we are already after the rains, it could not have been long after. Thus it is probably September/October, meaning that the final extinguishment was to take place in December/January. This conflicts with the tradition of ascribing his final extinguishment to the full moon of Vesak, in May.

dn16:3.10.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā cāpāle cetiye sato sampajāno āyusaṅkhāraṃ ossaji.
dn16:3.10.1.eng: So at the Cāpāla Shrine the Buddha, mindful and aware, surrendered the life force.
dn16:3.10.1.comm: The Cāpāla shrine is unknown outside of this context. The Udāna commentary says that it was named after the yakkha who formerly lived there. Now, cāpalla means “fickleness, propensity to tremble” and is from the same root as earth-“quake” (bhumicāla; capala = pacala via metathesis). It is no great leap to cāpāla. If this is correct, it suggests that the shrine was dedicated to an earth spirit who commanded earthquakes; a fitting setting for the events to follow.

dn16:3.10.2.pli: Ossaṭṭhe ca bhagavatā āyusaṅkhāre mahābhūmicālo ahosi bhiṃsanako salomahaṃso, devadundubhiyo ca phaliṃsu.
dn16:3.10.2.eng: When he did so there was a great earthquake, awe-inspiring and hair-raising, and thunder cracked the sky.
dn16:3.10.2.comm: Northern India lies in the shadow of the seismically active Alpide Belt, so the occurrence of earthquakes is realistic even if the causes are not scientific.

dn16:3.10.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
dn16:3.10.3.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

dn16:3.10.4.eng: “Comparing the incomparable <j>with the creation of prolonged life,
dn16:3.10.4.comm: For this difficult verse, I generally follow Bhikkhu Bodhi’s long discussion in Connected Discourses of the Buddha, note 255 on the Mahāvagga. | Sambhava means “production, creation”, and here I think it refers to the prolonging of life which the Buddha had just rejected.

dn16:3.10.5.eng: the sage surrendered the life force.
dn16:3.10.5.comm: Bhavasaṅkhāra (“life force”) here is equivalent to āyusaṅkhāra and jīvitasaṅkhāra.

dn16:3.10.7.eng: he shattered self-creation like a suit of armor.”
dn16:3.10.7.comm: Attasambhava (“self-creation”) refers back to sambhava in the first line.

dn16:3.11.2.pli: “acchariyaṃ vata bho, abbhutaṃ vata bho, mahā vatāyaṃ bhūmicālo;
dn16:3.11.2.eng: “How incredible, how amazing! That was a really big earthquake!

dn16:3.11.3.pli: sumahā vatāyaṃ bhūmicālo bhiṃsanako salomahaṃso; devadundubhiyo ca phaliṃsu.
dn16:3.11.3.eng: That was really a very big earthquake; awe-inspiring and hair-raising, and thunder cracked the sky!

dn16:3.11.4.pli: Ko nu kho hetu ko paccayo mahato bhūmicālassa pātubhāvāyā”ti?
dn16:3.11.4.eng: What’s the cause, what’s the reason for a great earthquake?”

dn16:3.12.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami,
dn16:3.12.1.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha,

dn16:3.12.2.eng: bowed, sat down to one side,

dn16:3.12.3.pli: ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

dn16:3.12.5.eng: That was a really big earthquake!

dn16:3.12.6.pli: sumahā vatāyaṃ, bhante, bhūmicālo bhiṃsanako salomahaṃso; devadundubhiyo ca phaliṃsu.
dn16:3.12.6.eng: That was really a very big earthquake; awe-inspiring and hair-raising, and thunder cracked the sky!

dn16:3.12.7.pli: Ko nu kho, bhante, hetu ko paccayo mahato bhūmicālassa pātubhāvāyā”ti?
dn16:3.12.7.eng: What’s the cause, what’s the reason for a great earthquake?”

dn16:3.13.1.pli: “Aṭṭha kho ime, ānanda, hetū, aṭṭha paccayā mahato bhūmicālassa pātubhāvāya.
dn16:3.13.1.eng: “Ānanda, there are these eight causes and reasons for a great earthquake.

dn16:3.13.3.pli: Ayaṃ, ānanda, mahāpathavī udake patiṭṭhitā, udakaṃ vāte patiṭṭhitaṃ, vāto ākāsaṭṭho. Hoti kho so, ānanda, samayo, yaṃ mahāvātā vāyanti. Mahāvātā vāyantā udakaṃ kampenti. Udakaṃ kampitaṃ pathaviṃ kampeti.
dn16:3.13.3.eng: This great earth is established on water, the water is established on air, and the air stands in space. At a time when a great wind blows, it stirs the water, and the water stirs the earth.
dn16:3.13.3.comm: So far as it goes, this is a naturalistic explanation. The “water element” has the quality of softening, while the “air element” is traditionally understood as “movement”. Thus in modern terms this means, “When underground forces disturb a region of instability.”

dn16:3.13.4.pli: Ayaṃ paṭhamo hetu paṭhamo paccayo mahato bhūmicālassa pātubhāvāya.
dn16:3.13.4.eng: This is the first cause and reason for a great earthquake.

dn16:3.14.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, samaṇo vā hoti brāhmaṇo vā iddhimā cetovasippatto, devo vā mahiddhiko mahānubhāvo, tassa parittā pathavīsaññā bhāvitā hoti, appamāṇā āposaññā. So imaṃ pathaviṃ kampeti saṅkampeti sampakampeti sampavedheti.
dn16:3.14.1.eng: Furthermore, there is an ascetic or brahmin with psychic power who has achieved mastery of the mind, or a god who is mighty and powerful. They’ve developed a limited perception of earth and a limitless perception of water. They make the earth shake and rock and tremble.
dn16:3.14.1.comm: The might of ascetics was legendary in ancient India (eg. MN 56:14.2). The meditation described here might be compared with the “dimensions of mastery” below (DN 16:3.25.1).

dn16:3.14.2.pli: Ayaṃ dutiyo hetu dutiyo paccayo mahato bhūmicālassa pātubhāvāya.
dn16:3.14.2.eng: This is the second cause and reason for a great earthquake.

dn16:3.15.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, yadā bodhisatto tusitakāyā cavitvā sato sampajāno mātukucchiṃ okkamati, tadāyaṃ pathavī kampati saṅkampati sampakampati sampavedhati.
dn16:3.15.1.eng: Furthermore, when the being intent on awakening passes away from the host of joyful gods, he’s conceived in his mother’s belly, mindful and aware. Then the earth shakes and rocks and trembles.
dn16:3.15.1.comm: At DN 14:1.17.7 and MN 123:7.6 it is, rather, the entire galaxy that trembles, perhaps indicating that the enhanced miracle is a later development.

dn16:3.15.2.pli: Ayaṃ tatiyo hetu tatiyo paccayo mahato bhūmicālassa pātubhāvāya.
dn16:3.15.2.eng: This is the third cause and reason for a great earthquake.

dn16:3.16.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, yadā bodhisatto sato sampajāno mātukucchismā nikkhamati, tadāyaṃ pathavī kampati saṅkampati sampakampati sampavedhati.
dn16:3.16.1.eng: Furthermore, when the being intent on awakening comes out of his mother’s belly mindful and aware, the earth shakes and rocks and trembles.

dn16:3.16.2.pli: Ayaṃ catuttho hetu catuttho paccayo mahato bhūmicālassa pātubhāvāya.
dn16:3.16.2.eng: This is the fourth cause and reason for a great earthquake.

dn16:3.17.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, yadā tathāgato anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambujjhati, tadāyaṃ pathavī kampati saṅkampati sampakampati sampavedhati.
dn16:3.17.1.eng: Furthermore, when the Realized One awakens to the supreme perfect awakening, the earth shakes and rocks and trembles.
dn16:3.17.1.comm: There are many accounts of the Buddha’s awakening in the suttas, but none, so far as I know, that mention an earthquake.

dn16:3.17.2.pli: Ayaṃ pañcamo hetu pañcamo paccayo mahato bhūmicālassa pātubhāvāya.
dn16:3.17.2.eng: This is the fifth cause and reason for a great earthquake.

dn16:3.18.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, yadā tathāgato anuttaraṃ dhammacakkaṃ pavatteti, tadāyaṃ pathavī kampati saṅkampati sampakampati sampavedhati.
dn16:3.18.1.eng: Furthermore, when the Realized One rolls forth the supreme Wheel of Dhamma, the earth shakes and rocks and trembles.

dn16:3.18.2.pli: Ayaṃ chaṭṭho hetu chaṭṭho paccayo mahato bhūmicālassa pātubhāvāya.
dn16:3.18.2.eng: This is the sixth cause and reason for a great earthquake.

dn16:3.19.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, yadā tathāgato sato sampajāno āyusaṅkhāraṃ ossajjati, tadāyaṃ pathavī kampati saṅkampati sampakampati sampavedhati.
dn16:3.19.1.eng: Furthermore, when the Realized One, mindful and aware, surrenders the life force, the earth shakes and rocks and trembles.

dn16:3.19.2.pli: Ayaṃ sattamo hetu sattamo paccayo mahato bhūmicālassa pātubhāvāya.
dn16:3.19.2.eng: This is the seventh cause and reason for a great earthquake.

dn16:3.20.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, yadā tathāgato anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāyati, tadāyaṃ pathavī kampati saṅkampati sampakampati sampavedhati.
dn16:3.20.1.eng: Furthermore, when the Realized One becomes fully extinguished in the element of extinguishment with no residue, the earth shakes and rocks and trembles.
dn16:3.20.1.comm: This refers to the Buddha’s death. The Pali here uses both nibbāna and parinibbāna. Sometimes it is said that nibbāna is the attainment of arahantship, while parinibbāna is the death of an arahant, but this distinction is not consistently applied in the suttas. | Regarding nibbānadhātuyā (“the element of extinguishment”), in Pali the case is ambiguous. It is sometimes translated “by means of” or “through”, which assumes the instrumental; but the Sanskrit is nirvāṇadhātau, which must be locative.

dn16:3.20.2.pli: Ayaṃ aṭṭhamo hetu aṭṭhamo paccayo mahato bhūmicālassa pātubhāvāya.
dn16:3.20.2.eng: This is the eighth cause and reason for a great earthquake.

dn16:3.20.3.pli: Ime kho, ānanda, aṭṭha hetū, aṭṭha paccayā mahato bhūmicālassa pātubhāvāya.
dn16:3.20.3.eng: These are the eight causes and reasons for a great earthquake.

dn16:3.21.1.eng: There are, Ānanda, these eight assemblies.
dn16:3.21.1.comm: As at AN 8.69. The following series of “eight things” seems arbitrarily inserted here and breaks the flow of the narrative. They are absent from the Sanskrit Sarvāstivāda text edited by Waldschmidt, which goes directly to the conversation where Ānanda realizes that the Buddha is going to die.

dn16:3.21.3.pli: Khattiyaparisā, brāhmaṇaparisā, gahapatiparisā, samaṇaparisā, cātumahārājikaparisā, tāvatiṃsaparisā, māraparisā, brahmaparisā.
dn16:3.21.3.eng: The assemblies of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, and ascetics. An assembly of the gods of the four great kings. An assembly of the gods of the thirty-three. An assembly of Māras. An assembly of divinities.
dn16:3.21.3.comm: These “assemblies” were formal deliberative meetings, not just gatherings. Thus “householders” here does not mean “lay folk” in apposition to “ascetics”; rather it means “home owners”. Some of these assemblies are depicted or alluded to in the Dīghanikāya. At DN 6:1.3, brahmins assemble in Vesālī; while at DN 3:1.13.3, Ambaṭṭha speaks of an assembly of Sakyans, who were aristocrats. At DN 18:12.1, we get a glimpse of the proceedings at a meeting of the gods of the thirty-three.

dn16:3.22.1.pli: Abhijānāmi kho panāhaṃ, ānanda, anekasataṃ khattiyaparisaṃ upasaṅkamitā.
dn16:3.22.1.eng: I recall having approached an assembly of hundreds of aristocrats.

dn16:3.22.2.pli: Tatrapi mayā sannisinnapubbañceva sallapitapubbañca sākacchā ca samāpajjitapubbā.
dn16:3.22.2.eng: There I used to sit with them, converse, and engage in discussion.

dn16:3.22.3.pli: Tattha yādisako tesaṃ vaṇṇo hoti, tādisako mayhaṃ vaṇṇo hoti. Yādisako tesaṃ saro hoti, tādisako mayhaṃ saro hoti.
dn16:3.22.3.eng: And my appearance and voice became just like theirs.

dn16:3.22.4.pli: Dhammiyā kathāya sandassemi samādapemi samuttejemi sampahaṃsemi.
dn16:3.22.4.eng: I educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired them with a Dhamma talk.

dn16:3.22.5.eng: But when I spoke they didn’t know:

dn16:3.22.6.pli: ‘ko nu kho ayaṃ bhāsati devo vā manusso vā’ti?
dn16:3.22.6.eng: ‘Who is this that speaks? Is it a god or a human?’

dn16:3.22.7.pli: Dhammiyā kathāya sandassetvā samādapetvā samuttejetvā sampahaṃsetvā antaradhāyāmi.
dn16:3.22.7.eng: And when my Dhamma talk was finished I vanished.

dn16:3.22.8.eng: But when I vanished they didn’t know:

dn16:3.22.9.pli: ‘ko nu kho ayaṃ antarahito devo vā manusso vā’ti?
dn16:3.22.9.eng: ‘Who was that who vanished? Was it a god or a human?’
dn16:3.22.9.comm: There do not appear to be any records of this happening in the early texts, although that is perhaps to be expected. It does feel out of character for the Buddha, as normally he is very up front. The commentary says that this ruse was adopted so the Buddha could plant subtle seeds (vāsanā) for the future. At Kena Upaniṣad 3, Brahma appears to the gods and tests them, but they do not know him.

dn16:3.23.1.pli: Abhijānāmi kho panāhaṃ, ānanda, anekasataṃ brāhmaṇaparisaṃ …pe…
dn16:3.23.1.eng: I recall having approached an assembly of hundreds of brahmins …

dn16:3.23.4.eng: the gods of the four great kings …

dn16:3.23.8.pli: Tatrapi mayā sannisinnapubbañceva sallapitapubbañca sākacchā ca samāpajjitapubbā.
dn16:3.23.8.eng: There too I used to sit with them, converse, and engage in discussion.

dn16:3.23.9.pli: Tattha yādisako tesaṃ vaṇṇo hoti, tādisako mayhaṃ vaṇṇo hoti.
dn16:3.23.9.eng: And my appearance and voice became just like theirs.

dn16:3.23.10.pli: Yādisako tesaṃ saro hoti, tādisako mayhaṃ saro hoti.

dn16:3.23.11.pli: Dhammiyā kathāya sandassemi samādapemi samuttejemi sampahaṃsemi.
dn16:3.23.11.eng: I educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired them with a Dhamma talk.

dn16:3.23.12.eng: But when I spoke they didn’t know:

dn16:3.23.13.pli: ‘ko nu kho ayaṃ bhāsati devo vā manusso vā’ti?
dn16:3.23.13.eng: ‘Who is this that speaks? Is it a god or a human?’

dn16:3.23.14.pli: Dhammiyā kathāya sandassetvā samādapetvā samuttejetvā sampahaṃsetvā antaradhāyāmi.
dn16:3.23.14.eng: And when my Dhamma talk was finished I vanished.

dn16:3.23.15.eng: But when I vanished they didn’t know:

dn16:3.23.16.pli: ‘ko nu kho ayaṃ antarahito devo vā manusso vā’ti?
dn16:3.23.16.eng: ‘Who was that who vanished? Was it a god or a human?’

dn16:3.24.1.eng: Ānanda, there are these eight dimensions of mastery.
dn16:3.24.1.comm: These are another way of describing the different experiences of jhāna. Also at AN 8.65, AN 10.29:6.1, DN 33:3.1.142, DN 34:2.1.160, and MN 77:23.1.

dn16:3.25.1.pli: Ajjhattaṃ rūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati parittāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni.
dn16:3.25.1.eng: Perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limited, both pretty and ugly.
dn16:3.25.1.comm: “Perceiving form (rūpa) internally” refers to someone developing meditation based on an aspect of their own body, such as the breath or the parts of the body. The “forms” (rūpā) seen externally are the lights or other meditation phenomena that today are usually called nimitta. An “ugly” form is the mental image that arises in such contemplations as the parts of the body. A “beautiful” image arises from practices such as mindfulness of breathing.

dn16:3.25.2.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

dn16:3.25.3.eng: This is the first dimension of mastery.

dn16:3.26.1.pli: Ajjhattaṃ rūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati appamāṇāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni.
dn16:3.26.1.eng: Perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limitless, both pretty and ugly.

dn16:3.26.2.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

dn16:3.26.3.eng: This is the second dimension of mastery.

dn16:3.27.1.pli: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati parittāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni.
dn16:3.27.1.eng: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limited, both pretty and ugly.
dn16:3.27.1.comm: “Not perceiving form internally” refers to meditations such as the external elements, or the decaying of another’s body.

dn16:3.27.2.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

dn16:3.27.3.eng: This is the third dimension of mastery.

dn16:3.28.1.pli: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati appamāṇāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni.
dn16:3.28.1.eng: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limitless, both pretty and ugly.

dn16:3.28.2.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

dn16:3.28.3.eng: This is the fourth dimension of mastery.

dn16:3.29.1.pli: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati nīlāni nīlavaṇṇāni nīlanidassanāni nīlanibhāsāni.
dn16:3.29.1.eng: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are blue, with blue color and blue appearance.
dn16:3.29.1.comm: This is the meditation where one contemplates an external color, either a prepared disk or a natural phenomena such as the sky or a flower, which eventually gives rise to a “counterpart” image. Today such meditations are called kasiṇa following the Visuddhimagga, but in the early texts kasiṇa means “totality” and refers rather to the state of samādhi that results.

dn16:3.29.2.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma umāpupphaṃ nīlaṃ nīlavaṇṇaṃ nīlanidassanaṃ nīlanibhāsaṃ. Seyyathā vā pana taṃ vatthaṃ bārāṇaseyyakaṃ ubhatobhāgavimaṭṭhaṃ nīlaṃ nīlavaṇṇaṃ nīlanidassanaṃ nīlanibhāsaṃ.
dn16:3.29.2.eng: They’re like a flax flower that’s blue, with blue color and blue appearance. Or a cloth from Varanasi that’s smoothed on both sides, blue, with blue color and blue appearance.

dn16:3.29.3.pli: Evameva ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati nīlāni nīlavaṇṇāni nīlanidassanāni nīlanibhāsāni.
dn16:3.29.3.eng: In the same way, not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, blue, with blue color and blue appearance.

dn16:3.29.4.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

dn16:3.29.5.eng: This is the fifth dimension of mastery.

dn16:3.30.1.pli: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati pītāni pītavaṇṇāni pītanidassanāni pītanibhāsāni.
dn16:3.30.1.eng: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are yellow, with yellow color and yellow appearance.

dn16:3.30.2.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma kaṇikārapupphaṃ pītaṃ pītavaṇṇaṃ pītanidassanaṃ pītanibhāsaṃ. Seyyathā vā pana taṃ vatthaṃ bārāṇaseyyakaṃ ubhatobhāgavimaṭṭhaṃ pītaṃ pītavaṇṇaṃ pītanidassanaṃ pītanibhāsaṃ.
dn16:3.30.2.eng: They’re like a champak flower that’s yellow, with yellow color and yellow appearance. Or a cloth from Varanasi that’s smoothed on both sides, yellow, with yellow color and yellow appearance.

dn16:3.30.3.pli: Evameva ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati pītāni pītavaṇṇāni pītanidassanāni pītanibhāsāni.
dn16:3.30.3.eng: In the same way, not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are yellow, with yellow color and yellow appearance.

dn16:3.30.4.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

dn16:3.30.5.eng: This is the sixth dimension of mastery.

dn16:3.31.1.pli: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati lohitakāni lohitakavaṇṇāni lohitakanidassanāni lohitakanibhāsāni.
dn16:3.31.1.eng: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are red, with red color and red appearance.

dn16:3.31.2.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma bandhujīvakapupphaṃ lohitakaṃ lohitakavaṇṇaṃ lohitakanidassanaṃ lohitakanibhāsaṃ. Seyyathā vā pana taṃ vatthaṃ bārāṇaseyyakaṃ ubhatobhāgavimaṭṭhaṃ lohitakaṃ lohitakavaṇṇaṃ lohitakanidassanaṃ lohitakanibhāsaṃ.
dn16:3.31.2.eng: They’re like a scarlet mallow flower that’s red, with red color and red appearance. Or a cloth from Varanasi that’s smoothed on both sides, red, with red color and red appearance.

dn16:3.31.3.pli: Evameva ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati lohitakāni lohitakavaṇṇāni lohitakanidassanāni lohitakanibhāsāni.
dn16:3.31.3.eng: In the same way, not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are red, with red color and red appearance.

dn16:3.31.4.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

dn16:3.31.5.eng: This is the seventh dimension of mastery.

dn16:3.32.1.pli: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati odātāni odātavaṇṇāni odātanidassanāni odātanibhāsāni.
dn16:3.32.1.eng: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are white, with white color and white appearance.

dn16:3.32.2.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma osadhitārakā odātā odātavaṇṇā odātanidassanā odātanibhāsā. Seyyathā vā pana taṃ vatthaṃ bārāṇaseyyakaṃ ubhatobhāgavimaṭṭhaṃ odātaṃ odātavaṇṇaṃ odātanidassanaṃ odātanibhāsaṃ.
dn16:3.32.2.eng: They’re like the morning star that’s white, with white color and white appearance. Or a cloth from Varanasi that’s smoothed on both sides, white, with white color and white appearance.

dn16:3.32.3.pli: Evameva ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati odātāni odātavaṇṇāni odātanidassanāni odātanibhāsāni.
dn16:3.32.3.eng: In the same way, not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally that are white, with white color and white appearance.

dn16:3.32.4.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

dn16:3.32.5.eng: This is the eighth dimension of mastery.

dn16:3.32.6.eng: These are the eight dimensions of mastery.

dn16:3.33.1.eng: Ānanda, there are these eight liberations.

dn16:3.33.3.eng: Having physical form, they see forms.

dn16:3.33.5.eng: Not perceiving form internally, they see forms externally.

dn16:3.33.9.pli: Sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati,
dn16:3.33.9.eng: Going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite space.

dn16:3.33.11.pli: Sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘anantaṃ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati,
dn16:3.33.11.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

dn16:3.33.13.pli: Sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati,
dn16:3.33.13.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness.

dn16:3.33.15.pli: Sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati,
dn16:3.33.15.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, they enter and remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

dn16:3.33.17.pli: Sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ upasampajja viharati,
dn16:3.33.17.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, they enter and remain in the cessation of perception and feeling.

dn16:3.34.1.pli: Ekamidāhaṃ, ānanda, samayaṃ uruvelāyaṃ viharāmi najjā nerañjarāya tīre ajapālanigrodhe paṭhamābhisambuddho.
dn16:3.34.1.eng: Ānanda, this one time, when I was first awakened, I was staying in Uruvelā at the goatherd’s banyan tree on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.

dn16:3.34.2.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, māro pāpimā yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho, ānanda, māro pāpimā maṃ etadavoca:
dn16:3.34.2.eng: Then Māra the wicked approached me, stood to one side, and said:

dn16:3.34.3.pli: ‘parinibbātu dāni, bhante, bhagavā; parinibbātu sugato, parinibbānakālo dāni, bhante, bhagavato’ti.
dn16:3.34.3.eng: ‘Sir, may the Blessed One now be fully extinguished! May the Holy One now be fully extinguished! Now is the time for the full extinguishment of the Buddha.’

dn16:3.34.4.pli: Evaṃ vutte, ahaṃ, ānanda, māraṃ pāpimantaṃ etadavocaṃ:
dn16:3.34.4.eng: When he had spoken, I said to Māra:

dn16:3.35.1.pli: ‘Na tāvāhaṃ, pāpima, parinibbāyissāmi, yāva me bhikkhū na sāvakā bhavissanti viyattā vinītā visāradā bahussutā dhammadharā dhammānudhammappaṭipannā sāmīcippaṭipannā anudhammacārino, sakaṃ ācariyakaṃ uggahetvā ācikkhissanti desessanti paññapessanti paṭṭhapessanti vivarissanti vibhajissanti uttānīkarissanti, uppannaṃ parappavādaṃ sahadhammena suniggahitaṃ niggahetvā sappāṭihāriyaṃ dhammaṃ desessanti.
dn16:3.35.1.eng: ‘Wicked One, I shall not be fully extinguished until I have monk disciples …

dn16:3.35.2.pli: Na tāvāhaṃ, pāpima, parinibbāyissāmi, yāva me bhikkhuniyo na sāvikā bhavissanti viyattā vinītā visāradā bahussutā dhammadharā dhammānudhammappaṭipannā sāmīcippaṭipannā anudhammacāriniyo, sakaṃ ācariyakaṃ uggahetvā ācikkhissanti desessanti paññapessanti paṭṭhapessanti vivarissanti vibhajissanti uttānīkarissanti, uppannaṃ parappavādaṃ sahadhammena suniggahitaṃ niggahetvā sappāṭihāriyaṃ dhammaṃ desessanti.

dn16:3.35.3.pli: Na tāvāhaṃ, pāpima, parinibbāyissāmi, yāva me upāsakā na sāvakā bhavissanti viyattā vinītā visāradā bahussutā dhammadharā dhammānudhammappaṭipannā sāmīcippaṭipannā anudhammacārino, sakaṃ ācariyakaṃ uggahetvā ācikkhissanti desessanti paññapessanti paṭṭhapessanti vivarissanti vibhajissanti uttānīkarissanti, uppannaṃ parappavādaṃ sahadhammena suniggahitaṃ niggahetvā sappāṭihāriyaṃ dhammaṃ desessanti.

dn16:3.35.4.pli: Na tāvāhaṃ, pāpima, parinibbāyissāmi, yāva me upāsikā na sāvikā bhavissanti viyattā vinītā visāradā bahussutā dhammadharā dhammānudhammappaṭipannā sāmīcippaṭipannā anudhammacāriniyo, sakaṃ ācariyakaṃ uggahetvā ācikkhissanti desessanti paññapessanti paṭṭhapessanti vivarissanti vibhajissanti uttānīkarissanti, uppannaṃ parappavādaṃ sahadhammena suniggahitaṃ niggahetvā sappāṭihāriyaṃ dhammaṃ desessanti.
dn16:3.35.4.eng: laywoman disciples who are competent, educated, assured, learned.

dn16:3.35.5.pli: Na tāvāhaṃ, pāpima, parinibbāyissāmi, yāva me idaṃ brahmacariyaṃ na iddhañceva bhavissati phītañca vitthārikaṃ bāhujaññaṃ puthubhūtaṃ yāva devamanussehi suppakāsitan’ti.
dn16:3.35.5.eng: I shall not be fully extinguished until my spiritual path is successful and prosperous, extensive, popular, widespread, and well proclaimed wherever there are gods and humans.’

dn16:3.36.1.pli: Idāneva kho, ānanda, ajja cāpāle cetiye māro pāpimā yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho, ānanda, māro pāpimā maṃ etadavoca:
dn16:3.36.1.eng: Today, just now at the Cāpāla Shrine Māra the Wicked approached me once more with the same request, reminding me of my former statement, and saying that those conditions had been fulfilled.

dn16:3.36.2.pli: ‘parinibbātu dāni, bhante, bhagavā, parinibbātu sugato, parinibbānakālo dāni, bhante, bhagavato.

dn16:3.36.3.pli: Bhāsitā kho panesā, bhante, bhagavatā vācā:

dn16:3.36.4.pli: “na tāvāhaṃ, pāpima, parinibbāyissāmi, yāva me bhikkhū na sāvakā bhavissanti …pe…

dn16:3.36.5.pli: yāva me bhikkhuniyo na sāvikā bhavissanti …pe…

dn16:3.36.6.pli: yāva me upāsakā na sāvakā bhavissanti …pe…

dn16:3.36.7.pli: yāva me upāsikā na sāvikā bhavissanti …pe…

dn16:3.36.8.pli: yāva me idaṃ brahmacariyaṃ na iddhañceva bhavissati phītañca vitthārikaṃ bāhujaññaṃ puthubhūtaṃ, yāva devamanussehi suppakāsitan”ti.

dn16:3.36.9.pli: Etarahi kho pana, bhante, bhagavato brahmacariyaṃ iddhañceva phītañca vitthārikaṃ bāhujaññaṃ puthubhūtaṃ, yāva devamanussehi suppakāsitaṃ.

dn16:3.36.10.pli: Parinibbātu dāni, bhante, bhagavā, parinibbātu sugato, parinibbānakālo dāni, bhante, bhagavato’ti.

dn16:3.37.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, ahaṃ, ānanda, māraṃ pāpimantaṃ etadavocaṃ:
dn16:3.37.1.eng: When he had spoken, I said to Māra:

dn16:3.37.2.pli: ‘appossukko tvaṃ, pāpima, hohi, na ciraṃ tathāgatassa parinibbānaṃ bhavissati.
dn16:3.37.2.eng: ‘Relax, Wicked One. The full extinguishment of the Realized One will be soon.

dn16:3.37.3.pli: Ito tiṇṇaṃ māsānaṃ accayena tathāgato parinibbāyissatī’ti.
dn16:3.37.3.eng: Three months from now the Realized One will be fully extinguished.’

dn16:3.37.4.pli: Idāneva kho, ānanda, ajja cāpāle cetiye tathāgatena satena sampajānena āyusaṅkhāro ossaṭṭho”ti.
dn16:3.37.4.eng: So today, just now at the Cāpāla Shrine, mindful and aware, I surrendered the life force.”

dn16:3.38.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn16:3.38.1.eng: When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha,

dn16:3.38.2.pli: “tiṭṭhatu, bhante, bhagavā kappaṃ, tiṭṭhatu sugato kappaṃ bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānan”ti.
dn16:3.38.2.eng: “Sir, may the Blessed One please remain for the proper lifespan! May the Holy One please remain for the proper lifespan! That would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.”

dn16:3.38.4.pli: Mā tathāgataṃ yāci, akālo dāni, ānanda, tathāgataṃ yācanāyā”ti.
dn16:3.38.4.eng: Do not beg the Realized One. Now is not the time to beg the Realized One.”

dn16:3.39.2.pli: tatiyampi kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn16:3.39.2.eng: For a third time, Ānanda said to the Buddha,

dn16:3.39.3.pli: “tiṭṭhatu, bhante, bhagavā kappaṃ, tiṭṭhatu sugato kappaṃ bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānan”ti.
dn16:3.39.3.eng: “Sir, may the Blessed One please remain for the proper lifespan! May the Holy One please remain for the proper lifespan! That would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.”

dn16:3.39.4.eng: “Ānanda, do you have faith in the Realized One’s awakening?”

dn16:3.39.6.pli: “Atha kiñcarahi tvaṃ, ānanda, tathāgataṃ yāvatatiyakaṃ abhinippīḷesī”ti?
dn16:3.39.6.eng: “So why then do you keep pressing me up to the third time?”

dn16:3.40.1.pli: “Sammukhā metaṃ, bhante, bhagavato sutaṃ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṃ:
dn16:3.40.1.eng: “Sir, I have heard and learned this in the presence of the Buddha:
dn16:3.40.1.comm: Note that this is the idiom that Ānanda uses when directly quoting the Buddha.

dn16:3.40.2.pli: ‘yassa kassaci, ānanda, cattāro iddhipādā bhāvitā bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā, so ākaṅkhamāno kappaṃ vā tiṭṭheyya kappāvasesaṃ vā.
dn16:3.40.2.eng: ‘Whoever has developed and cultivated the four bases of psychic power—made them a vehicle and a basis, kept them up, consolidated them, and properly implemented them—may, if they wish, live for the proper lifespan or what’s left of it.

dn16:3.40.3.pli: Tathāgatassa kho, ānanda, cattāro iddhipādā bhāvitā bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā. So ākaṅkhamāno, ānanda, tathāgato kappaṃ vā tiṭṭheyya kappāvasesaṃ vā’”ti.
dn16:3.40.3.eng: The Realized One has developed and cultivated the four bases of psychic power, made them a vehicle and a basis, kept them up, consolidated them, and properly implemented them. If he wished, the Realized One could live for the proper lifespan or what’s left of it.’”

dn16:3.40.6.pli: “Tasmātihānanda, tuyhevetaṃ dukkaṭaṃ, tuyhevetaṃ aparaddhaṃ, yaṃ tvaṃ tathāgatena evaṃ oḷārike nimitte kayiramāne oḷārike obhāse kayiramāne nāsakkhi paṭivijjhituṃ, na tathāgataṃ yāci:
dn16:3.40.6.eng: “Therefore, Ānanda, the misdeed is yours alone, the mistake is yours alone. For even though the Realized One dropped such an obvious hint, such a clear sign, you didn’t beg me to remain for the proper lifespan, or what’s left of it.
dn16:3.40.6.comm: “Misdeed” is dukkaṭaṁ. This term is familiar as the most minor class of offences in the Vinaya. Here we see an informal use of the term as something that has been wrongly done, rather than a legal violation. It is used in a similar way by Mahākassapa at the First Council, who accuses Ānanda of several misdeeds. As a legal term, dukkaṭa is late; the category of offences is not found in the Vinayas of the Mahāsaṅghika group of schools, which use vinayatikkrama for a similar idea.

dn16:3.40.7.pli: ‘tiṭṭhatu, bhante, bhagavā kappaṃ, tiṭṭhatu sugato kappaṃ bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānan’ti.

dn16:3.40.8.pli: Sace tvaṃ, ānanda, tathāgataṃ yāceyyāsi, dveva te vācā tathāgato paṭikkhipeyya, atha tatiyakaṃ adhivāseyya.
dn16:3.40.8.eng: If you had begged me, I would have turned you down twice, but consented on the third time.

dn16:3.40.9.eng: Therefore, Ānanda, the misdeed is yours alone, the mistake is yours alone.

dn16:3.41.1.pli: Ekamidāhaṃ, ānanda, samayaṃ rājagahe viharāmi gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
dn16:3.41.1.eng: Ānanda, this one time I was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
dn16:3.41.1.comm: The Buddha goes on to list multiple places where he hinted to Ānanda, but the only record of such a conversation is at the Cāpāla shrine.

dn16:3.41.3.pli: ‘ramaṇīyaṃ, ānanda, rājagahaṃ, ramaṇīyo, ānanda, gijjhakūṭo pabbato.
dn16:3.41.3.eng: ‘Ānanda, Rājagaha is lovely, and so is the Vulture’s Peak.

dn16:3.41.4.pli: Yassa kassaci, ānanda, cattāro iddhipādā bhāvitā bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā, so ākaṅkhamāno kappaṃ vā tiṭṭheyya kappāvasesaṃ vā.
dn16:3.41.4.eng: Whoever has developed and cultivated the four bases of psychic power—made them a vehicle and a basis, kept them up, consolidated them, and properly implemented them—may, if they wish, live for the proper lifespan or what’s left of it.

dn16:3.41.5.pli: Tathāgatassa kho, ānanda, cattāro iddhipādā bhāvitā bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā, so ākaṅkhamāno, ānanda, tathāgato kappaṃ vā tiṭṭheyya kappāvasesaṃ vā’ti.
dn16:3.41.5.eng: The Realized One has developed and cultivated the four bases of psychic power, made them a vehicle and a basis, kept them up, consolidated them, and properly implemented them. If he wished, the Realized One could live for the proper lifespan or what’s left of it.’

dn16:3.41.6.pli: Evampi kho tvaṃ, ānanda, tathāgatena oḷārike nimitte kayiramāne oḷārike obhāse kayiramāne nāsakkhi paṭivijjhituṃ, na tathāgataṃ yāci:
dn16:3.41.6.eng: But you didn’t get it, even though I dropped such an obvious hint, such a clear sign. You didn’t beg me to remain for the proper lifespan, or what’s left of it.
