dn16:3.41.7.pli: ‘tiṭṭhatu, bhante, bhagavā kappaṃ, tiṭṭhatu sugato kappaṃ bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānan’ti.

dn16:3.41.8.pli: Sace tvaṃ, ānanda, tathāgataṃ yāceyyāsi, dveva te vācā tathāgato paṭikkhipeyya, atha tatiyakaṃ adhivāseyya.
dn16:3.41.8.eng: If you had begged me, I would have turned you down twice, but consented on the third time.

dn16:3.41.9.eng: Therefore, Ānanda, the misdeed is yours alone, the mistake is yours alone.

dn16:3.42.1.pli: Ekamidāhaṃ, ānanda, samayaṃ tattheva rājagahe viharāmi gotamanigrodhe …pe…
dn16:3.42.1.eng: Ānanda, this one time I was staying right there near Rājagaha, at the Gotama banyan tree …
dn16:3.42.1.comm: The following group of places are all near Rājagaha, and collectively illustrate the variety of dwellings and environs enjoyed by the mendicants practicing there. | The Gotama banyan tree-shrine is mentioned only here. Gotama is a common name, and this shrine does not appear to have any connection with the Buddha.

dn16:3.42.2.comm: A cliff from which bandits were tossed as a means of execution.

dn16:3.42.3.eng: in the Sattapaṇṇi cave on the slopes of Vebhāra …
dn16:3.42.3.comm: The Sanskrit form is Vaibhāra or Vaihāra. The Pali tradition says the First Council was held near the entrance to this cave  (Dīpavaṁsa 4.19, Mahāvaṁsa 3.19, Samantapāsādikā Paṭhamamahāsaṅgītikathā). The Vinayas all agree that it was at Rājagaha, but traditions vary as to the exact location.

dn16:3.42.4.eng: at the Black Rock on the slopes of Isigili …
dn16:3.42.4.comm: A large open area where Jains did their penances (MN 14:15.2) and the Buddha taught occasionally (SN 8.10), but it is most famous as the place the monks Godhika (SN 4.23) and Vakkali took their lives (SN 22.87).

dn16:3.42.5.eng: in the Cool Grove, under the Snake’s Hood Grotto …
dn16:3.42.5.comm: Mentioned several times in the suttas as a pleasant place to meditate, it is notable as the site of the conversion of the Buddha’s chief layman disciple Anāthapiṇḍika (SN 10.8). But the most famous event there was when the Buddha moderated the monk Soṇa’s excessive striving (AN 6.55).

dn16:3.42.6.comm: The hot springs near Rājagaha were a popular place for monks to bathe, so much so that they prompted a rule ensuring that the monks did not monopolize the springs (Bu Pc 57). They are still in use and just as popular as ever.

dn16:3.42.7.eng: in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground …
dn16:3.42.7.comm: A personal gift of King Bimbisāra, this was the first permanent monastery offered to the Buddha and his Saṅgha (Kd 1:22.17.3).

dn16:3.42.9.comm: Mahākappina stayed here (Kd 1:5.3.1), and the Buddha rested there when his foot was first injured, apparently by Devadatta, before Jīvaka offered his mango grove (SN 1.38, SN 4.13).

dn16:3.43.1.eng: And in each place I said to you:

dn16:3.43.2.pli: ‘ramaṇīyaṃ, ānanda, rājagahaṃ, ramaṇīyo gijjhakūṭo pabbato, ramaṇīyo gotamanigrodho, ramaṇīyo corapapāto, ramaṇīyā vebhārapasse sattapaṇṇiguhā, ramaṇīyā isigilipasse kāḷasilā, ramaṇīyo sītavane sappasoṇḍikapabbhāro, ramaṇīyo tapodārāmo, ramaṇīyo veḷuvane kalandakanivāpo, ramaṇīyaṃ jīvakambavanaṃ, ramaṇīyo maddakucchismiṃ migadāyo.
dn16:3.43.2.eng: ‘Ānanda, Rājagaha is lovely, and so are all these places. …

dn16:3.44.1.pli: Yassa kassaci, ānanda, cattāro iddhipādā bhāvitā bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā …pe…

dn16:3.44.2.pli: ākaṅkhamāno, ānanda, tathāgato kappaṃ vā tiṭṭheyya kappāvasesaṃ vā’ti.
dn16:3.44.2.eng: If he wished, the Realized One could live for the proper lifespan or what’s left of it.’

dn16:3.44.3.pli: Evampi kho tvaṃ, ānanda, tathāgatena oḷārike nimitte kayiramāne oḷārike obhāse kayiramāne nāsakkhi paṭivijjhituṃ, na tathāgataṃ yāci:
dn16:3.44.3.eng: But you didn’t get it, even though I dropped such an obvious hint, such a clear sign. You didn’t beg me to remain for the proper lifespan, or what’s left of it.

dn16:3.44.4.pli: ‘tiṭṭhatu, bhante, bhagavā kappaṃ, tiṭṭhatu sugato kappaṃ bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānan’ti.

dn16:3.44.5.pli: Sace tvaṃ, ānanda, tathāgataṃ yāceyyāsi, dveva te vācā tathāgato paṭikkhipeyya, atha tatiyakaṃ adhivāseyya.

dn16:3.45.1.pli: Ekamidāhaṃ, ānanda, samayaṃ idheva vesāliyaṃ viharāmi udene cetiye.
dn16:3.45.1.eng: Ānanda, this one time I was staying right here near Vesālī, at the Udena Shrine …
dn16:3.45.1.comm: The following group of places are all in the Vajjian country near Vesālī. Whereas the varied sites around Rājagaha reflect the rugged terrain there, at Vesālī all the sites are tree-shrines, as the surrounding land is flat. DN 24:1.11.5 indicates where they lay relative to Vesālī; the Udena shrine was to the east, and the next three to the south, west, and north respectively. | Udena is an epithet of the “arising” sun (Rig Veda 1.48.7), although here it may have the sense “prosperity”.

dn16:3.45.4.pli: Yassa kassaci, ānanda, cattāro iddhipādā bhāvitā bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā, so ākaṅkhamāno kappaṃ vā tiṭṭheyya kappāvasesaṃ vā.

dn16:3.45.5.pli: Tathāgatassa kho, ānanda, cattāro iddhipādā bhāvitā bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā, so ākaṅkhamāno, ānanda, tathāgato kappaṃ vā tiṭṭheyya kappāvasesaṃ vā’ti.

dn16:3.45.6.pli: Evampi kho tvaṃ, ānanda, tathāgatena oḷārike nimitte kayiramāne oḷārike obhāse kayiramāne nāsakkhi paṭivijjhituṃ, na tathāgataṃ yāci:

dn16:3.45.7.pli: ‘tiṭṭhatu, bhante, bhagavā kappaṃ, tiṭṭhatu sugato kappaṃ bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānan’ti.

dn16:3.45.8.pli: Sace tvaṃ, ānanda, tathāgataṃ yāceyyāsi, dveva te vācā tathāgato paṭikkhipeyya, atha tatiyakaṃ adhivāseyya, tasmātihānanda, tuyhevetaṃ dukkaṭaṃ, tuyhevetaṃ aparaddhaṃ.

dn16:3.46.1.pli: Ekamidāhaṃ, ānanda, samayaṃ idheva vesāliyaṃ viharāmi gotamake cetiye …pe…
dn16:3.46.1.comm: Named after the local yakkha, to whom offerings would have been made. It could get cold enough to snow, prompting the Buddha to lay down a rule permitting three robes (Kd 1:13.2.1). A short but galaxy-shaking discourse was once taught there (AN 3.125:0.3).

dn16:3.46.2.comm: The Pali has amba (“mango”) and ambaka (“maiden”) as variants. The commentary supports the latter, saying it was named for seven legendary princesses of Varanasi in the time of Buddha Kassapa, all of whom went on to become great disciples of our Buddha. I made this translation on the small island of Qimei off the south coast of Taiwan, where there is a shrine to the “seven maidens” who gave the island its name. Stories of “seven maidens” are widespread in myth and folklore all over the world, including Aboriginal Dreamtime stories. The archetype descends from the constellation known in English as Pleiades and in Sanskrit as Kṛttikā. Since there are six main visible stars in the cluster today, the stories often tell of how the youngest of the seven sisters was lost. In the Buddhist telling this is Visākhā, the only sister not to become an arahant in this life.

dn16:3.46.3.comm: This was, obviously, a fertility shrine.

dn16:3.46.4.comm: Previously mentioned as the place where the seven principles of non-decline were taught to the Licchavis. The meaning of Sārandada is obscure and variants profligate, but it might be derived from the Munda word sara, “funeral pyre”. The commentary says it was taken over from an old shrine to a yakkha of that name.

dn16:3.47.1.pli: idāneva kho tāhaṃ, ānanda, ajja cāpāle cetiye āmantesiṃ:
dn16:3.47.1.eng: and just now, today at the Cāpāla Shrine. There I said to you:

dn16:3.47.2.pli: ‘ramaṇīyā, ānanda, vesālī, ramaṇīyaṃ udenaṃ cetiyaṃ, ramaṇīyaṃ gotamakaṃ cetiyaṃ, ramaṇīyaṃ sattambaṃ cetiyaṃ, ramaṇīyaṃ bahuputtaṃ cetiyaṃ, ramaṇīyaṃ sārandadaṃ cetiyaṃ, ramaṇīyaṃ cāpālaṃ cetiyaṃ.
dn16:3.47.2.eng: ‘Ānanda, Vesālī is lovely. And the Udena, Gotamaka, Seven Maidens, Many Sons, Sārandada, and Cāpāla Shrines are all lovely.

dn16:3.47.3.pli: Yassa kassaci, ānanda, cattāro iddhipādā bhāvitā bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā, so ākaṅkhamāno kappaṃ vā tiṭṭheyya kappāvasesaṃ vā.
dn16:3.47.3.eng: Whoever has developed and cultivated the four bases of psychic power—made them a vehicle and a basis, kept them up, consolidated them, and properly implemented them—may, if they wish, live for the proper lifespan or what’s left of it.

dn16:3.47.4.pli: Tathāgatassa kho, ānanda, cattāro iddhipādā bhāvitā bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā, so ākaṅkhamāno, ānanda, tathāgato kappaṃ vā tiṭṭheyya kappāvasesaṃ vā’ti.
dn16:3.47.4.eng: The Realized One has developed and cultivated the four bases of psychic power, made them a vehicle and a basis, kept them up, consolidated them, and properly implemented them. If he wished, the Realized One could live for the proper lifespan or what’s left of it.’

dn16:3.47.5.pli: Evampi kho tvaṃ, ānanda, tathāgatena oḷārike nimitte kayiramāne oḷārike obhāse kayiramāne nāsakkhi paṭivijjhituṃ, na tathāgataṃ yāci:
dn16:3.47.5.eng: But you didn’t get it, even though I dropped such an obvious hint, such a clear sign. You didn’t beg me to remain for the proper lifespan, or what’s left of it, saying:

dn16:3.47.6.pli: ‘tiṭṭhatu bhagavā kappaṃ, tiṭṭhatu sugato kappaṃ bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānan’ti.
dn16:3.47.6.eng: ‘Sir, may the Blessed One please remain for the proper lifespan! May the Holy One please remain for the proper lifespan! That would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.’

dn16:3.47.7.pli: Sace tvaṃ, ānanda, tathāgataṃ yāceyyāsi, dveva te vācā tathāgato paṭikkhipeyya, atha tatiyakaṃ adhivāseyya.
dn16:3.47.7.eng: If you had begged me, I would have turned you down twice, but consented on the third time.

dn16:3.47.8.eng: Therefore, Ānanda, the misdeed is yours alone, the mistake is yours alone.

dn16:3.48.1.pli: Nanu etaṃ, ānanda, mayā paṭikacceva akkhātaṃ:
dn16:3.48.1.eng: Did I not prepare for this when I explained that

dn16:3.48.2.eng: we must be parted and separated from all we hold dear and beloved?

dn16:3.48.3.pli: Taṃ kutettha, ānanda, labbhā, yaṃ taṃ jātaṃ bhūtaṃ saṅkhataṃ palokadhammaṃ, taṃ vata mā palujjīti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati’.
dn16:3.48.3.eng: How could it possibly be so that what is born, created, conditioned, and liable to wear out should not wear out?

dn16:3.48.4.pli: Yaṃ kho panetaṃ, ānanda, tathāgatena cattaṃ vantaṃ muttaṃ pahīnaṃ paṭinissaṭṭhaṃ ossaṭṭho āyusaṅkhāro, ekaṃsena vācā bhāsitā:
dn16:3.48.4.eng: The Realized One has discarded, eliminated, released, given up, relinquished, and surrendered the life force. He has categorically stated:

dn16:3.48.5.eng: ‘The full extinguishment of the Realized One will be soon.

dn16:3.48.6.pli: Ito tiṇṇaṃ māsānaṃ accayena tathāgato parinibbāyissatī’ti.
dn16:3.48.6.eng: Three months from now the Realized One will be fully extinguished.’

dn16:3.48.7.pli: Tañca tathāgato jīvitahetu puna paccāvamissatīti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
dn16:3.48.7.eng: It’s not possible for the Realized One, for the sake of life, to take back the life force once it has been given up like that.
dn16:3.48.7.comm: “Take back” is paccāvamissati, which has several variants. It occurs in Ja 69 and Ja 509, where it is the opposite of vamati, to “expel, vomit”.

dn16:3.48.8.eng: Come, Ānanda, let’s go to the Great Wood, the hall with the peaked roof.”
dn16:3.48.8.comm: This was the major Saṅgha residence near Vesālī. The Great Wood, according to the commentary, stretched as far as the Himalayas. Later tradition says that a town should have three woods: a “great wood” for wilderness (mahāvana); a “prosperity wood” for resources (sirivana); and an “ascetic wood” for spiritual practice (tapovana).

dn16:3.48.9.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paccassosi.

dn16:3.49.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmatā ānandena saddhiṃ yena mahāvanaṃ kūṭāgārasālā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
dn16:3.49.1.eng: So the Buddha went with Ānanda to the hall with the peaked roof, and said to him,

dn16:3.49.2.pli: “gaccha tvaṃ, ānanda, yāvatikā bhikkhū vesāliṃ upanissāya viharanti, te sabbe upaṭṭhānasālāyaṃ sannipātehī”ti.
dn16:3.49.2.eng: “Go, Ānanda, gather all the mendicants staying in the vicinity of Vesālī together in the assembly hall.”
dn16:3.49.2.comm: Compare the earlier request to gather all the mendicants around Rājagaha (DN 16:1.6.2).

dn16:3.49.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paṭissutvā yāvatikā bhikkhū vesāliṃ upanissāya viharanti, te sabbe upaṭṭhānasālāyaṃ sannipātetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn16:3.49.3.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied Ānanda. He did what the Buddha asked, went up to him, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him,

dn16:3.49.4.pli: “sannipatito, bhante, bhikkhusaṅgho, yassadāni, bhante, bhagavā kālaṃ maññatī”ti.
dn16:3.49.4.eng: “Sir, the mendicant Saṅgha has assembled. Please, sir, go at your convenience.”

dn16:3.50.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā yenupaṭṭhānasālā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
dn16:3.50.1.eng: Then the Buddha went to the assembly hall, where he sat on the seat spread out

dn16:3.50.3.pli: “tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ye te mayā dhammā abhiññā desitā, te vo sādhukaṃ uggahetvā āsevitabbā bhāvetabbā bahulīkātabbā, yathayidaṃ brahmacariyaṃ addhaniyaṃ assa ciraṭṭhitikaṃ, tadassa bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
dn16:3.50.3.eng: “So, mendicants, having carefully memorized those things I have taught you from my direct knowledge, you should cultivate, develop, and make much of them so that this spiritual practice may last for a long time. That would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.
dn16:3.50.3.comm: Memorization was considered an essential basis for learning. In similar passages, we also find the injunction to “recite” the teachings, thus authorizing the recitation of the Buddha’s teachings after his death, which was later formalized in the Councils (saṅgīti).

dn16:3.50.4.pli: Katame ca te, bhikkhave, dhammā mayā abhiññā desitā, ye vo sādhukaṃ uggahetvā āsevitabbā bhāvetabbā bahulīkātabbā, yathayidaṃ brahmacariyaṃ addhaniyaṃ assa ciraṭṭhitikaṃ, tadassa bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
dn16:3.50.4.eng: And what are those things I have taught from my direct knowledge?

dn16:3.50.5.pli: Seyyathidaṃ—cattāro satipaṭṭhānā, cattāro sammappadhānā, cattāro iddhipādā, pañcindriyāni, pañca balāni, satta bojjhaṅgā, ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo.
dn16:3.50.5.eng: They are: the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, the four right efforts, the four bases of psychic power, the five faculties, the five powers, the seven awakening factors, and the noble eightfold path.
dn16:3.50.5.comm: These are the sets of practices later called the 37 bodhiyapakkhiyā dhammā, the “wings to awakening”. Here they are presented as an essential summary of the Buddha’s teachings. They form the backbone of the final book of the Saṁyuttanikāya, the Maggavagga (or Mahāvagga). It is likely that the Buddha was referring to the earliest recension of this text. They are found as a summary of the Buddha’s teachings at DN 29:17.3, MN 103:3.2, MN 104:5.3, and AN 8.19:17.2 = Ud 5.5:25.2.

dn16:3.51.1.pli: Ime kho te, bhikkhave, dhammā mayā abhiññā desitā, ye vo sādhukaṃ uggahetvā āsevitabbā bhāvetabbā bahulīkātabbā, yathayidaṃ brahmacariyaṃ addhaniyaṃ assa ciraṭṭhitikaṃ, tadassa bahujanahitāya bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānan”ti.
dn16:3.51.1.eng: These are the things I have taught from my direct knowledge. Having carefully memorized them, you should cultivate, develop, and make much of them so that this spiritual practice may last for a long time. That would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.”

dn16:3.51.2.eng: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants:

dn16:3.51.3.eng: “Come now, mendicants, I say to you all:

dn16:3.51.4.comm: This is perhaps the briefest summary possible of the Buddha’s teaching. The world as it is, and all the beings in it, are created and sustained through conditions. Since the conditions that sustain them are finite, the conditioned phenomena are also finite and must come to an end. Reflecting on this gives rise to gratitude for the life we have and the opportunities it grants us, and determination to live and practice dedicated to the realization of the unconditioned, Nibbana.

dn16:3.51.5.eng: The full extinguishment of the Realized One will be soon.

dn16:3.51.6.pli: Ito tiṇṇaṃ māsānaṃ accayena tathāgato parinibbāyissatī”ti.
dn16:3.51.6.eng: Three months from now the Realized One will be fully extinguished.”

dn16:3.51.7.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

dn16:3.51.8.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
dn16:3.51.8.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

dn16:3.51.9.comm: “Ripe old age” is paripakko vayo.

dn16:3.51.10.eng: and little of my life is left.

dn16:3.51.11.eng: Having given it up, I’ll depart;

dn16:3.51.12.eng: I’ve made a refuge for myself.

dn16:3.51.15.comm: “Well-settled thoughts” is susamāhitasaṅkappā. Compare asamāhitasaṅkappo at AN 4.22:5.3.

dn16:3.51.16.eng: take good care of your minds.

dn16:3.51.20.eng: will make an end to suffering.”

dn16:4.1.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya vesāliṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
dn16:4.1.1.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Vesālī for alms.

dn16:4.1.2.pli: Vesāliyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto nāgāpalokitaṃ vesāliṃ apaloketvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
dn16:4.1.2.eng: Then, after the meal, on his return from almsround, he turned to gaze back at Vesālī, the way that elephants do. He said to Venerable Ānanda:
dn16:4.1.2.comm: Nāgāpalokitaṁ is the “elephant look”. There is a similar Sanskrit term siṁhāvalokana, the “lion look”, said to be the slow glance back that a lion makes as he leaves his kill. There is a nuance in meaning here, because while apalokana literally means to “look back”, it is used in the sense to “take leave” before setting out on a journey.

dn16:4.1.3.pli: “idaṃ pacchimakaṃ, ānanda, tathāgatassa vesāliyā dassanaṃ bhavissati.
dn16:4.1.3.eng: “Ānanda, this will be the last time the Realized One sees Vesālī.

dn16:4.1.4.eng: Come, Ānanda, let’s go to Wares Village.”
dn16:4.1.4.comm: Bhaṇḍagāma, where bhaṇḍa means “wares”; it must have been a trading post. It seems the villages in this passage were named after their chief economic activity, so I translate them to highlight this pragmatic system.

dn16:4.1.5.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paccassosi.

dn16:4.2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ yena bhaṇḍagāmo tadavasari.
dn16:4.2.1.eng: Then the Buddha together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants arrived at Wares Village,

dn16:4.2.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

dn16:4.2.4.pli: “catunnaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammānaṃ ananubodhā appaṭivedhā evamidaṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ sandhāvitaṃ saṃsaritaṃ mamañceva tumhākañca.
dn16:4.2.4.eng: “Mendicants, due to not understanding and not penetrating four things, both you and I have wandered and transmigrated for such a very long time.

dn16:4.2.6.pli: Ariyassa, bhikkhave, sīlassa ananubodhā appaṭivedhā evamidaṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ sandhāvitaṃ saṃsaritaṃ mamañceva tumhākañca.
dn16:4.2.6.comm: This four also found at AN 4.1:2.3 and AN 7.66:14.4.

dn16:4.2.7.pli: Ariyassa, bhikkhave, samādhissa ananubodhā appaṭivedhā evamidaṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ sandhāvitaṃ saṃsaritaṃ mamañceva tumhākañca.

dn16:4.2.8.pli: Ariyāya, bhikkhave, paññāya ananubodhā appaṭivedhā evamidaṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ sandhāvitaṃ saṃsaritaṃ mamañceva tumhākañca.

dn16:4.2.9.pli: Ariyāya, bhikkhave, vimuttiyā ananubodhā appaṭivedhā evamidaṃ dīghamaddhānaṃ sandhāvitaṃ saṃsaritaṃ mamañceva tumhākañca.

dn16:4.2.10.pli: Tayidaṃ, bhikkhave, ariyaṃ sīlaṃ anubuddhaṃ paṭividdhaṃ, ariyo samādhi anubuddho paṭividdho, ariyā paññā anubuddhā paṭividdhā, ariyā vimutti anubuddhā paṭividdhā, ucchinnā bhavataṇhā, khīṇā bhavanetti, natthi dāni punabbhavo”ti.
dn16:4.2.10.eng: These noble ethics, immersion, wisdom, and freedom have been understood and comprehended. Craving for continued existence has been cut off; the leash to existence is ended; now there’ll be no more future lives.”

dn16:4.3.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

dn16:4.3.2.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
dn16:4.3.2.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

dn16:4.3.7.eng: And so the Buddha, having insight,
dn16:4.3.7.comm: Here the text refers to the Buddha in the third person; compare the previous set of verses in first person. Although the text states that these verses were spoken by the Buddha, it is possible that, as with many similar cases especially in the Aṅguttaranikāya, the verses were added by redactors.

dn16:4.3.8.eng: explained this teaching to the mendicants.

dn16:4.3.9.eng: The teacher made an end of suffering,

dn16:4.3.10.eng: seeing clearly, he is fully quenched.”
dn16:4.3.10.comm: Note the use of “quenched” (parinibbuto) here while the Buddha is still alive.

dn16:4.4.1.pli: Tatrāpi sudaṃ bhagavā bhaṇḍagāme viharanto etadeva bahulaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ dhammiṃ kathaṃ karoti:
dn16:4.4.1.eng: And while staying there, too, he often gave this Dhamma talk to the mendicants:

dn16:4.4.2.eng: “Such is ethics, such is immersion, such is wisdom.

dn16:4.4.3.eng: When immersion is imbued with ethics it’s very fruitful and beneficial.

dn16:4.4.4.eng: When wisdom is imbued with immersion it’s very fruitful and beneficial.

dn16:4.4.5.pli: Paññāparibhāvitaṃ cittaṃ sammadeva āsavehi vimuccati, seyyathidaṃ—
dn16:4.4.5.eng: When the mind is imbued with wisdom it is rightly freed from the defilements, namely,

dn16:4.4.6.eng: the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.”

dn16:4.5.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā bhaṇḍagāme yathābhirantaṃ viharitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
dn16:4.5.1.eng: When the Buddha had stayed in Wares Village as long as he pleased, he addressed Ānanda,

dn16:4.5.2.eng: “Come, Ānanda, let’s go to Elephant Village.”…
dn16:4.5.2.comm: Hatthigāma, probably a village which specialized in training elephants.

dn16:4.5.5.comm: Departing from the economic naming scheme, here bhoga does not mean “wealth”. Rather, the Bhogas were one of the clans of the Vajji Federation.

dn16:4.6.1.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paccassosi.

dn16:4.6.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ yena bhoganagaraṃ tadavasari.
dn16:4.6.2.eng: Then the Buddha together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants arrived at Bhoga City,

dn16:4.7.1.pli: Tatra sudaṃ bhagavā bhoganagare viharati ānande cetiye.
dn16:4.7.1.eng: where he stayed at the Ānanda Shrine.

dn16:4.7.2.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

dn16:4.7.3.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the four great references.
dn16:4.7.3.comm: “Great references” is mahāpadesa; also at AN 4.180. A different set of four mahāpadesas are Kd 1:40.1.1, which provide criteria by which mendicants may judge what is and is not allowable.

dn16:4.7.4.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

dn16:4.7.5.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṃ.

dn16:4.8.2.pli: ‘sammukhā metaṃ, āvuso, bhagavato sutaṃ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṃ,
dn16:4.8.2.eng: ‘Reverend, I have heard and learned this in the presence of the Buddha:
dn16:4.8.2.comm: The phrase used in the suttas when reporting a teaching heard directly from the Buddha, eg. SN 55.52:5.1, SN 22.90:9.1, MN 47:10.7, etc.

dn16:4.8.3.pli: ayaṃ dhammo ayaṃ vinayo idaṃ satthusāsanan’ti.
dn16:4.8.3.eng: this is the teaching, this is the training, this is the Teacher’s instruction.’
dn16:4.8.3.comm: Dhamma, vinaya, and satthusāsana are used in the suttas in the general sense of the entirety of the Buddha’s teachings. In his advice to Mahāpajāpatī (AN 8.53) and Upāli (AN 7.83), they are said to be whatever conforms with letting go. A stream-enterer who is a lay person is grounded in them (AN 6.16:7.2). They are more frequent in the Vinaya, being used as a general qualifier of a legitimate legal procedure (Bu Pc 63:2.1.8). Due to this, the fact that there are three items, and the fact that dhamma and sutta are different words, we should not take dhamma and vinaya here as equivalent to sutta and vinaya below. Rather, they are a general claim to authenticity and do not specify particular texts.

dn16:4.8.4.pli: Tassa, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno bhāsitaṃ neva abhinanditabbaṃ nappaṭikkositabbaṃ.
dn16:4.8.4.eng: You should neither approve nor reject that mendicant’s statement.
dn16:4.8.4.comm: As at MN 112:3.1, DN 29:18.4, and AN 4.180:2.5.

dn16:4.8.5.pli: Anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā tāni padabyañjanāni sādhukaṃ uggahetvā sutte osāretabbāni, vinaye sandassetabbāni.
dn16:4.8.5.eng: Instead, having carefully memorized those words and phrases, you should make sure they fit in the discourse and are exhibited in the training.
dn16:4.8.5.comm: It is tempting to assume that sutta here means the Suttapiṭaka and vinaya means the Vinayapiṭaka, or at least an earlier version of these texts; but this is not supported by tradition. The late canonical Netti explains sutta as “the four noble truths” and vinaya as “the removal of greed, hate, and delusion” (Ne 6). The commentaries discuss many interpretations; ultimately they agree with the Netti for vinaya, but say sutta means the entire Tipiṭaka. I think the Netti is correct: teachings should “fit in” with the four noble truths (like other footprints fit in to an elephant’s footprint, MN 28), and they should “be exhibited” in that the results of practice should be apparent (sandiṭṭhika). | “Memorize” (uggahetvā), because in an oral tradition a text is not learned until it is known by heart; such claims must be taken seriously. | “Fit into” is osāreti or otāreti per AN 4.180; the two words have a similar meaning, “to flow down into”.

dn16:4.8.6.pli: Tāni ce sutte osāriyamānāni vinaye sandassiyamānāni na ceva sutte osaranti, na ca vinaye sandissanti, niṭṭhamettha gantabbaṃ:
dn16:4.8.6.eng: If they do not fit in the discourse and are not exhibited in the training, you should draw the conclusion:
dn16:4.8.6.comm: The text has ca (“and”) rather than vā (“or”), which would be expected if they were to be found in one or other textual collection. This is urging that any teaching fits in with the fundamental principles of the four noble truths, and is effective in removing defilements.

dn16:4.8.7.pli: ‘addhā idaṃ na ceva tassa bhagavato vacanaṃ;
dn16:4.8.7.eng: ‘Clearly this is not the word of the Buddha.

dn16:4.8.8.eng: It has been incorrectly memorized by that mendicant.’

dn16:4.8.9.eng: And so you should discard it.

dn16:4.8.10.pli: Tāni ce sutte osāriyamānāni vinaye sandassiyamānāni sutte ceva osaranti, vinaye ca sandissanti, niṭṭhamettha gantabbaṃ:
dn16:4.8.10.eng: If they do fit in the discourse and are exhibited in the training, you should draw the conclusion:

dn16:4.8.11.eng: ‘Clearly this is the word of the Buddha.

dn16:4.8.12.eng: It has been correctly memorized by that mendicant.’

dn16:4.8.13.eng: You should remember it. This is the first great reference.
dn16:4.8.13.comm: The Pali text appears to say that one should remember the mahāpadesa, whereas the Sanskrit clearly says one should remember the passage (ayaṁ dharmo’yaṁ vinaya idaṁ śāstuḥ śāsanam iti viditvā dhārayitavyāḥ). It seems as if this pattern should underlie the Pali too, for if the passage is false, one “should discard it” (chaḍḍeyyātha). In the case of a correct passage we should expect a parallel injunction that one “should remember it” (dhāreyyātha). But if this applies to the mahāpadesa there is no such injunction. Thus it seems as if the Sanskrit is correct here and the Pali corrupt. I restore it by reversing the order of the phrases.

dn16:4.9.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ vadeyya:

dn16:4.9.2.pli: ‘amukasmiṃ nāma āvāse saṅgho viharati sathero sapāmokkho.
dn16:4.9.2.eng: ‘In such-and-such monastery lives a Saṅgha with seniors and leaders.
dn16:4.9.2.comm: Each of the four references is a little less solid than the previous. Here one hasn’t heard from the Buddha, but from the Saṅgha. The fact that one hears it from the Saṅgha implies a kind of formal group recitation such as a saṅgīti or “council”.

dn16:4.9.3.pli: Tassa me saṅghassa sammukhā sutaṃ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṃ,
dn16:4.9.3.eng: I’ve heard and learned this in the presence of that Saṅgha:

dn16:4.9.4.pli: ayaṃ dhammo ayaṃ vinayo idaṃ satthusāsanan’ti.
dn16:4.9.4.eng: this is the teaching, this is the training, this is the Teacher’s instruction.’

dn16:4.9.5.pli: Tassa, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno bhāsitaṃ neva abhinanditabbaṃ nappaṭikkositabbaṃ.
dn16:4.9.5.eng: You should neither approve nor reject that mendicant’s statement.

dn16:4.9.6.pli: Anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā tāni padabyañjanāni sādhukaṃ uggahetvā sutte osāretabbāni, vinaye sandassetabbāni.
dn16:4.9.6.eng: Instead, having carefully memorized those words and phrases, you should make sure they fit in the discourse and are exhibited in the training.

dn16:4.9.7.pli: Tāni ce sutte osāriyamānāni vinaye sandassiyamānāni na ceva sutte osaranti, na ca vinaye sandissanti, niṭṭhamettha gantabbaṃ:
dn16:4.9.7.eng: If they do not fit in the discourse and are not exhibited in the training, you should draw the conclusion:

dn16:4.9.8.pli: ‘addhā idaṃ na ceva tassa bhagavato vacanaṃ;
dn16:4.9.8.eng: ‘Clearly this is not the word of the Buddha.

dn16:4.9.9.eng: It has been incorrectly memorized by that Saṅgha.’

dn16:4.9.10.eng: And so you should discard it.

dn16:4.9.11.pli: Tāni ce sutte osāriyamānāni vinaye sandassiyamānāni sutte ceva osaranti, vinaye ca sandissanti, niṭṭhamettha gantabbaṃ:
dn16:4.9.11.eng: If they do fit in the discourse and are exhibited in the training, you should draw the conclusion:

dn16:4.9.12.eng: ‘Clearly this is the word of the Buddha.

dn16:4.9.13.eng: It has been correctly memorized by that Saṅgha.’

dn16:4.9.14.eng: You should remember it. This is the second great reference.

dn16:4.10.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ vadeyya:

dn16:4.10.2.pli: ‘amukasmiṃ nāma āvāse sambahulā therā bhikkhū viharanti bahussutā āgatāgamā dhammadharā vinayadharā mātikādharā.
dn16:4.10.2.eng: ‘In such-and-such monastery there are several senior mendicants who are very learned, inheritors of the heritage, who have memorized the teachings, the monastic law, and the outlines.
dn16:4.10.2.comm: Now one learns not from a unified Saṅgha, but from several learned elders. This is a stock description of learned mendicants (eg. AN 3.20:6.2). | “Inheritors of the heritage” is āgatāgamā, where āgama means “what has come down”, namely the scriptural heritage. Āgama is a synonym for nikāya in the sense of “collection of scripture”. | The “outlines” (mātikā, literally “matrix”) are the summary outlines of topics that served as seeds for the development of Abhidhamma. DN 16:3.50.5 features one of the earliest of such lists, the 37 path factors that the Buddha “taught from his own direct knowledge”. These serve as outline for the section on the path in the Saṁyutta, from where they were adopted in various Abhidhamma texts such as the Vibhaṅga.

dn16:4.10.3.pli: Tesaṃ me therānaṃ sammukhā sutaṃ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṃ—
dn16:4.10.3.eng: I’ve heard and learned this in the presence of those senior mendicants:

dn16:4.10.4.pli: ayaṃ dhammo ayaṃ vinayo idaṃ satthusāsanan’ti.
dn16:4.10.4.eng: this is the teaching, this is the training, this is the Teacher’s instruction.’

dn16:4.10.5.pli: Tassa, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno bhāsitaṃ neva abhinanditabbaṃ …
dn16:4.10.5.eng: You should neither approve nor reject that mendicant’s statement.

dn16:4.10.6.eng: Instead, having carefully memorized those words and phrases, you should make sure they fit in the discourse and are exhibited in the training.

dn16:4.10.7.pli: na ca vinaye sandissanti, niṭṭhamettha gantabbaṃ:
dn16:4.10.7.eng: If they do not fit in the discourse and are not exhibited in the training, you should draw the conclusion:

dn16:4.10.8.pli: ‘addhā idaṃ na ceva tassa bhagavato vacanaṃ;
dn16:4.10.8.eng: ‘Clearly this is not the word of the Buddha.

dn16:4.10.9.eng: It has not been correctly memorized by those senior mendicants.’

dn16:4.10.10.eng: And so you should discard it.

dn16:4.10.12.eng: If they do fit in the discourse and are exhibited in the training, you should draw the conclusion:

dn16:4.10.13.eng: ‘Clearly this is the word of the Buddha.

dn16:4.10.14.eng: It has been correctly memorized by those senior mendicants.’

dn16:4.10.15.eng: You should remember it. This is the third great reference.

dn16:4.11.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ vadeyya:

dn16:4.11.2.pli: ‘amukasmiṃ nāma āvāse eko thero bhikkhu viharati bahussuto āgatāgamo dhammadharo vinayadharo mātikādharo.
dn16:4.11.2.eng: ‘In such-and-such monastery there is a single senior mendicant who is very learned, an inheritor of the heritage, who has memorized the teachings, the monastic law, and the outlines.
dn16:4.11.2.comm: Finally the testimony of a single mendicant, which is the weakest of all. Nonetheless, the procedure is the same.

dn16:4.11.3.pli: Tassa me therassa sammukhā sutaṃ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṃ—
dn16:4.11.3.eng: I’ve heard and learned this in the presence of that senior mendicant:

dn16:4.11.4.pli: ayaṃ dhammo ayaṃ vinayo idaṃ satthusāsanan’ti.
dn16:4.11.4.eng: this is the teaching, this is the training, this is the Teacher’s instruction.’

dn16:4.11.5.pli: Tassa, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno bhāsitaṃ neva abhinanditabbaṃ nappaṭikkositabbaṃ.
dn16:4.11.5.eng: You should neither approve nor reject that mendicant’s statement.

dn16:4.11.6.pli: Anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā tāni padabyañjanāni sādhukaṃ uggahetvā sutte osāretabbāni, vinaye sandassetabbāni.
dn16:4.11.6.eng: Instead, having carefully memorized those words and phrases, you should make sure they fit in the discourse and are exhibited in the training.

dn16:4.11.7.pli: Tāni ce sutte osāriyamānāni vinaye sandassiyamānāni na ceva sutte osaranti, na ca vinaye sandissanti, niṭṭhamettha gantabbaṃ:
dn16:4.11.7.eng: If they do not fit in the discourse and are not exhibited in the training, you should draw the conclusion:

dn16:4.11.8.pli: ‘addhā idaṃ na ceva tassa bhagavato vacanaṃ;
dn16:4.11.8.eng: ‘Clearly this is not the word of the Buddha.

dn16:4.11.9.eng: It has been incorrectly memorized by that senior mendicant.’

dn16:4.11.10.eng: And so you should discard it.

dn16:4.11.11.pli: Tāni ca sutte osāriyamānāni vinaye sandassiyamānāni sutte ceva osaranti, vinaye ca sandissanti, niṭṭhamettha gantabbaṃ:
dn16:4.11.11.eng: If they do fit in the discourse and are exhibited in the training, you should draw the conclusion:

dn16:4.11.12.eng: ‘Clearly this is the word of the Buddha.

dn16:4.11.13.eng: It has been correctly memorized by that senior mendicant.’

dn16:4.11.14.eng: You should remember it. This is the fourth great reference.

dn16:4.11.15.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro mahāpadese dhāreyyāthā”ti.
dn16:4.11.15.eng: These are the four great references.”
dn16:4.11.15.comm: The parallel at AN 4.180:9.11 omits dhāreyyāthā, which I take to be the correct reading. See my note on dhāreyyāthā at DN 16:4.8.13.

dn16:4.12.1.pli: Tatrapi sudaṃ bhagavā bhoganagare viharanto ānande cetiye etadeva bahulaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ dhammiṃ kathaṃ karoti:
dn16:4.12.1.eng: And while staying at the Ānanda Shrine, too, the Buddha often gave this Dhamma talk to the mendicants:

dn16:4.12.2.eng: “Such is ethics, such is immersion, such is wisdom.

dn16:4.12.3.eng: When immersion is imbued with ethics it’s very fruitful and beneficial.

dn16:4.12.4.eng: When wisdom is imbued with immersion it’s very fruitful and beneficial.

dn16:4.12.5.pli: Paññāparibhāvitaṃ cittaṃ sammadeva āsavehi vimuccati, seyyathidaṃ—
dn16:4.12.5.eng: When the mind is imbued with wisdom it is rightly freed from the defilements, namely,

dn16:4.12.6.eng: the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.”

dn16:4.13.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā bhoganagare yathābhirantaṃ viharitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
dn16:4.13.1.eng: When the Buddha had stayed in Bhoga City as long as he pleased, he addressed Ānanda,

dn16:4.13.2.comm: Pāvā, a town of the Mallas, has more significance for this narrative than appears at first sight. It was, according to Buddhist texts, the place where Mahāvīra had recently died, plunging the Jains into chaos. (The Jains, however, say this was another Pāvā, east of Nāḷandā.) Pāvā became associated with especially ascetic monks: thirty Pāvā monks became awakened on hearing a particularly strong discourse (SN 15.13); Mahākassapa heard the news of the Buddha’s passing at Pāvā; and monks from Pāvā allied with monks of “Avanti and the south” arguing for strict Vinaya in the Second Council (Kd 22:1.7.11.1).

dn16:4.13.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paccassosi.

dn16:4.13.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ yena pāvā tadavasari.
dn16:4.13.4.eng: Then the Buddha together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants arrived at Pāvā,

dn16:4.13.5.pli: Tatra sudaṃ bhagavā pāvāyaṃ viharati cundassa kammāraputtassa ambavane.
dn16:4.13.5.eng: where he stayed in Cunda the smith’s mango grove.
dn16:4.13.5.comm: Cunda was apparently a metal-worker, which was an advanced form of technological craftsmanship.

dn16:4.14.1.pli: Assosi kho cundo kammāraputto: “bhagavā kira pāvaṃ anuppatto, pāvāyaṃ viharati mayhaṃ ambavane”ti.
dn16:4.14.1.eng: Cunda heard that the Buddha had arrived and was staying in his mango grove.

dn16:4.14.2.pli: Atha kho cundo kammāraputto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
dn16:4.14.2.eng: Then he went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side.

dn16:4.14.3.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho cundaṃ kammāraputtaṃ bhagavā dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi.
dn16:4.14.3.eng: The Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired him with a Dhamma talk.
dn16:4.14.3.comm: This is, according to the commentary, preserved as the other discourse taught to Cunda, which deals with proper asceticism (Snp 1.5).

dn16:4.14.4.pli: Atha kho cundo kammāraputto bhagavatā dhammiyā kathāya sandassito samādapito samuttejito sampahaṃsito bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn16:4.14.4.eng: Then Cunda said to the Buddha,

dn16:4.15.1.pli: “adhivāsetu me, bhante, bhagavā svātanāya bhattaṃ saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghenā”ti.
dn16:4.15.1.eng: “Sir, may the Buddha together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me.”

dn16:4.16.1.pli: Atha kho cundo kammāraputto bhagavato adhivāsanaṃ viditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
dn16:4.16.1.eng: Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, Cunda got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.

dn16:4.17.1.pli: Atha kho cundo kammāraputto tassā rattiyā accayena sake nivesane paṇītaṃ khādanīyaṃ bhojanīyaṃ paṭiyādāpetvā pahūtañca sūkaramaddavaṃ bhagavato kālaṃ ārocāpesi:
dn16:4.17.1.eng: And when the night had passed Cunda had delicious fresh and cooked foods prepared in his own home, and plenty of pork on the turn. Then he had the Buddha informed of the time, saying,
dn16:4.17.1.comm: The exact meaning of sūkaramaddava is unclear. Sūkara is “pig”, but some Chinese translations suggest the sense “mushroom”; and it is true that there are several names of plants or plant dishes that begin with sūkara or other animals. At Dhp 377, flowers are described as maddava, meaning “overripe, withering on the vine”. It is a common practice to allow meat to sit for a while to become tender and “high” for extra flavor when cooked. But this can lead to a proliferation of dangerous bacteria unless properly cooked, and such seems to have been the case here. In any case, this disputed term is marginal in a consideration of meat-eating in early Buddhism, which is discussed more fully elsewhere.

dn16:4.17.2.eng: “Sir, it’s time. The meal is ready.”

dn16:4.18.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghena yena cundassa kammāraputtassa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
dn16:4.18.1.eng: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the home of Cunda together with the mendicant Saṅgha, where he sat on the seat spread out

dn16:4.18.2.pli: Nisajja kho bhagavā cundaṃ kammāraputtaṃ āmantesi:

dn16:4.18.3.pli: “yaṃ te, cunda, sūkaramaddavaṃ paṭiyattaṃ, tena maṃ parivisa.
dn16:4.18.3.eng: “Cunda, please serve me with the pork on the turn that you’ve prepared.
dn16:4.18.3.comm: If the Buddha knew the meal was dangerous, why ask to be served it? This is even more striking in light of the fact that it is a Vinaya offence to request fine food, including meat, and nowhere else is such a request recorded (Bu Pc 39:2.10.1). Such narrative ambiguities serve to escalate a sense of wonder.

dn16:4.18.4.pli: Yaṃ panaññaṃ khādanīyaṃ bhojanīyaṃ paṭiyattaṃ, tena bhikkhusaṅghaṃ parivisā”ti.
dn16:4.18.4.eng: And serve the mendicant Saṅgha with the other foods.”

dn16:4.18.5.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho cundo kammāraputto bhagavato paṭissutvā yaṃ ahosi sūkaramaddavaṃ paṭiyattaṃ, tena bhagavantaṃ parivisi.
dn16:4.18.5.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied Cunda, and did as he was asked.

dn16:4.18.6.pli: Yaṃ panaññaṃ khādanīyaṃ bhojanīyaṃ paṭiyattaṃ, tena bhikkhusaṅghaṃ parivisi.

dn16:4.19.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā cundaṃ kammāraputtaṃ āmantesi:

dn16:4.19.2.pli: “yaṃ te, cunda, sūkaramaddavaṃ avasiṭṭhaṃ, taṃ sobbhe nikhaṇāhi.
dn16:4.19.2.eng: “Cunda, any pork on the turn that’s left over, you should bury it in a pit.

dn16:4.19.3.pli: Nāhaṃ taṃ, cunda, passāmi sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya, yassa taṃ paribhuttaṃ sammā pariṇāmaṃ gaccheyya aññatra tathāgatassā”ti.
dn16:4.19.3.eng: I don’t see anyone in this world—with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—who could properly digest it except for the Realized One.”

dn16:4.19.4.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho cundo kammāraputto bhagavato paṭissutvā yaṃ ahosi sūkaramaddavaṃ avasiṭṭhaṃ, taṃ sobbhe nikhaṇitvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
dn16:4.19.4.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied Cunda. He did as he was asked, then came back to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side.

dn16:4.19.5.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho cundaṃ kammāraputtaṃ bhagavā dhammiyā kathāya sandassetvā samādapetvā samuttejetvā sampahaṃsetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi.
dn16:4.19.5.eng: Then the Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired him with a Dhamma talk, after which he got up from his seat and left.

dn16:4.20.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavato cundassa kammāraputtassa bhattaṃ bhuttāvissa kharo ābādho uppajji, lohitapakkhandikā pabāḷhā vedanā vattanti māraṇantikā.
dn16:4.20.1.eng: After the Buddha had eaten Cunda’s meal, he fell severely ill with bloody dysentery, struck by dreadful pains, close to death.
dn16:4.20.1.comm: The Buddha’s illness is sometimes diagnosed as mesenteric infarction. The Buddha’s body rejects the world of conditioned existence entirely.

dn16:4.20.2.pli: Tā sudaṃ bhagavā sato sampajāno adhivāsesi avihaññamāno.
dn16:4.20.2.eng: But he endured unbothered, with mindfulness and situational awareness.

dn16:4.20.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:

dn16:4.20.5.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paccassosi.

dn16:4.20.6.comm: The commentary says that these verses were added by the elders at the Council.

dn16:4.20.7.eng: the meal of Cunda the smith,

dn16:4.20.8.eng: the attentive one fell severely ill,

dn16:4.20.10.eng: A severe sickness struck the Teacher

dn16:4.20.11.eng: who had eaten the pork on the turn.

dn16:4.20.12.eng: While still purging the Buddha said:

dn16:4.20.13.eng: “I’ll go to the citadel of Kusinārā.”

dn16:4.21.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā maggā okkamma yena aññataraṃ rukkhamūlaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
dn16:4.21.1.eng: Then the Buddha left the road and went to the root of a certain tree, where he addressed Ānanda,

dn16:4.21.2.pli: “iṅgha me tvaṃ, ānanda, catugguṇaṃ saṅghāṭiṃ paññapehi, kilantosmi, ānanda, nisīdissāmī”ti.
dn16:4.21.2.eng: “Please, Ānanda, fold my outer robe in four and spread it out for me. I am tired and will sit down.”
dn16:4.21.2.comm: The saṅghāṭi (“outer robe” or “cloak”) is double-layered, and served both for warmth and as bedding. The Buddha has not recovered fully from his illness.

dn16:4.21.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paṭissutvā catugguṇaṃ saṅghāṭiṃ paññapesi.
dn16:4.21.3.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied Ānanda, and did as he was asked.

dn16:4.21.4.eng: The Buddha sat on the seat spread out.

dn16:4.22.1.pli: Nisajja kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
dn16:4.22.1.eng: When he was seated he said to Venerable Ānanda,

dn16:4.22.2.pli: “iṅgha me tvaṃ, ānanda, pānīyaṃ āhara, pipāsitosmi, ānanda, pivissāmī”ti.
dn16:4.22.2.eng: “Please, Ānanda, fetch me some water. I am thirsty and will drink.”
dn16:4.22.2.comm: The Buddha was an exemplary patient. He did not complain, but made his needs known clearly to his carer.

dn16:4.22.3.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn16:4.22.3.eng: When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha,

dn16:4.22.4.pli: “idāni, bhante, pañcamattāni sakaṭasatāni atikkantāni, taṃ cakkacchinnaṃ udakaṃ parittaṃ luḷitaṃ āvilaṃ sandati.
dn16:4.22.4.eng: “Sir, just now around five hundred carts have passed by. The shallow water has been churned up by their wheels, and it flows cloudy and murky.

dn16:4.22.5.pli: Ayaṃ, bhante, kakudhā nadī avidūre acchodakā sātodakā sītodakā setodakā suppatitthā ramaṇīyā.
dn16:4.22.5.eng: The Kakudhā river is not far away, with clear, sweet, cool water, clean, with smooth banks, delightful.

dn16:4.22.6.pli: Ettha bhagavā pānīyañca pivissati, gattāni ca sītī karissatī”ti.
dn16:4.22.6.eng: There the Buddha can drink and cool his limbs.”
dn16:4.22.6.comm: It would seem that, since the Buddha was enduring his illness without complaint and with dignity, Ānanda did not fully realize how weak he has become.

dn16:4.23.1.pli: Dutiyampi kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
dn16:4.23.1.eng: For a second time, the Buddha asked Ānanda for a drink,

dn16:4.23.2.pli: “iṅgha me tvaṃ, ānanda, pānīyaṃ āhara, pipāsitosmi, ānanda, pivissāmī”ti.

dn16:4.23.3.pli: Dutiyampi kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn16:4.23.3.eng: and for a second time Ānanda suggested going to the Kakudhā river.

dn16:4.23.4.pli: “idāni, bhante, pañcamattāni sakaṭasatāni atikkantāni, taṃ cakkacchinnaṃ udakaṃ parittaṃ luḷitaṃ āvilaṃ sandati.

dn16:4.23.5.pli: Ayaṃ, bhante, kakudhā nadī avidūre acchodakā sātodakā sītodakā setodakā suppatitthā ramaṇīyā.

dn16:4.23.6.pli: Ettha bhagavā pānīyañca pivissati, gattāni ca sītīkarissatī”ti.

dn16:4.24.1.pli: Tatiyampi kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
dn16:4.24.1.eng: And for a third time, the Buddha said to Ānanda,

dn16:4.24.2.pli: “iṅgha me tvaṃ, ānanda, pānīyaṃ āhara, pipāsitosmi, ānanda, pivissāmī”ti.
dn16:4.24.2.eng: “Please, Ānanda, fetch me some water. I am thirsty and will drink.”

dn16:4.24.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paṭissutvā pattaṃ gahetvā yena sā nadikā tenupasaṅkami.
dn16:4.24.3.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied Ānanda. Taking his bowl he went to the river.
dn16:4.24.3.comm: The bowl (patta) was used both for eating and drinking.

dn16:4.24.4.pli: Atha kho sā nadikā cakkacchinnā parittā luḷitā āvilā sandamānā, āyasmante ānande upasaṅkamante acchā vippasannā anāvilā sandittha.
dn16:4.24.4.eng: Now, though the shallow water in that creek had been churned up by wheels, and flowed cloudy and murky, when Ānanda approached it flowed transparent, clear, and unclouded.

dn16:4.25.2.pli: “acchariyaṃ vata bho, abbhutaṃ vata bho, tathāgatassa mahiddhikatā mahānubhāvatā.
dn16:4.25.2.eng: “Oh lord, how incredible, how amazing! The Realized One has such psychic power and might!

dn16:4.25.3.pli: Ayañhi sā nadikā cakkacchinnā parittā luḷitā āvilā sandamānā mayi upasaṅkamante acchā vippasannā anāvilā sandatī”ti.
dn16:4.25.3.eng: For though the shallow water in that creek had been churned up by wheels, and flowed cloudy and murky, when I approached it flowed transparent, clear, and unclouded.”

dn16:4.25.4.pli: Pattena pānīyaṃ ādāya yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn16:4.25.4.eng: Gathering a bowl of drinking water he went back to the Buddha, and said to him,

dn16:4.25.5.pli: “acchariyaṃ, bhante, abbhutaṃ, bhante, tathāgatassa mahiddhikatā mahānubhāvatā.
dn16:4.25.5.eng: “It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing! The Realized One has such psychic power and might!

dn16:4.25.6.pli: Idāni sā bhante nadikā cakkacchinnā parittā luḷitā āvilā sandamānā mayi upasaṅkamante acchā vippasannā anāvilā sandittha.
dn16:4.25.6.eng: Just now, though the shallow water in that creek had been churned up by wheels, and flowed cloudy and murky, when I approached it flowed transparent, clear, and unclouded.

dn16:4.25.7.pli: Pivatu bhagavā pānīyaṃ pivatu sugato pānīyan”ti.
dn16:4.25.7.eng: Drink the water, Blessed One! Drink the water, Holy One!”

dn16:4.25.8.eng: So the Buddha drank the water.

dn16:4.26.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena pukkuso mallaputto āḷārassa kālāmassa sāvako kusinārāya pāvaṃ addhānamaggappaṭipanno hoti.
dn16:4.26.1.eng: Now at that time Pukkusa the Malla, a disciple of Āḷāra Kālāma, was traveling along the road from Kusinārā to Pāvā.
dn16:4.26.1.comm: Pukkusa is not elsewhere mentioned. The reference to Āḷāra Kālāma recalls the narrative of the bodhisatta’s practices before awakening. There are several details that indicate the stories of the first part and the last part of the Buddha’s life were unified by such callbacks. We meet the Malla clan later on.

dn16:4.26.2.pli: Addasā kho pukkuso mallaputto bhagavantaṃ aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle nisinnaṃ.
dn16:4.26.2.eng: He saw the Buddha sitting at the root of a certain tree.

dn16:4.26.3.pli: Disvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho pukkuso mallaputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn16:4.26.3.eng: He went up to him, bowed, sat down to one side, and said,

dn16:4.26.4.pli: “acchariyaṃ, bhante, abbhutaṃ, bhante, santena vata, bhante, pabbajitā vihārena viharanti.
dn16:4.26.4.eng: “It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing! Those who have gone forth remain in such peaceful meditations.

dn16:4.27.1.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, bhante, āḷāro kālāmo addhānamaggappaṭipanno maggā okkamma avidūre aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle divāvihāraṃ nisīdi.
dn16:4.27.1.eng: Once it so happened that Āḷāra Kālāma, while traveling along a road, left the road and sat at the root of a nearby tree for the day’s meditation.

dn16:4.27.2.pli: Atha kho, bhante, pañcamattāni sakaṭasatāni āḷāraṃ kālāmaṃ nissāya nissāya atikkamiṃsu.
dn16:4.27.2.eng: Then around five hundred carts passed by right beside Āḷāra Kālāma.
dn16:4.27.2.comm: Niśraya in the sense of “near” occurs at Śatapathabrāhmaṇa 3.1.2.17.

dn16:4.27.3.pli: Atha kho, bhante, aññataro puriso tassa sakaṭasatthassa piṭṭhito piṭṭhito āgacchanto yena āḷāro kālāmo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āḷāraṃ kālāmaṃ etadavoca:
dn16:4.27.3.eng: Then a certain person coming behind those carts went up to Āḷāra Kālāma and said to him:

dn16:4.27.4.eng: ‘Sir, didn’t you see the five hundred carts pass by?’
dn16:4.27.4.comm: In deep meditation the senses cease to function.

dn16:4.27.6.eng: ‘But sir, didn’t you hear a sound?’

dn16:4.27.7.eng: ‘No, friend, I didn’t hear a sound.’

dn16:4.27.12.pli: ‘So tvaṃ, bhante, saññī samāno jāgaro pañcamattāni sakaṭasatāni nissāya nissāya atikkantāni neva addasa, na pana saddaṃ assosi;
dn16:4.27.12.eng: ‘So, sir, while conscious and awake you neither saw nor heard a sound as five hundred carts passed by right beside you?

dn16:4.27.13.pli: apisu te, bhante, saṅghāṭi rajena okiṇṇā’ti?
dn16:4.27.13.eng: Why sir, even your outer robe is covered with dust!’

dn16:4.27.15.pli: Atha kho, bhante, tassa purisassa etadahosi:

dn16:4.27.16.pli: ‘acchariyaṃ vata bho, abbhutaṃ vata bho, santena vata bho pabbajitā vihārena viharanti.
dn16:4.27.16.eng: ‘Oh lord, how incredible, how amazing! Those who have gone forth remain in such peaceful meditations,

dn16:4.27.17.pli: Yatra hi nāma saññī samāno jāgaro pañcamattāni sakaṭasatāni nissāya nissāya atikkantāni neva dakkhati, na pana saddaṃ sossatī’ti.
dn16:4.27.17.eng: in that, while conscious and awake he neither saw nor heard a sound as five hundred carts passed by right next to him.’

dn16:4.27.18.pli: Āḷāre kālāme uḷāraṃ pasādaṃ pavedetvā pakkāmī”ti.
dn16:4.27.18.eng: And after declaring his lofty confidence in Āḷāra Kālāma, he left.”

dn16:4.28.2.pli: katamaṃ nu kho dukkarataraṃ vā durabhisambhavataraṃ vā—
dn16:4.28.2.eng: Which is harder and more challenging to do while conscious and awake:

dn16:4.28.3.pli: yo vā saññī samāno jāgaro pañcamattāni sakaṭasatāni nissāya nissāya atikkantāni neva passeyya, na pana saddaṃ suṇeyya;
dn16:4.28.3.eng: to neither see nor hear a sound as five hundred carts pass by right next to you?

dn16:4.28.4.pli: yo vā saññī samāno jāgaro deve vassante deve gaḷagaḷāyante vijjullatāsu niccharantīsu asaniyā phalantiyā neva passeyya, na pana saddaṃ suṇeyyā”ti?
dn16:4.28.4.eng: Or to neither see nor hear a sound as the heavens are raining and pouring, lightning’s flashing, and thunder’s cracking?”

dn16:4.29.1.pli: “Kiñhi, bhante, karissanti pañca vā sakaṭasatāni cha vā sakaṭasatāni satta vā sakaṭasatāni aṭṭha vā sakaṭasatāni nava vā sakaṭasatāni, sakaṭasahassaṃ vā sakaṭasatasahassaṃ vā.
dn16:4.29.1.eng: “What do five hundred carts matter, or six hundred, or seven hundred, or eight hundred, or nine hundred, or a thousand, or even a hundred thousand carts?

dn16:4.29.2.pli: Atha kho etadeva dukkaratarañceva durabhisambhavatarañca yo saññī samāno jāgaro deve vassante deve gaḷagaḷāyante vijjullatāsu niccharantīsu asaniyā phalantiyā neva passeyya, na pana saddaṃ suṇeyyā”ti.
dn16:4.29.2.eng: It’s far harder and more challenging to neither see nor hear a sound as the heavens are raining and pouring, lightning’s flashing, and thunder’s cracking!”

dn16:4.30.1.eng: “This one time, Pukkusa, I was staying near Ātumā in a threshing-hut.
dn16:4.30.1.comm: A nearby town where the Buddha had stayed previously (Kd 1:37.4.2).

dn16:4.30.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena deve vassante deve gaḷagaḷāyante vijjullatāsu niccharantīsu asaniyā phalantiyā avidūre bhusāgārassa dve kassakā bhātaro hatā cattāro ca balibaddā.
dn16:4.30.2.eng: At that time the heavens were raining and pouring, lightning was flashing, and thunder was cracking. And not far from the threshing-hut two farmers who were brothers were killed, as well as four oxen.

dn16:4.30.3.pli: Atha kho, pukkusa, ātumāya mahājanakāyo nikkhamitvā yena te dve kassakā bhātaro hatā cattāro ca balibaddā tenupasaṅkami.
dn16:4.30.3.eng: Then a large crowd came from Ātumā to the place where that happened.

dn16:4.31.1.pli: Tena kho panāhaṃ, pukkusa, samayena bhusāgārā nikkhamitvā bhusāgāradvāre abbhokāse caṅkamāmi.
dn16:4.31.1.eng: Now at that time I came out of the threshing-hut and was walking mindfully in the open near the door of the hut.

dn16:4.31.2.pli: Atha kho, pukkusa, aññataro puriso tamhā mahājanakāyā yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā maṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitaṃ kho ahaṃ, pukkusa, taṃ purisaṃ etadavocaṃ:
dn16:4.31.2.eng: Then having left that crowd, a certain person approached me, bowed, and stood to one side. I said to them,

dn16:4.32.1.pli: ‘kiṃ nu kho eso, āvuso, mahājanakāyo sannipatito’ti?

dn16:4.32.2.pli: ‘Idāni, bhante, deve vassante deve gaḷagaḷāyante vijjullatāsu niccharantīsu asaniyā phalantiyā dve kassakā bhātaro hatā cattāro ca balibaddā.
dn16:4.32.2.eng: ‘Just now, sir, the heavens were raining and pouring, lightning was flashing, and thunder was cracking. And two farmers who were brothers were killed, as well as four oxen.

dn16:4.32.8.eng: ‘But sir, didn’t you hear a sound?’

dn16:4.32.9.eng: ‘No, friend, I didn’t hear a sound.’

dn16:4.32.14.pli: ‘So tvaṃ, bhante, saññī samāno jāgaro deve vassante deve gaḷagaḷāyante vijjullatāsu niccharantīsu asaniyā phalantiyā neva addasa, na pana saddaṃ assosī’ti?
dn16:4.32.14.eng: ‘So, sir, while conscious and awake you neither saw nor heard a sound as the heavens were raining and pouring, lightning was flashing, and thunder was cracking?’

dn16:4.33.1.pli: Atha kho, pukkusa, tassa purisassa etadahosi:

dn16:4.33.2.pli: ‘acchariyaṃ vata bho, abbhutaṃ vata bho, santena vata bho pabbajitā vihārena viharanti.
dn16:4.33.2.eng: ‘Oh lord, how incredible, how amazing! Those who have gone forth remain in such peaceful meditations,

dn16:4.33.3.pli: Yatra hi nāma saññī samāno jāgaro deve vassante deve gaḷagaḷāyante vijjullatāsu niccharantīsu asaniyā phalantiyā neva dakkhati, na pana saddaṃ sossatī’ti.
dn16:4.33.3.eng: in that, while conscious and awake he neither saw nor heard a sound as the heavens were raining and pouring, lightning was flashing, and thunder was cracking.’

dn16:4.33.4.pli: Mayi uḷāraṃ pasādaṃ pavedetvā maṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmī”ti.
dn16:4.33.4.eng: And after declaring their lofty confidence in me, they bowed and respectfully circled me, keeping me on their right, before leaving.”

dn16:4.34.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, pukkuso mallaputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn16:4.34.1.eng: When he said this, Pukkusa said to him,

dn16:4.34.2.pli: “esāhaṃ, bhante, yo me āḷāre kālāme pasādo taṃ mahāvāte vā ophuṇāmi sīghasotāya vā nadiyā pavāhemi.
dn16:4.34.2.eng: “Any confidence I had in Āḷāra Kālāma I whisk away as in a strong wind, or glide away as down a swift stream.

dn16:4.34.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṃ bhagavatā anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
dn16:4.34.4.eng: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, the Buddha has made the teaching clear in many ways.

dn16:4.34.5.pli: Esāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
dn16:4.34.5.eng: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

dn16:4.34.6.pli: Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
dn16:4.34.6.eng: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

dn16:4.35.1.pli: Atha kho pukkuso mallaputto aññataraṃ purisaṃ āmantesi:
dn16:4.35.1.eng: Then Pukkusa addressed a certain man,

dn16:4.35.2.pli: “iṅgha me tvaṃ, bhaṇe, siṅgīvaṇṇaṃ yugamaṭṭhaṃ dhāraṇīyaṃ āharā”ti.
dn16:4.35.2.eng: “Please, my man, fetch a pair of ready to wear garments the color of mountain gold.”
dn16:4.35.2.comm: Siṅgīvaṇṇa, or else siṅgīsuvaṇṇa (AN 3.70:38.3), is gold from a mountain peak (siṅgī). Kauṭilya mentions a form of gold that is śṛṅgaśūktija, “occurring on mount Śūkti” (Arthaśāstra 2.13.3). The commentary to that passage says it had the color of red arsenic, so it would have been a rose gold color.

dn16:4.35.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho so puriso pukkusassa mallaputtassa paṭissutvā taṃ siṅgīvaṇṇaṃ yugamaṭṭhaṃ dhāraṇīyaṃ āhari.
dn16:4.35.3.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied that man, and did as he was asked.

dn16:4.35.4.pli: Atha kho pukkuso mallaputto taṃ siṅgīvaṇṇaṃ yugamaṭṭhaṃ dhāraṇīyaṃ bhagavato upanāmesi:
dn16:4.35.4.eng: Then Pukkusa brought the garments to the Buddha,

dn16:4.35.5.pli: “idaṃ, bhante, siṅgīvaṇṇaṃ yugamaṭṭhaṃ dhāraṇīyaṃ, taṃ me bhagavā paṭiggaṇhātu anukampaṃ upādāyā”ti.
dn16:4.35.5.eng: “Sir, please accept this pair of ready to wear garments the color of mountain gold from me out of sympathy.”

dn16:4.35.6.pli: “Tena hi, pukkusa, ekena maṃ acchādehi, ekena ānandan”ti.
dn16:4.35.6.eng: “Well then, Pukkusa, clothe me in one, and Ānanda in the other.”

dn16:4.35.7.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho pukkuso mallaputto bhagavato paṭissutvā ekena bhagavantaṃ acchādeti, ekena āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ.
dn16:4.35.7.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied Pukkusa, and did so.

dn16:4.36.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pukkusaṃ mallaputtaṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi.
dn16:4.36.1.eng: Then the Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired Pukkusa the Malla with a Dhamma talk,

dn16:4.36.2.pli: Atha kho pukkuso mallaputto bhagavatā dhammiyā kathāya sandassito samādapito samuttejito sampahaṃsito uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
dn16:4.36.2.eng: after which he got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha before leaving.

dn16:4.37.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando acirapakkante pukkuse mallaputte taṃ siṅgīvaṇṇaṃ yugamaṭṭhaṃ dhāraṇīyaṃ bhagavato kāyaṃ upanāmesi.
dn16:4.37.1.eng: Then, not long after Pukkusa had left, Ānanda placed the pair of garments the color of mountain gold by the Buddha’s body.

dn16:4.37.2.pli: Taṃ bhagavato kāyaṃ upanāmitaṃ hataccikaṃ viya khāyati.
dn16:4.37.2.eng: But when placed by the Buddha’s body they seemed to lose their shine.

dn16:4.37.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn16:4.37.3.eng: Then Ānanda said to the Buddha,

dn16:4.37.4.pli: “acchariyaṃ, bhante, abbhutaṃ, bhante, yāva parisuddho, bhante, tathāgatassa chavivaṇṇo pariyodāto.
dn16:4.37.4.eng: “It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing, how pure and bright is the color of the Realized One’s skin.

dn16:4.37.5.pli: Idaṃ, bhante, siṅgīvaṇṇaṃ yugamaṭṭhaṃ dhāraṇīyaṃ bhagavato kāyaṃ upanāmitaṃ hataccikaṃ viya khāyatī”ti.
dn16:4.37.5.eng: When this pair of ready to wear garments the color of mountain gold is placed by the Buddha’s body they seem to lose their sheen.”

dn16:4.37.6.pli: “Evametaṃ, ānanda, evametaṃ, ānanda, dvīsu kālesu ativiya tathāgatassa kāyo parisuddho hoti chavivaṇṇo pariyodāto.
dn16:4.37.6.eng: “That’s so true, Ānanda, that’s so true! There are two times when the color of the Realized One’s skin becomes extra pure and bright.

dn16:4.38.2.pli: Yañca, ānanda, rattiṃ tathāgato anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambujjhati, yañca rattiṃ anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāyati.
dn16:4.38.2.eng: The night when a Realized One awakens to the supreme perfect awakening; and the night he becomes fully extinguished in the element of extinguishment with no residue.
dn16:4.38.2.comm: Closing the narrative circle with the story of awakening.

dn16:4.38.3.pli: Imesu kho, ānanda, dvīsu kālesu ativiya tathāgatassa kāyo parisuddho hoti chavivaṇṇo pariyodāto.
dn16:4.38.3.eng: These are the are two times when the color of the Realized One’s skin becomes extra pure and bright.

dn16:4.38.4.pli: Ajja kho panānanda, rattiyā pacchime yāme kusinārāyaṃ upavattane mallānaṃ sālavane antarena yamakasālānaṃ tathāgatassa parinibbānaṃ bhavissati.
dn16:4.38.4.eng: Today, Ānanda, in the last watch of the night, between a pair of sal trees in the sal forest of the Mallas at Upavattana near Kusinārā, shall be the Realized One’s full extinguishment.

dn16:4.38.5.eng: Come, Ānanda, let’s go to the Kakudhā River.”

dn16:4.38.6.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paccassosi.

dn16:4.38.7.eng: A pair of garments the color of mountain gold
dn16:4.38.7.comm: The commentary says this verse was added by the senior monks at the Council.

dn16:4.38.9.eng: when the teacher was clothed with them,

dn16:4.38.10.eng: his snow gold skin glowed bright.

dn16:4.39.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ yena kakudhā nadī tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā kakudhaṃ nadiṃ ajjhogāhetvā nhatvā ca pivitvā ca paccuttaritvā yena ambavanaṃ tenupasaṅkami.
dn16:4.39.1.eng: Then the Buddha together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants went to the Kakudhā River. He plunged into the river and bathed and drank. And when he had emerged, he went to the mango grove,

dn16:4.39.2.comm: The monk Cundaka makes an abrupt appearance here; this is the only mention of this name. The commentary to this passage calls him cunda, while the gloss to the parallel passage at Ud 8.5:14.3 has cundaka throughout. The diminutive ending -ka is perhaps meant to differentiate him from the smith Cunda. There are various Cundas whose connection is unclear. Mahācunda was one of the great disciples (MN 118:, AN 6.17, MN 8), who later brought the Dhamma to the land of the Cetīs (AN 6.46, AN 10.24). He once stayed with Channa and Sāriputta (MN 144:4.1, SN 35.87:1.2); the commentaries say he was in fact Sāriputta’s younger brother. They also identify him with the “novice Cunda” who reported the deaths of Sāriputta (SN 47.13:1.3) and Mahāvīra (DN 29:2.1, MN 104:3.1), explaining that the title “novice” was a nickname that persisted from the time he ordained as a young novice. It is unclear whether the commentaries take the Cundaka of this passage to be the same person, but he is here performing a similar role as carer adjacent to the Buddha’s death. Later there appears a Cūḷacunda (Tha Ap 52:13.3). Thus there may have been one person known by different names, or several people whose stories have become conflated.

dn16:4.39.3.pli: “iṅgha me tvaṃ, cundaka, catugguṇaṃ saṅghāṭiṃ paññapehi, kilantosmi, cundaka, nipajjissāmī”ti.
dn16:4.39.3.eng: “Please, Cundaka, fold my outer robe in four and spread it out for me. I am tired and will lie down.”

dn16:4.40.1.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā cundako bhagavato paṭissutvā catugguṇaṃ saṅghāṭiṃ paññapesi.
dn16:4.40.1.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied Cundaka, and did as he was asked.

dn16:4.40.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā dakkhiṇena passena sīhaseyyaṃ kappesi pāde pādaṃ accādhāya sato sampajāno uṭṭhānasaññaṃ manasikaritvā.
dn16:4.40.2.eng: And then the Buddha laid down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware, and focused on the time of getting up.

dn16:4.40.3.pli: Āyasmā pana cundako tattheva bhagavato purato nisīdi.
dn16:4.40.3.eng: But Cundaka sat down right there in front of the Buddha.

dn16:4.41.1.comm: These verses were also added at the Council according to the commentary.

dn16:4.41.2.eng: whose water was transparent, sweet, and clear,

dn16:4.41.3.eng: the Teacher, being tired, plunged in,

dn16:4.41.4.eng: the Realized One, without compare in the world.

dn16:4.41.5.eng: And after bathing and drinking the Teacher emerged.

dn16:4.41.6.eng: Before the group of mendicants, in the middle, <j>the Buddha,

dn16:4.41.7.eng: the Teacher <j>who rolled forth the present dispensation,
dn16:4.41.7.comm: Adopt PTS and BJT reading satthā pavattā.

dn16:4.41.8.eng: the great seer went to the mango grove.

dn16:4.41.9.eng: He addressed the mendicant named Cundaka:

dn16:4.41.10.eng: “Spread out my folded robe so I can lie down.”

dn16:4.41.12.eng: who quickly spread the folded robe.

dn16:4.41.13.eng: The Teacher lay down so tired,

dn16:4.41.14.eng: while Cunda sat there before him.

dn16:4.42.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
dn16:4.42.1.eng: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Ānanda:

dn16:4.42.2.pli: “siyā kho panānanda, cundassa kammāraputtassa koci vippaṭisāraṃ uppādeyya:
dn16:4.42.2.eng: “Now it may happen, Ānanda, that someone may give rise to regret in Cunda the smith:

dn16:4.42.3.pli: ‘tassa te, āvuso cunda, alābhā tassa te dulladdhaṃ, yassa te tathāgato pacchimaṃ piṇḍapātaṃ paribhuñjitvā parinibbuto’ti.
dn16:4.42.3.eng: ‘It’s your loss, respected Cunda, it’s your misfortune, in that the Realized One was fully quenched after eating his last almsmeal from you.’
dn16:4.42.3.comm: The text addresses Cunda with the respectful āvuso.

dn16:4.42.4.pli: Cundassa, ānanda, kammāraputtassa evaṃ vippaṭisāro paṭivinetabbo:
dn16:4.42.4.eng: You should dispel remorse in Cunda the smith like this:

dn16:4.42.5.pli: ‘tassa te, āvuso cunda, lābhā tassa te suladdhaṃ,
dn16:4.42.5.eng: ‘You’re fortunate, respected Cunda, you’re so very fortunate,

dn16:4.42.6.pli: yassa te tathāgato pacchimaṃ piṇḍapātaṃ paribhuñjitvā parinibbuto.
dn16:4.42.6.eng: in that the Realized One was fully quenched after eating his last almsmeal from you.

dn16:4.42.7.pli: Sammukhā metaṃ, āvuso cunda, bhagavato sutaṃ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṃ:
dn16:4.42.7.eng: I have heard and learned this in the presence of the Buddha.

dn16:4.42.8.pli: dveme piṇḍapātā samasamaphalā samavipākā, ativiya aññehi piṇḍapātehi mahapphalatarā ca mahānisaṃsatarā ca.
dn16:4.42.8.eng: There are two almsmeal offerings that have identical fruit and result, and are more fruitful and beneficial than other almsmeal offerings.

dn16:4.42.10.pli: Yañca piṇḍapātaṃ paribhuñjitvā tathāgato anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambujjhati, yañca piṇḍapātaṃ paribhuñjitvā tathāgato anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāyati.
dn16:4.42.10.eng: The almsmeal after eating which a Realized One awakens to the supreme perfect awakening; and the almsmeal after eating which he becomes fully extinguished in the element of extinguishment with no residue.

dn16:4.42.11.pli: Ime dve piṇḍapātā samasamaphalā samavipākā, ativiya aññehi piṇḍapātehi mahapphalatarā ca mahānisaṃsatarā ca.
dn16:4.42.11.eng: These two almsmeal offerings have identical fruit and result, and are more fruitful and beneficial than other almsmeal offerings.

dn16:4.42.12.pli: Āyusaṃvattanikaṃ āyasmatā cundena kammāraputtena kammaṃ upacitaṃ, vaṇṇasaṃvattanikaṃ āyasmatā cundena kammāraputtena kammaṃ upacitaṃ, sukhasaṃvattanikaṃ āyasmatā cundena kammāraputtena kammaṃ upacitaṃ, yasasaṃvattanikaṃ āyasmatā cundena kammāraputtena kammaṃ upacitaṃ, saggasaṃvattanikaṃ āyasmatā cundena kammāraputtena kammaṃ upacitaṃ, ādhipateyyasaṃvattanikaṃ āyasmatā cundena kammāraputtena kammaṃ upacitan’ti.
dn16:4.42.12.eng: You’ve accumulated a deed that leads to long life, beauty, happiness, fame, heaven, and sovereignty.’
dn16:4.42.12.comm: The text uses āyasmā here for Cunda, as does the Sanskrit, whereas it is normally reserved for mendicants (see below, DN 16:6.2.1).

dn16:4.42.13.pli: Cundassa, ānanda, kammāraputtassa evaṃ vippaṭisāro paṭivinetabbo”ti.
dn16:4.42.13.eng: That’s how you should dispel remorse in Cunda the smith.”

dn16:4.43.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
dn16:4.43.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:

dn16:4.43.2.comm: This became a point of discussion in later Buddhism: can it be that the merit of a gift grows after it is given?

dn16:4.43.3.eng: enmity doesn’t build up when you have self-control.

dn16:4.43.4.eng: A skillful person gives up bad things—

dn16:4.43.5.eng: with the end of greed, hate, and delusion, <j>they’re quenched.”

dn16:5.1.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
dn16:5.1.1.eng: Then the Buddha said to Ānanda,

dn16:5.1.2.pli: “āyāmānanda, yena hiraññavatiyā nadiyā pārimaṃ tīraṃ, yena kusinārā upavattanaṃ mallānaṃ sālavanaṃ tenupasaṅkamissāmā”ti.
dn16:5.1.2.eng: “Come, Ānanda, let’s go to the far shore of the Golden River, and on to the sal forest of the Mallas at Upavattana near Kusinārā.”
dn16:5.1.2.comm: Known today as Kushinagar, it is a popular site for pilgrims, with many ancient stupas, Buddha images, and a peaceful park for meditation.

dn16:5.1.3.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paccassosi.

dn16:5.1.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ yena hiraññavatiyā nadiyā pārimaṃ tīraṃ, yena kusinārā upavattanaṃ mallānaṃ sālavanaṃ tenupasaṅkami. upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
dn16:5.1.4.eng: And that’s where they went. Then the Buddha addressed Ānanda,

dn16:5.1.5.pli: “iṅgha me tvaṃ, ānanda, antarena yamakasālānaṃ uttarasīsakaṃ mañcakaṃ paññapehi, kilantosmi, ānanda, nipajjissāmī”ti.
dn16:5.1.5.eng: “Please, Ānanda, set up a cot for me between the twin sal trees, with my head to the north. I am tired and will lie down.”

dn16:5.1.6.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paṭissutvā antarena yamakasālānaṃ uttarasīsakaṃ mañcakaṃ paññapesi.
dn16:5.1.6.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied Ānanda, and did as he was asked.

dn16:5.1.7.pli: Atha kho bhagavā dakkhiṇena passena sīhaseyyaṃ kappesi pāde pādaṃ accādhāya sato sampajāno.
dn16:5.1.7.eng: And then the Buddha laid down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware.
dn16:5.1.7.comm: Normally when the Buddha lies down, his mind is focused on getting up. But now he knows that he will not rise again.

dn16:5.2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena yamakasālā sabbaphāliphullā honti akālapupphehi.
dn16:5.2.1.eng: Now at that time the twin sal trees were in full blossom with flowers out of season.
dn16:5.2.1.comm: Sal trees blossom in April/May. This detail agrees with the Buddha’s final extinguishment in December/January, rather than in May (Vesak) as is currently celebrated (see note to DN 16:3.9.3).

dn16:5.2.2.pli: Te tathāgatassa sarīraṃ okiranti ajjhokiranti abhippakiranti tathāgatassa pūjāya.
dn16:5.2.2.eng: They sprinkled and bestrewed the Realized One’s body in honor of the Realized One.

dn16:5.2.3.pli: Dibbānipi mandāravapupphāni antalikkhā papatanti, tāni tathāgatassa sarīraṃ okiranti ajjhokiranti abhippakiranti tathāgatassa pūjāya.
dn16:5.2.3.eng: And the flowers of the heavenly Flame Tree fell from the sky, and they too sprinkled and bestrewed the Realized One’s body in honor of the Realized One.

dn16:5.2.4.pli: Dibbānipi candanacuṇṇāni antalikkhā papatanti, tāni tathāgatassa sarīraṃ okiranti ajjhokiranti abhippakiranti tathāgatassa pūjāya.
dn16:5.2.4.eng: And heavenly sandalwood powder fell from the sky, and it too sprinkled and bestrewed the Realized One’s body in honor of the Realized One.

dn16:5.2.5.pli: Dibbānipi tūriyāni antalikkhe vajjanti tathāgatassa pūjāya.
dn16:5.2.5.eng: And heavenly music played in midair in honor of the Realized One.

dn16:5.2.6.pli: Dibbānipi saṅgītāni antalikkhe vattanti tathāgatassa pūjāya.
dn16:5.2.6.eng: And heavenly choirs sang in midair in honor of the Realized One.

dn16:5.3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
dn16:5.3.1.eng: Then the Buddha pointed out to Ānanda what was happening, adding:

dn16:5.3.3.pli: Te tathāgatassa sarīraṃ okiranti ajjhokiranti abhippakiranti tathāgatassa pūjāya.

dn16:5.3.4.pli: Dibbānipi mandāravapupphāni antalikkhā papatanti, tāni tathāgatassa sarīraṃ okiranti ajjhokiranti abhippakiranti tathāgatassa pūjāya.

dn16:5.3.5.pli: Dibbānipi candanacuṇṇāni antalikkhā papatanti, tāni tathāgatassa sarīraṃ okiranti ajjhokiranti abhippakiranti tathāgatassa pūjāya.

dn16:5.3.6.pli: Dibbānipi tūriyāni antalikkhe vajjanti tathāgatassa pūjāya.

dn16:5.3.7.pli: Dibbānipi saṅgītāni antalikkhe vattanti tathāgatassa pūjāya.

dn16:5.3.8.pli: Na kho, ānanda, ettāvatā tathāgato sakkato vā hoti garukato vā mānito vā pūjito vā apacito vā.
dn16:5.3.8.eng: “That’s not the full extent of how the Realized One is honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed.

dn16:5.3.9.pli: Yo kho, ānanda, bhikkhu vā bhikkhunī vā upāsako vā upāsikā vā dhammānudhammappaṭipanno viharati sāmīcippaṭipanno anudhammacārī, so tathāgataṃ sakkaroti garuṃ karoti māneti pūjeti apaciyati, paramāya pūjāya.
dn16:5.3.9.eng: Any monk or nun or male or female lay follower who practices in line with the teaching, practicing properly, living in line with the teaching—they honor, respect, revere, venerate, and esteem the Realized One with the highest honor.
dn16:5.3.9.comm: This calls back to the description of the fourfold assembly in the Māra section above (DN 16:3.7.4).

dn16:5.3.10.eng: So Ānanda, you should train like this: ‘We shall practice in line with the teaching, practicing properly, living in line with the teaching.’”
dn16:5.3.10.comm: This kind of narrative elevation is characteristic of the Buddha’s teaching. He did not try to deny or eliminate any belief in the miraculous, or in the power of devotion, but rather to show that such things were of limited worth compared with practice.

dn16:5.4.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā upavāṇo bhagavato purato ṭhito hoti bhagavantaṃ bījayamāno.
dn16:5.4.1.eng: Now at that time Venerable Upavāṇa was standing in front of the Buddha fanning him.
dn16:5.4.1.comm: Like Cundaka above, Upavāṇa shares the duties of an attendant with Ānanda; at DN 29:41.1 he is also fanning the Buddha. At AN 5.166, Ānanda goes to Upavāṇa for support when he feels he has disappointed the Buddha.

dn16:5.4.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ upavāṇaṃ apasāresi:
dn16:5.4.2.eng: Then the Buddha made him move,

dn16:5.4.3.eng: “Move over, mendicant, don’t stand in front of me.”

dn16:5.4.5.pli: “ayaṃ kho āyasmā upavāṇo dīgharattaṃ bhagavato upaṭṭhāko santikāvacaro samīpacārī.
dn16:5.4.5.eng: “This Venerable Upavāṇa has been the Buddha’s attendant for a long time, close to him, living in his presence.
dn16:5.4.5.comm: In SN 7.13 Upavāna fetched hot water and molasses for the Buddha, an event he remembered in his own verses at Thag 2.33.

dn16:5.4.6.pli: Atha ca pana bhagavā pacchime kāle āyasmantaṃ upavāṇaṃ apasāreti:
dn16:5.4.6.eng: Yet in his final hour the Buddha makes him move, saying:

dn16:5.4.7.eng: ‘Move over, mendicant, don’t stand in front of me.’

dn16:5.4.8.pli: Ko nu kho hetu, ko paccayo, yaṃ bhagavā āyasmantaṃ upavāṇaṃ apasāreti:
dn16:5.4.8.eng: What is the cause, what is the reason for this?”

dn16:5.5.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn16:5.5.1.eng: Then Ānanda said to the Buddha,

dn16:5.5.2.pli: “ayaṃ, bhante, āyasmā upavāṇo dīgharattaṃ bhagavato upaṭṭhāko santikāvacaro samīpacārī.
dn16:5.5.2.eng: “This Venerable Upavāṇa has been the Buddha’s attendant for a long time, close to him, living in his presence.

dn16:5.5.3.pli: Atha ca pana bhagavā pacchime kāle āyasmantaṃ upavāṇaṃ apasāreti:
dn16:5.5.3.eng: Yet in his final hour the Buddha makes him move, saying:

dn16:5.5.4.eng: ‘Move over, mendicant, don’t stand in front of me.’

dn16:5.5.5.pli: Ko nu kho, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo, yaṃ bhagavā āyasmantaṃ upavāṇaṃ apasāreti:
dn16:5.5.5.eng: What is the cause, sir, what is the reason for this?”

dn16:5.5.7.pli: “Yebhuyyena, ānanda, dasasu lokadhātūsu devatā sannipatitā tathāgataṃ dassanāya.
dn16:5.5.7.eng: “Most of the deities from ten solar systems have gathered to see the Realized One.

dn16:5.5.8.pli: Yāvatā, ānanda, kusinārā upavattanaṃ mallānaṃ sālavanaṃ samantato dvādasa yojanāni, natthi so padeso vālaggakoṭinittudanamattopi mahesakkhāhi devatāhi apphuṭo.
dn16:5.5.8.eng: For twelve leagues all around this sal grove there’s no spot, not even a fraction of a hair’s tip, that’s not crowded full of illustrious deities.
dn16:5.5.8.comm: For this usage of phuṭo, see AN 3.56:1.3.

dn16:5.5.10.eng: ‘We’ve come such a long way to see the Realized One!

dn16:5.5.11.pli: Kadāci karahaci tathāgatā loke uppajjanti arahanto sammāsambuddhā.
dn16:5.5.11.eng: Only rarely do Realized Ones arise in the world, perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas.

dn16:5.5.12.pli: Ajjeva rattiyā pacchime yāme tathāgatassa parinibbānaṃ bhavissati.
dn16:5.5.12.eng: This very day, in the last watch of the night, the Realized One will be fully extinguished.

dn16:5.5.13.pli: Ayañca mahesakkho bhikkhu bhagavato purato ṭhito ovārento, na mayaṃ labhāma pacchime kāle tathāgataṃ dassanāyā’”ti.
dn16:5.5.13.eng: And this illustrious mendicant is standing in front of the Buddha blocking the view. We won’t get to see the Realized One in his final hour!’”
