dn16:5.6.1.eng: “But sir, what kind of deities are you thinking of?”

dn16:5.6.2.pli: “Santānanda, devatā ākāse pathavīsaññiniyo kese pakiriya kandanti, bāhā paggayha kandanti, chinnapātaṃ papatanti, āvaṭṭanti, vivaṭṭanti:
dn16:5.6.2.eng: “There are, Ānanda, deities—both in space and on the earth—who are aware of the earth. With hair disheveled and arms raised, they fall down like their feet were chopped off, rolling back and forth, lamenting:
dn16:5.6.2.comm: Elsewhere, pathavīsaññī refers to those who develop a form of meditation where they are “percipient of earth” (AN 10.6:1.2). Here, however, it simply means those deities who are aware of events on the ground. | Read chinnaṁpādaṁ viya papatanti.

dn16:5.6.3.pli: ‘atikhippaṃ bhagavā parinibbāyissati, atikhippaṃ sugato parinibbāyissati, atikhippaṃ cakkhuṃ loke antaradhāyissatī’ti.
dn16:5.6.3.eng: ‘Too soon the Blessed One will be fully extinguished! Too soon the Holy One will be fully extinguished! Too soon the Eye of the World will vanish!’
dn16:5.6.3.comm: The Buddha as “eye” evokes the common (eg. Rig Veda 1.164.14, 5.40.8, 5.59.5, 10.10.9) Vedic image of the Sun as the “eye of all” (viśvacakṣāḥ, 7.63.1), the “eye” for “eyes to see” (10.158.4), moving as an unaging wheel through the sky (1.164.14). See Snp 3.9:11.1 = MN 98:7.23. | Pali has cakkhuṁ loke (“eye in the world”), Sanskrit has cakṣur lokasya (“eye of the world”).

dn16:5.6.4.pli: Santānanda, devatā pathaviyaṃ pathavīsaññiniyo kese pakiriya kandanti, bāhā paggayha kandanti, chinnapātaṃ papatanti, āvaṭṭanti, vivaṭṭanti:

dn16:5.6.5.pli: ‘atikhippaṃ bhagavā parinibbāyissati, atikhippaṃ sugato parinibbāyissati, atikhippaṃ cakkhuṃ loke antaradhāyissatī’ti.

dn16:5.6.6.pli: Yā pana tā devatā vītarāgā, tā satā sampajānā adhivāsenti:
dn16:5.6.6.eng: But the deities who are free of desire endure, mindful and aware, thinking:

dn16:5.6.7.eng: ‘Conditions are impermanent. How could it possibly be otherwise?’”
dn16:5.6.7.comm: These two reactions—grief and equanimity—are depicted often in Buddhist art and narrative. They stimulated the two poles of development of the Buddhist community. The devotional tradition, feeling the need for an emotional connection with the Teacher, developed art, story, and doctrines to, as it were, keep him alive, resulting in the Jātakas and the Bodhisattva doctrine. A cooler, rational tradition developed a comprehensive system analyzing the impermanence of “conditions”, leading to the Abhidhamma.

dn16:5.7.1.pli: “Pubbe, bhante, disāsu vassaṃvuṭṭhā bhikkhū āgacchanti tathāgataṃ dassanāya.
dn16:5.7.1.eng: “Previously, sir, when mendicants had completed the rainy season residence in various districts they came to see the Realized One.

dn16:5.7.2.pli: Te mayaṃ labhāma manobhāvanīye bhikkhū dassanāya, labhāma payirupāsanāya.
dn16:5.7.2.eng: We got to see the esteemed mendicants, and to pay homage to them.
dn16:5.7.2.comm: Manobhāvanīya is explained in the commentaries as “those who, when seen, cause the mind to grow in what is skillful.”

dn16:5.7.3.pli: Bhagavato pana mayaṃ, bhante, accayena na labhissāma manobhāvanīye bhikkhū dassanāya, na labhissāma payirupāsanāyā”ti.
dn16:5.7.3.eng: But when the Buddha has passed, we won’t get to see the esteemed mendicants or to pay homage to them.”

dn16:5.8.1.pli: “Cattārimāni, ānanda, saddhassa kulaputtassa dassanīyāni saṃvejanīyāni ṭhānāni.
dn16:5.8.1.eng: “Ānanda, a faithful gentleman should go to see these four inspiring places.
dn16:5.8.1.comm: These four sites are the primary destinations of modern Buddhist pilgrims in India. | Saṁvejanīya is “stirring, provoking inspiration or urgency” such as when seeing an astonishing, disturbing, or amazing sight.

dn16:5.8.3.pli: ‘Idha tathāgato jāto’ti, ānanda, saddhassa kulaputtassa dassanīyaṃ saṃvejanīyaṃ ṭhānaṃ.
dn16:5.8.3.eng: Thinking: ‘Here the Realized One was born!’—that is an inspiring place.
dn16:5.8.3.comm: Lumbinī in modern Nepal, which today is a well-maintained and quiet place for devotion and meditation. The site is marked with an Ashokan pillar dated perhaps 150 years after this time. On the pillar is inscribed in Brahmī characters hida bhagavaṁ jāte ti, which is a direct quote in Māgadhī of the Pali phrase here, idha tathāgato jāto ti. (Tathāgata “realized one” is how the Buddha referred to himself, while bhagavā “blessed one” is how his followers referred to him.) This is the oldest direct quote from the early canon preserved in the archaeological record.

dn16:5.8.4.pli: ‘Idha tathāgato anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddho’ti, ānanda, saddhassa kulaputtassa dassanīyaṃ saṃvejanīyaṃ ṭhānaṃ.
dn16:5.8.4.eng: Thinking: ‘Here the Realized One became awakened as a supreme fully awakened Buddha!’—that is an inspiring place.
dn16:5.8.4.comm: Bodhgaya in modern Bihar, which is called Uruvelā in the Pali texts. It is a bustling center for pilgrims from all over the Buddhist world, at the center of which is the great stupa next to the Bodhi tree.

dn16:5.8.5.pli: ‘Idha tathāgatena anuttaraṃ dhammacakkaṃ pavattitan’ti, ānanda, saddhassa kulaputtassa dassanīyaṃ saṃvejanīyaṃ ṭhānaṃ.
dn16:5.8.5.eng: Thinking: ‘Here the supreme Wheel of Dhamma was rolled forth by the Realized One!’—that is an inspiring place.
dn16:5.8.5.comm: Isipatana is modern Sarnath, in the northern part of Varanasi on the Ganges. In the temple next to the park, the first sermon is recited every night. | Note the passive voice, whereas the parallel at AN 4.118 is active.

dn16:5.8.6.pli: ‘Idha tathāgato anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbuto’ti, ānanda, saddhassa kulaputtassa dassanīyaṃ saṃvejanīyaṃ ṭhānaṃ.
dn16:5.8.6.eng: Thinking: ‘Here the Realized One was fully quenched in the element of extinguishment with no residue!’—that is an inspiring place.
dn16:5.8.6.comm: The phrase nibbānadhātuyā parinibbuto, “fully quenched in the element of extinguishment” shows how the Pali uses two roots simultaneously for Nibbana. The better-known term, nibbāna (Sanskrit nirvāṇa), is from the root vā (“to blow”), with the basic sense of going out through being deprived of air. The past participle form nibbuta (Sanskrit nirvṛta), from the root var (“to check or restrain”), has the basic sense of freedom from obstacles and constrictions. Generally, the Pali treats nibbuta as the past participle form of nibbāna, and for the most part the difference is purely verbal. Yet I believe the ambiguity is deliberate, as each captures a slightly different nuance of Nibbana. “Quenched” means both to go out like a flame and to be satisfied like a thirst. This positive feel appears in Sanskrit passages using nirvṛta, such as Manusmṛti 1.54, where it describes the blissful absorption of all beings into the great divinity. By using “extinguishment” for nibbāna and “quenched” for nibbuta I hope to express this subtle distinction, or at least to alert the reader that it exists.

dn16:5.8.7.pli: Imāni kho, ānanda, cattāri saddhassa kulaputtassa dassanīyāni saṃvejanīyāni ṭhānāni.
dn16:5.8.7.eng: These are the four inspiring places that a faithful gentleman should go to see.

dn16:5.8.8.pli: Āgamissanti kho, ānanda, saddhā bhikkhū bhikkhuniyo upāsakā upāsikāyo:
dn16:5.8.8.eng: Faithful monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen will come, and think:

dn16:5.8.9.pli: ‘idha tathāgato jāto’tipi, ‘idha tathāgato anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddho’tipi, ‘idha tathāgatena anuttaraṃ dhammacakkaṃ pavattitan’tipi, ‘idha tathāgato anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbuto’tipi.
dn16:5.8.9.eng: ‘Here the Realized One was born!’ and ‘Here the Realized One became awakened as a supreme fully awakened Buddha!’ and ‘Here the supreme Wheel of Dhamma was rolled forth by the Realized One!’ and ‘Here the Realized One was fully quenched in the element of extinguishment with no residue!’

dn16:5.8.10.pli: Ye hi keci, ānanda, cetiyacārikaṃ āhiṇḍantā pasannacittā kālaṃ karissanti, sabbe te kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjissantī”ti.
dn16:5.8.10.eng: Anyone who passes away while on pilgrimage to these shrines will, when their body breaks up, after death, be reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.”

dn16:5.9.1.eng: “Sir, how do we proceed when it comes to ladies?”
dn16:5.9.1.comm: This passage is absent from the Sanskrit parallel and it is probably a late interpolation. Ānanda was handsome, and many stories of his encounters with women are preserved, for example at Bu Pc 41:1.1.5.

dn16:5.9.2.comm: As it stands, this appears to contradict MN 152:2.10, where the Buddha ridicules the idea that sense restraint implies not seeing. The commentary, however, explains it as not looking at a woman who is standing in the doorway of a monk’s hut, so as not to give rise to lust. Thus it restricts this apparently general rule to an unusually intimate encounter.

dn16:5.9.3.comm: The verb changes from paṭipajjāma (first person plural) to paṭipajjitabbaṁ (future passive participle), a shift that mirrors the following passage regarding the funeral proceedings. There, the shift to future passive participle indicates that the subject is the lay folk who carry out the funeral, whereas here that does not apply. This suggests that this passage has been derived from that later passage.

dn16:5.9.4.comm: The commentary refers to AN 5.55:6.5, which speaks of chatting alone in private with a woman, a circumstance also dealt with in Bu Pc 45.

dn16:5.9.5.comm: Ānanda does not hesitate to let the Buddha know he has no intention of following his advice.

dn16:5.9.6.comm: The commentary says, quoting SN 35.127:1.6, that when a woman has sincere motivations, one should speak while thinking of them as a mother, a sister, or a daughter.

dn16:5.10.1.eng: “Sir, how do we proceed when it comes to the Realized One’s corpse?”

dn16:5.10.2.eng: “Don’t get involved in the rites for venerating the Realized One’s corpse, Ānanda.
dn16:5.10.2.comm: For abyāvaṭā (“don’t get involved”), compare samaṇena bhavitabbaṁ abyāvaṭena (“a monastic shouldn’t get involved” (in domestic matters)) at Bu Ss 5:1.3.34.

dn16:5.10.3.pli: Iṅgha tumhe, ānanda, sāratthe ghaṭatha anuyuñjatha, sāratthe appamattā ātāpino pahitattā viharatha.
dn16:5.10.3.eng: Please, Ānanda, you must all strive and practice for your heart’s goal! Meditate diligent, keen, and resolute for your heart’s goal!
dn16:5.10.3.comm: Read sadatthe (“own goal”) rather than sāratthe (“essential goal”).

dn16:5.10.4.pli: Santānanda, khattiyapaṇḍitāpi brāhmaṇapaṇḍitāpi gahapatipaṇḍitāpi tathāgate abhippasannā, te tathāgatassa sarīrapūjaṃ karissantī”ti.
dn16:5.10.4.eng: There are astute aristocrats, brahmins, and householders who are devoted to the Realized One. They will perform the rites for venerating the Realized One’s corpse.”

dn16:5.11.1.eng: “But sir, how to proceed when it comes to the Realized One’s corpse?”

dn16:5.11.2.pli: “Yathā kho, ānanda, rañño cakkavattissa sarīre paṭipajjanti, evaṃ tathāgatassa sarīre paṭipajjitabban”ti.
dn16:5.11.2.eng: “Proceed in the same way as they do for the corpse of a wheel-turning monarch.”

dn16:5.11.3.pli: “Kathaṃ pana, bhante, rañño cakkavattissa sarīre paṭipajjantī”ti?
dn16:5.11.3.eng: “But how do they proceed with a wheel-turning monarch’s corpse?”

dn16:5.11.4.pli: “Rañño, ānanda, cakkavattissa sarīraṃ ahatena vatthena veṭhenti, ahatena vatthena veṭhetvā vihatena kappāsena veṭhenti, vihatena kappāsena veṭhetvā ahatena vatthena veṭhenti.
dn16:5.11.4.eng: “They wrap a wheel-turning monarch’s corpse with unworn cloth, then with uncarded cotton, then again with unworn cloth.

dn16:5.11.5.pli: Etenupāyena pañcahi yugasatehi rañño cakkavattissa sarīraṃ veṭhetvā āyasāya teladoṇiyā pakkhipitvā aññissā āyasāya doṇiyā paṭikujjitvā sabbagandhānaṃ citakaṃ karitvā rañño cakkavattissa sarīraṃ jhāpenti.
dn16:5.11.5.eng: In this way they wrap the corpse with five hundred double-layers. Then they place it in an iron casket filled with oil and close it up with another casket. Then, having built a funeral pyre out of all kinds of aromatics, they cremate the corpse.
dn16:5.11.5.comm: An iron case was also used for Queen Bhaddā’s body at AN 5.50:1.6. The second iron case does not “enclose” the first; rather it “crooks” (paṭikujjati) like a lid to “close it up”.

dn16:5.11.6.eng: They build a monument for the wheel-turning monarch at the crossroads.
dn16:5.11.6.comm: This is a rare mention of the thūpa (“sepulchral momunent”) that became a major feature of the Buddhist landscape. Buddhist monuments were round in shape, which was apparently a characteristic of the lands around Magadha. Śatapathabrāhmaṇa 13.8.1.5 says that the correct form of such a monument was square, and that round monuments were built by godless “easterners”.

dn16:5.11.7.pli: Evaṃ kho, ānanda, rañño cakkavattissa sarīre paṭipajjanti.
dn16:5.11.7.eng: That’s how they proceed with a wheel-turning monarch’s corpse.

dn16:5.11.8.pli: Yathā kho, ānanda, rañño cakkavattissa sarīre paṭipajjanti, evaṃ tathāgatassa sarīre paṭipajjitabbaṃ.
dn16:5.11.8.eng: Proceed in the same way with the Realized One’s corpse.
dn16:5.11.8.comm: Here the Buddha is said to be explicitly instructing his followers to adopt the building of monuments from the local customs.

dn16:5.11.9.eng: A monument for the Realized One is to be built at the crossroads.

dn16:5.11.10.pli: Tattha ye mālaṃ vā gandhaṃ vā cuṇṇakaṃ vā āropessanti vā abhivādessanti vā cittaṃ vā pasādessanti tesaṃ taṃ bhavissati dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya.
dn16:5.11.10.eng: When someone there lifts up garlands or fragrance or powder, or bows, or inspires confidence in their heart, that will be for their lasting welfare and happiness.

dn16:5.12.1.eng: Ānanda, these four are worthy of a monument.

dn16:5.12.3.pli: Tathāgato arahaṃ sammāsambuddho thūpāraho, paccekasambuddho thūpāraho, tathāgatassa sāvako thūpāraho, rājā cakkavattī thūpārahoti.
dn16:5.12.3.eng: A Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha; an independent Buddha; a disciple of a Realized One; and a wheel-turning monarch.

dn16:5.12.4.pli: Kiñcānanda, atthavasaṃ paṭicca tathāgato arahaṃ sammāsambuddho thūpāraho?
dn16:5.12.4.eng: And for what reason is a Realized One worthy of a monument?

dn16:5.12.5.pli: ‘Ayaṃ tassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa thūpo’ti, ānanda, bahujanā cittaṃ pasādenti.
dn16:5.12.5.eng: So that many people will inspire confidence in their hearts, thinking: ‘This is the monument for that Blessed One, perfected and fully awakened!’

dn16:5.12.6.pli: Te tattha cittaṃ pasādetvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjanti.
dn16:5.12.6.eng: And having done so, when their body breaks up, after death, they are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

dn16:5.12.7.pli: Idaṃ kho, ānanda, atthavasaṃ paṭicca tathāgato arahaṃ sammāsambuddho thūpāraho.
dn16:5.12.7.eng: It is for this reason that a Realized One is worthy of a monument.

dn16:5.12.8.eng: And for what reason is an independent Buddha worthy of a monument?
dn16:5.12.8.comm: “Independent Buddhas” are sages who discover the Dhamma and are awakened independently, but who do not themselves go on to found a dispensation or establish a monastic order. Text has paccekasambuddho rather than the usual paccekabuddho.

dn16:5.12.9.pli: ‘Ayaṃ tassa bhagavato paccekasambuddhassa thūpo’ti, ānanda, bahujanā cittaṃ pasādenti.
dn16:5.12.9.eng: So that many people will inspire confidence in their hearts, thinking: ‘This is the monument for that independent Buddha!’

dn16:5.12.10.pli: Te tattha cittaṃ pasādetvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjanti.
dn16:5.12.10.eng: And having done so, when their body breaks up, after death, they are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

dn16:5.12.11.pli: Idaṃ kho, ānanda, atthavasaṃ paṭicca paccekasambuddho thūpāraho.
dn16:5.12.11.eng: It is for this reason that an independent Buddha is worthy of a monument.

dn16:5.12.12.pli: Kiñcānanda, atthavasaṃ paṭicca tathāgatassa sāvako thūpāraho?
dn16:5.12.12.eng: And for what reason is a Realized One’s disciple worthy of a monument?
dn16:5.12.12.comm: This refers to the “eight individuals” who make up the “Saṅgha of disciples”, namely those who have achieved the four stages of awakening and those on the path.

dn16:5.12.13.pli: ‘Ayaṃ tassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa sāvakassa thūpo’ti, ānanda, bahujanā cittaṃ pasādenti.
dn16:5.12.13.eng: So that many people will inspire confidence in their hearts, thinking: ‘This is the monument for that Blessed One’s disciple!’

dn16:5.12.14.pli: Te tattha cittaṃ pasādetvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjanti.
dn16:5.12.14.eng: And having done so, when their body breaks up, after death, they are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

dn16:5.12.15.pli: Idaṃ kho, ānanda, atthavasaṃ paṭicca tathāgatassa sāvako thūpāraho.
dn16:5.12.15.eng: It is for this reason that a Realized One’s disciple is worthy of a monument.

dn16:5.12.16.pli: Kiñcānanda, atthavasaṃ paṭicca rājā cakkavattī thūpāraho?
dn16:5.12.16.eng: And for what reason is a wheel-turning monarch worthy of a monument?

dn16:5.12.17.pli: ‘Ayaṃ tassa dhammikassa dhammarañño thūpo’ti, ānanda, bahujanā cittaṃ pasādenti.
dn16:5.12.17.eng: So that many people will inspire confidence in their hearts, thinking: ‘This is the monument for that just and principled king!’

dn16:5.12.18.pli: Te tattha cittaṃ pasādetvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjanti.
dn16:5.12.18.eng: And having done so, when their body breaks up, after death, they are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

dn16:5.12.19.pli: Idaṃ kho, ānanda, atthavasaṃ paṭicca rājā cakkavattī thūpāraho.
dn16:5.12.19.eng: It is for this reason that a wheel-turning monarch is worthy of a monument.

dn16:5.12.20.eng: These four are worthy of a monument.”

dn16:5.13.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando vihāraṃ pavisitvā kapisīsaṃ ālambitvā rodamāno aṭṭhāsi:
dn16:5.13.1.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda entered a building, and stood there leaning against the door-jamb and crying,
dn16:5.13.1.comm: Like Queen Subhaddā, wife of Mahāsudassana, at DN 17:2.8.7 and DN 17:2.12.1. | Kapisīsa is door-jamb, not lintel. | For vihāra (“building”) the commentary has “pavilion” (maṇḍalamāla), which may have been a temporary construction for the occasion (compare MN 92:4.6).

dn16:5.13.2.pli: “ahañca vatamhi sekho sakaraṇīyo, satthu ca me parinibbānaṃ bhavissati, yo mama anukampako”ti.
dn16:5.13.2.eng: “Oh! I’m still only a trainee with work left to do; and my Teacher is about to be fully extinguished, he who is so kind to me!”
dn16:5.13.2.comm: At this point Ānanda was a stream-enterer.

dn16:5.13.3.eng: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants,

dn16:5.13.5.pli: “Eso, bhante, āyasmā ānando vihāraṃ pavisitvā kapisīsaṃ ālambitvā rodamāno ṭhito:
dn16:5.13.5.eng: “Sir, Ānanda has entered a dwelling, and stands there leaning against the door-jamb and crying:

dn16:5.13.6.pli: ‘ahañca vatamhi sekho sakaraṇīyo, satthu ca me parinibbānaṃ bhavissati, yo mama anukampako’”ti.
dn16:5.13.6.eng: ‘Oh! I’m still only a trainee with work left to do; and my Teacher is about to be fully extinguished, he who is so kind to me!’”

dn16:5.13.7.pli: Atha kho bhagavā aññataraṃ bhikkhuṃ āmantesi:
dn16:5.13.7.eng: So the Buddha addressed one of the monks,

dn16:5.13.8.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, mama vacanena ānandaṃ āmantehi:
dn16:5.13.8.eng: “Please, monk, in my name tell Ānanda that

dn16:5.13.10.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho so bhikkhu bhagavato paṭissutvā yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:
dn16:5.13.10.eng: “Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to Ānanda and said to him,

dn16:5.14.1.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho āyasmā ānando tassa bhikkhuno paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
dn16:5.14.1.eng: “Yes, reverend,” Ānanda replied. He went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:

dn16:5.14.2.pli: “alaṃ, ānanda, mā soci mā paridevi, nanu etaṃ, ānanda, mayā paṭikacceva akkhātaṃ:
dn16:5.14.2.eng: “Enough, Ānanda! Do not grieve, do not lament. Did I not prepare for this when I explained that
dn16:5.14.2.comm: When admonishing Ānanda, the Buddha first gently but firmly restrains him, then gives words of support and encouragement.

dn16:5.14.3.eng: we must be parted and separated from all we hold dear and beloved?

dn16:5.14.4.pli: taṃ kutettha, ānanda, labbhā. Yaṃ taṃ jātaṃ bhūtaṃ saṅkhataṃ palokadhammaṃ, ‘taṃ vata tathāgatassāpi sarīraṃ mā palujjī’ti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
dn16:5.14.4.eng: How could it possibly be so that what is born, created, conditioned, and liable to wear out should not wear out, even the Realized One’s body?

dn16:5.14.5.pli: Dīgharattaṃ kho te, ānanda, tathāgato paccupaṭṭhito mettena kāyakammena hitena sukhena advayena appamāṇena, mettena vacīkammena hitena sukhena advayena appamāṇena, mettena manokammena hitena sukhena advayena appamāṇena.
dn16:5.14.5.eng: For a long time, Ānanda, you’ve treated the Realized One with deeds of body, speech, and mind that are loving, beneficial, pleasant, undivided, and limitless.
dn16:5.14.5.comm: The phrase “undivided and limitless” (advayena appamāṇena) normally describes kasiṇa meditation (AN 10.25:1.3); here it is also found in the Sanskrit: ānanda maitreṇa kāyakarmaṇā hitena sukhenādvayenāpramāṇena.

dn16:5.14.6.pli: Katapuññosi tvaṃ, ānanda, padhānamanuyuñja, khippaṃ hohisi anāsavo”ti.
dn16:5.14.6.eng: You have done good deeds, Ānanda. Devote yourself to meditation, and you will soon be free of defilements.”
dn16:5.14.6.comm: On the eve of the First Council—in about six months time—Ānanda devoted himself to meditation and achieved arahantship.

dn16:5.15.1.eng: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants:

dn16:5.15.2.pli: “yepi te, bhikkhave, ahesuṃ atītamaddhānaṃ arahanto sammāsambuddhā, tesampi bhagavantānaṃ etapparamāyeva upaṭṭhākā ahesuṃ, seyyathāpi mayhaṃ ānando.
dn16:5.15.2.eng: “Those who were perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas in the past also had attendants, who at best were like Ānanda is for me.
dn16:5.15.2.comm: The same is said regarding the chief disciples Sāriputta and Moggallāna at SN 47.14:2.4 and regarding assemblies of deities at DN 20:4.3.

dn16:5.15.3.pli: Yepi te, bhikkhave, bhavissanti anāgatamaddhānaṃ arahanto sammāsambuddhā, tesampi bhagavantānaṃ etapparamāyeva upaṭṭhākā bhavissanti, seyyathāpi mayhaṃ ānando.
dn16:5.15.3.eng: Those who will be perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas in the future will also have attendants, who at best will be like Ānanda is for me.

dn16:5.15.6.pli: Jānāti ‘ayaṃ kālo tathāgataṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṃ bhikkhūnaṃ, ayaṃ kālo bhikkhunīnaṃ, ayaṃ kālo upāsakānaṃ, ayaṃ kālo upāsikānaṃ, ayaṃ kālo rañño rājamahāmattānaṃ titthiyānaṃ titthiyasāvakānan’ti.
dn16:5.15.6.eng: He knows the time for monks, nuns, laymen, laywomen, king’s ministers, monastics of other religions and their disciples to visit the Realized One.
dn16:5.15.6.comm: Tittha, literally “ford”, is a path to salvation, used as a term for a non-Buddhist “religion”. Titthakara is a “religious founder” (literally “ford-maker”); titthiya is a “monastic of (another) religion” (for example at Bu NP 22:1.2.5); titthiyasāvaka is a “disciple of a monastic of (another) religion”.

dn16:5.16.1.pli: Cattārome, bhikkhave, acchariyā abbhutā dhammā ānande.
dn16:5.16.1.eng: There are these four incredible and amazing things about Ānanda.
dn16:5.16.1.comm: As at AN 4.130:6.4. Ānanda was in awe of the “incredible and amazing” qualities of the Buddha, and spoke of them often. Here, when Ānanda is at his most vulnerable, the Buddha turns the teaching around, pointing out that Ānanda is incredible and amazing too.

dn16:5.16.3.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, bhikkhuparisā ānandaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamati, dassanena sā attamanā hoti.
dn16:5.16.3.eng: If an assembly of monks goes to see Ānanda, they’re uplifted by seeing him

dn16:5.16.4.pli: Tatra ce ānando dhammaṃ bhāsati, bhāsitenapi sā attamanā hoti.
dn16:5.16.4.eng: and uplifted by hearing him speak.

dn16:5.16.5.pli: Atittāva, bhikkhave, bhikkhuparisā hoti, atha kho ānando tuṇhī hoti.
dn16:5.16.5.eng: And when he falls silent, they’ve never had enough.

dn16:5.16.6.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, bhikkhunīparisā ānandaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamati, dassanena sā attamanā hoti.

dn16:5.16.7.pli: Tatra ce ānando dhammaṃ bhāsati, bhāsitenapi sā attamanā hoti.

dn16:5.16.8.pli: Atittāva, bhikkhave, bhikkhunīparisā hoti, atha kho ānando tuṇhī hoti.

dn16:5.16.9.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, upāsakaparisā ānandaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamati, dassanena sā attamanā hoti.

dn16:5.16.10.pli: Tatra ce ānando dhammaṃ bhāsati, bhāsitenapi sā attamanā hoti.

dn16:5.16.11.pli: Atittāva, bhikkhave, upāsakaparisā hoti, atha kho ānando tuṇhī hoti.

dn16:5.16.12.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, upāsikāparisā ānandaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamati, dassanena sā attamanā hoti.
dn16:5.16.12.eng: or laywomen goes to see Ānanda, they’re uplifted by seeing him

dn16:5.16.13.pli: Tatra ce ānando dhammaṃ bhāsati, bhāsitenapi sā attamanā hoti.
dn16:5.16.13.eng: and uplifted by hearing him speak.

dn16:5.16.14.pli: Atittāva, bhikkhave, upāsikāparisā hoti, atha kho ānando tuṇhī hoti.
dn16:5.16.14.eng: And when he falls silent, they’ve never had enough.

dn16:5.16.15.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro acchariyā abbhutā dhammā ānande.
dn16:5.16.15.eng: These are the four incredible and amazing things about Ānanda.

dn16:5.16.16.pli: Cattārome, bhikkhave, acchariyā abbhutā dhammā raññe cakkavattimhi.
dn16:5.16.16.eng: There are these four incredible and amazing things about a wheel-turning monarch.
dn16:5.16.16.comm: This anticipates the story to follow.

dn16:5.16.18.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, khattiyaparisā rājānaṃ cakkavattiṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamati, dassanena sā attamanā hoti.
dn16:5.16.18.eng: If an assembly of aristocrats goes to see a wheel-turning monarch, they’re uplifted by seeing him

dn16:5.16.19.pli: Tatra ce rājā cakkavattī bhāsati, bhāsitenapi sā attamanā hoti.
dn16:5.16.19.eng: and uplifted by hearing him speak.

dn16:5.16.20.pli: Atittāva, bhikkhave, khattiyaparisā hoti. Atha kho rājā cakkavattī tuṇhī hoti.
dn16:5.16.20.eng: And when he falls silent, they’ve never had enough.

dn16:5.16.23.pli: samaṇaparisā rājānaṃ cakkavattiṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamati, dassanena sā attamanā hoti.
dn16:5.16.23.eng: or ascetics goes to see a wheel-turning monarch, they’re uplifted by seeing him

dn16:5.16.24.pli: Tatra ce rājā cakkavattī bhāsati, bhāsitenapi sā attamanā hoti.
dn16:5.16.24.eng: and uplifted by hearing him speak.

dn16:5.16.25.pli: Atittāva, bhikkhave, samaṇaparisā hoti. Atha kho rājā cakkavattī tuṇhī hoti.
dn16:5.16.25.eng: And when he falls silent, they’ve never had enough.

dn16:5.16.26.pli: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, cattārome acchariyā abbhutā dhammā ānande.
dn16:5.16.26.eng: In the same way, there are those four incredible and amazing things about Ānanda.”

dn16:5.16.27.pli: Sace, bhikkhave, bhikkhuparisā ānandaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamati, dassanena sā attamanā hoti.

dn16:5.16.28.pli: Tatra ce ānando dhammaṃ bhāsati, bhāsitenapi sā attamanā hoti.

dn16:5.16.33.pli: upāsikāparisā ānandaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamati, dassanena sā attamanā hoti.

dn16:5.16.34.pli: Tatra ce ānando dhammaṃ bhāsati, bhāsitenapi sā attamanā hoti.

dn16:5.16.37.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro acchariyā abbhutā dhammā ānande”ti.

dn16:5.17.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn16:5.17.1.eng: When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha:

dn16:5.17.2.pli: “mā, bhante, bhagavā imasmiṃ khuddakanagarake ujjaṅgalanagarake sākhānagarake parinibbāyi.
dn16:5.17.2.eng: “Sir, please don’t be fully extinguished in this little hamlet, this jungle hamlet, this branch hamlet.

dn16:5.17.3.eng: There are other great cities such as

dn16:5.17.4.pli: campā rājagahaṃ sāvatthī sāketaṃ kosambī bārāṇasī;
dn16:5.17.4.eng: Campā, Rājagaha, Sāvatthī, Sāketa, Kosambī, and Varanasi.
dn16:5.17.4.comm: Campā, Rājagaha, Sāvatthī, and Kosambī were the capitals of Aṅga, Magadha, Kosala, and Vaccha respectively. Sāketa was the former capital of Kosala. Varanasi was formerly the capital of Kāsi, but at this time was contested by Kosala and Magadha, and had recently been won from Ajātasattu (SN 3.14, SN 3.15).

dn16:5.17.5.eng: Let the Buddha be fully extinguished there.

dn16:5.17.6.pli: Ettha bahū khattiyamahāsālā, brāhmaṇamahāsālā gahapatimahāsālā tathāgate abhippasannā.
dn16:5.17.6.eng: There are many well-to-do aristocrats, brahmins, and householders there who are devoted to the Buddha.

dn16:5.17.7.eng: They will perform the rites of venerating the Realized One’s corpse.”

dn16:5.17.8.pli: “mā hevaṃ, ānanda, avaca, mā hevaṃ, ānanda, avaca:
dn16:5.17.8.eng: “Don’t say that Ānanda! Don’t say that

dn16:5.17.9.eng: this is a little hamlet, a jungle hamlet, a branch hamlet.

dn16:5.18.1.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, ānanda, rājā mahāsudassano nāma ahosi cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā cāturanto vijitāvī janapadatthāvariyappatto sattaratanasamannāgato.
dn16:5.18.1.eng: Once upon a time there was a king named Mahāsudassana who was a wheel-turning monarch, a just and principled king. His dominion extended to all four sides, he achieved stability in the country, and he possessed the seven treasures.
dn16:5.18.1.comm: This story is also found in DN 17. It seems that the Pali tradition extracted the story and greatly expanded it in an independent long discourse, whereas the Sanskrit tradition kept it at a more moderate length within the Mahāparinirvāṇasūtra itself.

dn16:5.18.2.pli: Rañño, ānanda, mahāsudassanassa ayaṃ kusinārā kusāvatī nāma rājadhānī ahosi.
dn16:5.18.2.eng: His capital was this Kusinārā, which at the time was named Kusāvatī.
dn16:5.18.2.comm: Kusāvatī features in the Kusajātaka (Ja 531), where the ugly but wise prince Kusa, son of the legendary Okkāka, wins the hand of the radiant Pabhāvatī. The Rāmāyaṇa also tells the story of a Kusa, son of Rāma, who ruled the city of Kusāvatī, although this city was located far to the south in the Vindhya ranges. Both stories are united by the detail that kusa grass, a prominent feature of Vedic ritual, ensured the kingly lineage.

dn16:5.18.3.pli: puratthimena ca pacchimena ca dvādasayojanāni āyāmena; uttarena ca dakkhiṇena ca sattayojanāni vitthārena.
dn16:5.18.3.eng: It stretched for twelve leagues from east to west, and seven leagues from north to south.
dn16:5.18.3.comm: A “league” (yojana) is usually estimated at between seven and twelve kilometers. By way of comparison, even at its greatest extent under Ashoka, Pāṭaliputta was less than a league per side, so the dimensions of Kusāvatī here are strictly legendary.

dn16:5.18.4.pli: Kusāvatī, ānanda, rājadhānī iddhā ceva ahosi phītā ca bahujanā ca ākiṇṇamanussā ca subhikkhā ca.
dn16:5.18.4.eng: The royal capital of Kusāvatī was successful, prosperous, populous, full of people, with plenty of food.

dn16:5.18.5.pli: Seyyathāpi, ānanda, devānaṃ āḷakamandā nāma rājadhānī iddhā ceva hoti phītā ca bahujanā ca ākiṇṇayakkhā ca subhikkhā ca;
dn16:5.18.5.eng: It was just like Āḷakamandā, the royal capital of the gods, which is successful, prosperous, populous, full of spirits, with plenty of food.
dn16:5.18.5.comm: According to DN 32, Āḷakamandā was one of the many cities of Kuvera in Uttarakuru.

dn16:5.18.6.pli: evameva kho, ānanda, kusāvatī rājadhānī iddhā ceva ahosi phītā ca bahujanā ca ākiṇṇamanussā ca subhikkhā ca.

dn16:5.18.7.pli: Kusāvatī, ānanda, rājadhānī dasahi saddehi avivittā ahosi divā ceva rattiñca, seyyathidaṃ—
dn16:5.18.7.eng: Kusāvatī was never free of ten sounds by day or night, namely:

dn16:5.18.8.pli: hatthisaddena assasaddena rathasaddena bherisaddena mudiṅgasaddena vīṇāsaddena gītasaddena saṅkhasaddena sammasaddena pāṇitāḷasaddena ‘asnātha pivatha khādathā’ti dasamena saddena.
dn16:5.18.8.eng: the sound of elephants, horses, chariots, drums, clay drums, arched harps, singing, horns, gongs, and handbells; and the cry: ‘Eat, drink, be merry!’ as the tenth.

dn16:5.19.1.pli: Gaccha tvaṃ, ānanda, kusināraṃ pavisitvā kosinārakānaṃ mallānaṃ ārocehi:
dn16:5.19.1.eng: Go, Ānanda, into Kusinārā and inform the Mallas:

dn16:5.19.2.pli: ‘ajja kho, vāseṭṭhā, rattiyā pacchime yāme tathāgatassa parinibbānaṃ bhavissati.
dn16:5.19.2.eng: ‘This very day, Vāseṭṭhas, in the last watch of the night, the Realized One will be fully extinguished.
dn16:5.19.2.comm: Vāseṭṭha is a Vedic priestly clan. The Mallas adopted the name of their priest’s lineage, which was the normal custom for initiated khattiyas. Other examples in the Pali are Saccaka who is called Aggivessana (MN 35:4.2), and the Buddha and his family who are called Gotama.

dn16:5.19.3.eng: Come forth, Vāseṭṭhas! Come forth, Vāseṭṭhas!

dn16:5.19.5.pli: amhākañca no gāmakkhette tathāgatassa parinibbānaṃ ahosi, na mayaṃ labhimhā pacchime kāle tathāgataṃ dassanāyā’”ti.
dn16:5.19.5.eng: ‘The Realized One became fully extinguished in our own village district, but we didn’t get a chance to see him in his final hour.’”

dn16:5.19.6.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paṭissutvā nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya attadutiyo kusināraṃ pāvisi.
dn16:5.19.6.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied Ānanda. Then he robed up and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Kusinārā with a companion.
dn16:5.19.6.comm: Attadutiyo “with self as second” is also at MN 146:4.6 where Nandaka visits the nuns. Sanskrit has bhikṣuṇā paścācchramaṇena (“with a mendicant as accompanying ascetic”). It was apparently evening (the “wrong time”, vikāla), when it is inappropriate for a monk to be wandering the town alone.

dn16:5.20.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena kosinārakā mallā sandhāgāre sannipatitā honti kenacideva karaṇīyena.
dn16:5.20.1.eng: Now at that time the Mallas of Kusinārā were sitting together at the town hall on some business.
dn16:5.20.1.comm: Evidently the Mallas, like the Vajjis, met frequently.

dn16:5.20.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena kosinārakānaṃ mallānaṃ sandhāgāraṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā kosinārakānaṃ mallānaṃ ārocesi:
dn16:5.20.2.eng: Ānanda went up to them, and announced:

dn16:5.20.3.pli: “ajja kho, vāseṭṭhā, rattiyā pacchime yāme tathāgatassa parinibbānaṃ bhavissati.
dn16:5.20.3.eng: “This very day, Vāseṭṭhas, in the last watch of the night, the Realized One will be fully extinguished.

dn16:5.20.4.eng: Come forth, Vāseṭṭhas! Come forth, Vāseṭṭhas!

dn16:5.20.6.pli: ‘amhākañca no gāmakkhette tathāgatassa parinibbānaṃ ahosi, na mayaṃ labhimhā pacchime kāle tathāgataṃ dassanāyā’”ti.
dn16:5.20.6.eng: ‘The Realized One became fully extinguished in our own village district, but we didn’t get a chance to see him in his final hour.’”

dn16:5.21.1.pli: Idamāyasmato ānandassa vacanaṃ sutvā mallā ca mallaputtā ca mallasuṇisā ca mallapajāpatiyo ca aghāvino dummanā cetodukkhasamappitā appekacce kese pakiriya kandanti, bāhā paggayha kandanti, chinnapātaṃ papatanti, āvaṭṭanti vivaṭṭanti:
dn16:5.21.1.eng: When they heard what Ānanda had to say, the Mallas, their sons, daughters-in-law, and wives became distraught, saddened, and grief-stricken. And some, with hair disheveled and arms raised, falling down like their feet were chopped off, rolling back and forth, lamented,

dn16:5.21.2.pli: “atikhippaṃ bhagavā parinibbāyissati, atikhippaṃ sugato parinibbāyissati, atikhippaṃ cakkhuṃ loke antaradhāyissatī”ti.
dn16:5.21.2.eng: “Too soon the Blessed One will be fully extinguished! Too soon the Holy One will be fully extinguished! Too soon the Eye of the World will vanish!”

dn16:5.21.3.pli: Atha kho mallā ca mallaputtā ca mallasuṇisā ca mallapajāpatiyo ca aghāvino dummanā cetodukkhasamappitā yena upavattanaṃ mallānaṃ sālavanaṃ yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkamiṃsu.
dn16:5.21.3.eng: Then the Mallas, their sons, daughters-in-law, and wives, distraught, saddened, and grief-stricken went to the Mallian sal grove at Upavattana and approached Ānanda.

dn16:5.22.2.pli: “sace kho ahaṃ kosinārake malle ekamekaṃ bhagavantaṃ vandāpessāmi, avandito bhagavā kosinārakehi mallehi bhavissati, athāyaṃ ratti vibhāyissati.
dn16:5.22.2.eng: “If I have the Mallas pay homage to the Buddha one by one, they won’t be finished before first light.

dn16:5.22.3.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ kosinārake malle kulaparivattaso kulaparivattaso ṭhapetvā bhagavantaṃ vandāpeyyaṃ:
dn16:5.22.3.eng: I’d better separate them family by family and then have them pay homage, saying:

dn16:5.22.4.pli: ‘itthannāmo, bhante, mallo saputto sabhariyo sapariso sāmacco bhagavato pāde sirasā vandatī’”ti.
dn16:5.22.4.eng: ‘Sir, the Malla named so-and-so with children, wives, retinue, and ministers bows with his head at your feet.’”

dn16:5.22.5.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando kosinārake malle kulaparivattaso kulaparivattaso ṭhapetvā bhagavantaṃ vandāpesi:
dn16:5.22.5.eng: And so that’s what he did.

dn16:5.22.6.pli: “itthannāmo, bhante, mallo saputto sabhariyo sapariso sāmacco bhagavato pāde sirasā vandatī”ti.

dn16:5.22.7.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando etena upāyena paṭhameneva yāmena kosinārake malle bhagavantaṃ vandāpesi.
dn16:5.22.7.eng: So by this means Ānanda got the Mallas to finish paying homage to the Buddha in the first watch of the night.

dn16:5.23.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena subhaddo nāma paribbājako kusinārāyaṃ paṭivasati.
dn16:5.23.1.eng: Now at that time a wanderer named Subhadda was residing near Kusinārā.
dn16:5.23.1.comm: This is the second Subhadda we have met in this discourse, the first being a deceased devotee of Ñātika (DN 16:2.6.13). The corrupt monk who, after the Buddha’s death, urges the rejection of the Vinaya rules is another person of the same name (DN 16:6.20.1). The Mahāsudassanasutta also features a Queen Subhaddā (DN 17:2.5.9).

dn16:5.23.3.pli: “ajja kira rattiyā pacchime yāme samaṇassa gotamassa parinibbānaṃ bhavissatī”ti.
dn16:5.23.3.eng: on that very day, in the last watch of the night, will be the full extinguishment of the ascetic Gotama.

dn16:5.23.5.pli: “sutaṃ kho pana metaṃ paribbājakānaṃ vuḍḍhānaṃ mahallakānaṃ ācariyapācariyānaṃ bhāsamānānaṃ:
dn16:5.23.5.eng: “I have heard that brahmins of the past who were elderly and senior, the tutors of tutors, said:

dn16:5.23.6.pli: ‘kadāci karahaci tathāgatā loke uppajjanti arahanto sammāsambuddhā’ti.
dn16:5.23.6.eng: ‘Only rarely do Realized Ones arise in the world, perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas.’

dn16:5.23.7.pli: Ajjeva rattiyā pacchime yāme samaṇassa gotamassa parinibbānaṃ bhavissati.
dn16:5.23.7.eng: And this very day, in the last watch of the night, will be the full extinguishment of the ascetic Gotama.

dn16:5.23.8.pli: Atthi ca me ayaṃ kaṅkhādhammo uppanno,
dn16:5.23.8.eng: This state of uncertainty has come up in me.

dn16:5.23.9.pli: evaṃ pasanno ahaṃ samaṇe gotame, ‘pahoti me samaṇo gotamo tathā dhammaṃ desetuṃ, yathāhaṃ imaṃ kaṅkhādhammaṃ pajaheyyan’”ti.
dn16:5.23.9.eng: I am quite confident that the Buddha is capable of teaching me so that I can give up this state of uncertainty.”

dn16:5.24.1.pli: Atha kho subhaddo paribbājako yena upavattanaṃ mallānaṃ sālavanaṃ, yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:
dn16:5.24.1.eng: Then Subhadda went to the Mallian sal grove at Upavattana, approached Ānanda, and said to him,

dn16:5.24.2.pli: “sutaṃ metaṃ, bho ānanda, paribbājakānaṃ vuḍḍhānaṃ mahallakānaṃ ācariyapācariyānaṃ bhāsamānānaṃ:
dn16:5.24.2.eng: “Worthy Ānanda, I have heard that brahmins of the past who were elderly and senior, the tutors of tutors, said:

dn16:5.24.3.pli: ‘kadāci karahaci tathāgatā loke uppajjanti arahanto sammāsambuddhā’ti.
dn16:5.24.3.eng: ‘Only rarely do Realized Ones arise in the world, perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas.’

dn16:5.24.4.pli: Ajjeva rattiyā pacchime yāme samaṇassa gotamassa parinibbānaṃ bhavissati.
dn16:5.24.4.eng: And this very day, in the last watch of the night, will be the full extinguishment of the ascetic Gotama.

dn16:5.24.5.pli: Atthi ca me ayaṃ kaṅkhādhammo uppanno—
dn16:5.24.5.eng: This state of uncertainty has come up in me.

dn16:5.24.6.pli: evaṃ pasanno ahaṃ samaṇe gotame ‘pahoti me samaṇo gotamo tathā dhammaṃ desetuṃ, yathāhaṃ imaṃ kaṅkhādhammaṃ pajaheyyan’ti.
dn16:5.24.6.eng: I am quite confident that the Buddha is capable of teaching me so that I can give up this state of uncertainty.

dn16:5.24.7.pli: Sādhāhaṃ, bho ānanda, labheyyaṃ samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāyā”ti.
dn16:5.24.7.eng: Worthy Ānanda, please let me see the ascetic Gotama.”

dn16:5.24.8.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā ānando subhaddaṃ paribbājakaṃ etadavoca:
dn16:5.24.8.eng: When he had spoken, Ānanda said,

dn16:5.24.9.pli: “alaṃ, āvuso subhadda, mā tathāgataṃ viheṭhesi, kilanto bhagavā”ti.
dn16:5.24.9.eng: “Enough, Reverend Subhadda, do not trouble the Realized One. He is tired.”

dn16:5.24.11.pli: tatiyampi kho subhaddo paribbājako āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:
dn16:5.24.11.eng: and a third time, Subhadda asked Ānanda, and a third time Ānanda refused.

dn16:5.24.12.pli: “sutaṃ metaṃ, bho ānanda, paribbājakānaṃ vuḍḍhānaṃ mahallakānaṃ ācariyapācariyānaṃ bhāsamānānaṃ:

dn16:5.24.13.pli: ‘kadāci karahaci tathāgatā loke uppajjanti arahanto sammāsambuddhā’ti.

dn16:5.24.14.pli: Ajjeva rattiyā pacchime yāme samaṇassa gotamassa parinibbānaṃ bhavissati.

dn16:5.24.15.pli: Atthi ca me ayaṃ kaṅkhādhammo uppanno—

dn16:5.24.16.pli: evaṃ pasanno ahaṃ samaṇe gotame, ‘pahoti me samaṇo gotamo tathā dhammaṃ desetuṃ, yathāhaṃ imaṃ kaṅkhādhammaṃ pajaheyyan’ti.

dn16:5.24.17.pli: Sādhāhaṃ, bho ānanda, labheyyaṃ samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ dassanāyā”ti.

dn16:5.24.18.pli: Tatiyampi kho āyasmā ānando subhaddaṃ paribbājakaṃ etadavoca:

dn16:5.24.19.pli: “alaṃ, āvuso subhadda, mā tathāgataṃ viheṭhesi, kilanto bhagavā”ti.

dn16:5.25.1.pli: Assosi kho bhagavā āyasmato ānandassa subhaddena paribbājakena saddhiṃ imaṃ kathāsallāpaṃ.
dn16:5.25.1.eng: The Buddha heard that discussion between Ānanda and Subhadda.

dn16:5.25.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:

dn16:5.25.3.pli: “alaṃ, ānanda, mā subhaddaṃ vāresi, labhataṃ, ānanda, subhaddo tathāgataṃ dassanāya.
dn16:5.25.3.eng: “Enough, Ānanda, don’t obstruct Subhadda; let him see the Realized One.

dn16:5.25.4.pli: Yaṃ kiñci maṃ subhaddo pucchissati, sabbaṃ taṃ aññāpekkhova pucchissati, no vihesāpekkho.
dn16:5.25.4.eng: For whatever he asks me, he will only be looking to understand, not to trouble me.

dn16:5.25.5.pli: Yañcassāhaṃ puṭṭho byākarissāmi, taṃ khippameva ājānissatī”ti.
dn16:5.25.5.eng: And he will quickly understand any answer I give to his question.”

dn16:5.25.6.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando subhaddaṃ paribbājakaṃ etadavoca:
dn16:5.25.6.eng: So Ānanda said to the wanderer Subhadda,

dn16:5.25.7.eng: “Go, Reverend Subhadda, the Buddha is making time for you.”

dn16:5.26.1.pli: Atha kho subhaddo paribbājako yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi, sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho subhaddo paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn16:5.26.1.eng: Then the wanderer Subhadda went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him. When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:

dn16:5.26.2.pli: “yeme, bho gotama, samaṇabrāhmaṇā saṅghino gaṇino gaṇācariyā ñātā yasassino titthakarā sādhusammatā bahujanassa,
dn16:5.26.2.eng: “Worthy Gotama, there are those ascetics and brahmins who lead an order and a community, and tutor a community. They’re well-known and famous religious founders, deemed holy by many people.

dn16:5.26.3.pli: seyyathidaṃ—pūraṇo kassapo, makkhali gosālo, ajito kesakambalo, pakudho kaccāyano, sañcayo belaṭṭhaputto, nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto,
dn16:5.26.3.eng: Namely: Pūraṇa Kassapa, the bamboo-staffed ascetic Gosāla, Ajita of the hair blanket, Pakudha Kaccāyana, Sañjaya Belaṭṭhiputta, and the Jain ascetic of the Ñātika clan.

dn16:5.26.4.pli: sabbete sakāya paṭiññāya abbhaññiṃsu, sabbeva na abbhaññiṃsu, udāhu ekacce abbhaññiṃsu, ekacce na abbhaññiṃsū”ti?
dn16:5.26.4.eng: According to their own claims, did all of them have direct knowledge, or none of them, or only some?”
dn16:5.26.4.comm: While some such as Mahāvīra the Ñātika (MN 14:17.2) and Pūraṇa Kassapa (AN 9.38:2.1) claimed to have direct knowledge, others such as Ajita Kesakambala denied that such knowledge was possible (DN 2:23.2).

dn16:5.26.5.comm: The Buddha responded the same way when asked this question by the brahmin Piṅgalakoccha (MN 30:2.6), and to a similar question at AN 9.38:3.2.

dn16:5.26.6.pli: ‘sabbete sakāya paṭiññāya abbhaññiṃsu, sabbeva na abbhaññiṃsu, udāhu ekacce abbhaññiṃsu, ekacce na abbhaññiṃsū’ti.

dn16:5.26.7.eng: I shall teach you the Dhamma.

dn16:5.26.8.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

dn16:5.26.9.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho subhaddo paribbājako bhagavato paccassosi.

dn16:5.27.1.pli: “Yasmiṃ kho, subhadda, dhammavinaye ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo na upalabbhati, samaṇopi tattha na upalabbhati. Dutiyopi tattha samaṇo na upalabbhati. Tatiyopi tattha samaṇo na upalabbhati. Catutthopi tattha samaṇo na upalabbhati.
dn16:5.27.1.eng: “Subhadda, in whatever teaching and training the noble eightfold path is not found, there is no ascetic found, no second ascetic, no third ascetic, and no fourth ascetic.
dn16:5.27.1.comm: The four ascetics are defined at AN 4.241:1.1 as those on the four paths.

dn16:5.27.2.pli: Yasmiñca kho, subhadda, dhammavinaye ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo upalabbhati, samaṇopi tattha upalabbhati, dutiyopi tattha samaṇo upalabbhati, tatiyopi tattha samaṇo upalabbhati, catutthopi tattha samaṇo upalabbhati.
dn16:5.27.2.eng: In whatever teaching and training the noble eightfold path is found, there is an ascetic found, a second ascetic, a third ascetic, and a fourth ascetic.
dn16:5.27.2.comm: While many aspects of the eightfold path are shared with others, some details may be missing (such as not-self or Nibbāna), while others are added (such as the belief in the efficacy of rituals, an eternal soul, or a creator god).

dn16:5.27.3.pli: Imasmiṃ kho, subhadda, dhammavinaye ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo upalabbhati, idheva, subhadda, samaṇo, idha dutiyo samaṇo, idha tatiyo samaṇo, idha catuttho samaṇo, suññā parappavādā samaṇebhi aññehi.
dn16:5.27.3.eng: In this teaching and training the noble eightfold path is found. Only here is there an ascetic, here a second ascetic, here a third ascetic, and here a fourth ascetic. Other sects are empty of ascetics.

dn16:5.27.4.pli: Ime ca, subhadda, bhikkhū sammā vihareyyuṃ, asuñño loko arahantehi assāti.
dn16:5.27.4.eng: Were these mendicants to practice well, the world would not be empty of perfected ones.
dn16:5.27.4.comm: The Buddha points to the mendicants who have gathered there.

dn16:5.27.5.eng: I was twenty-nine years of age, Subhadda,
dn16:5.27.5.comm: This is the only place in the early texts where the Buddha identifies his age when going forth.

dn16:5.27.6.eng: when I went forth to discover what is skillful.
dn16:5.27.6.comm: Detailed in such suttas as MN 36.

dn16:5.27.9.eng: Teacher of the references <j>for the systematic teaching:
dn16:5.27.9.comm: This verse appears to be corrupt. The sense can be restored through two extra lines in the Sanskrit: “Ethics, immersion, conduct, and knowledge, and unification of mind have been developed by me, teacher of the references for the noble teaching.” | For padesavattī, the Sanskrit has pradeśavaktā, where vaktā means “speaker” and pradeśa has the sense “pointing out”. I think it means, “I am the one who taught the four great references (mahāpadesa)”.

dn16:5.27.10.eng: outside of here there is no ascetic,

dn16:5.27.14.eng: Other sects are empty of ascetics.

dn16:5.27.15.pli: Ime ca, subhadda, bhikkhū sammā vihareyyuṃ, asuñño loko arahantehi assā”ti.
dn16:5.27.15.eng: Were these mendicants to practice well, the world would not be empty of perfected ones.”

dn16:5.28.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, subhaddo paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn16:5.28.1.eng: When he had spoken, Subhadda said to the Buddha,

dn16:5.28.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṃ bhagavatā anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
dn16:5.28.3.eng: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, the Buddha has made the teaching clear in many ways.

dn16:5.28.4.pli: Esāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
dn16:5.28.4.eng: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

dn16:5.28.5.pli: Labheyyāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ, labheyyaṃ upasampadan”ti.
dn16:5.28.5.eng: Sir, may I receive the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence?”

dn16:5.29.1.pli: “Yo kho, subhadda, aññatitthiyapubbo imasmiṃ dhammavinaye ākaṅkhati pabbajjaṃ, ākaṅkhati upasampadaṃ, so cattāro māse parivasati. Catunnaṃ māsānaṃ accayena āraddhacittā bhikkhū pabbājenti upasampādenti bhikkhubhāvāya.
dn16:5.29.1.eng: “Subhadda, if someone formerly ordained in another sect wishes to take the going forth, the ordination in this teaching and training, they must spend four months on probation. When four months have passed, if the mendicants are satisfied, they’ll give the going forth, the ordination into monkhood.

dn16:5.29.2.eng: However, I have recognized individual differences in this matter.”

dn16:5.29.3.pli: “Sace, bhante, aññatitthiyapubbā imasmiṃ dhammavinaye ākaṅkhantā pabbajjaṃ ākaṅkhantā upasampadaṃ cattāro māse parivasanti, catunnaṃ māsānaṃ accayena āraddhacittā bhikkhū pabbājenti upasampādenti bhikkhubhāvāya. Ahaṃ cattāri vassāni parivasissāmi, catunnaṃ vassānaṃ accayena āraddhacittā bhikkhū pabbājentu upasampādentu bhikkhubhāvāyā”ti.
dn16:5.29.3.eng: “Sir, if four months probation are required in such a case, I’ll spend four years on probation. When four years have passed, if the mendicants are satisfied, let them give me the going forth, the ordination into monkhood.”

dn16:5.29.4.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
dn16:5.29.4.eng: Then the Buddha said to Ānanda,

dn16:5.29.5.eng: “Well then, Ānanda, give Subhadda the going forth.”

dn16:5.29.6.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paccassosi.

dn16:5.30.1.pli: Atha kho subhaddo paribbājako āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:

dn16:5.30.2.pli: “lābhā vo, āvuso ānanda; suladdhaṃ vo, āvuso ānanda,
dn16:5.30.2.eng: “You’re so fortunate, Reverand Ānanda, so very fortunate,

dn16:5.30.3.pli: ye ettha satthu sammukhā antevāsikābhisekena abhisittā”ti.
dn16:5.30.3.eng: to be anointed here in the Teacher’s presence as his pupil!”

dn16:5.30.4.pli: Alattha kho subhaddo paribbājako bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ, alattha upasampadaṃ.
dn16:5.30.4.eng: And the wanderer Subhadda received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.

dn16:5.30.5.pli: Acirūpasampanno kho panāyasmā subhaddo eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti—tadanuttaraṃ brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
dn16:5.30.5.eng: Not long after his ordination, Venerable Subhadda, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

dn16:5.30.6.pli: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
dn16:5.30.6.eng: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”

dn16:5.30.7.pli: Aññataro kho panāyasmā subhaddo arahataṃ ahosi.
dn16:5.30.7.eng: And Venerable Subhadda became one of the perfected.

dn16:5.30.8.eng: He was the last personal disciple of the Buddha.
dn16:5.30.8.comm: The commentary says this line was added at the Council.

dn16:6.1.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
dn16:6.1.1.eng: Then the Buddha addressed Venerable Ānanda:

dn16:6.1.2.eng: “Now, Ānanda, some of you might think:

dn16:6.1.3.eng: ‘The teacher’s dispensation has passed. Now we have no Teacher.’

dn16:6.1.4.pli: Na kho panetaṃ, ānanda, evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
dn16:6.1.4.eng: But you should not see it like this.

dn16:6.1.5.pli: Yo vo, ānanda, mayā dhammo ca vinayo ca desito paññatto, so vo mamaccayena satthā.
dn16:6.1.5.eng: The teaching and training that I have taught and pointed out for you shall be your Teacher after my passing.
dn16:6.1.5.comm: This is similar to the idea of the Four Great references, and sets the scene for the First Council at which the teachings were recited. | Paññatto here means “pointed out” rather than “laid down”, as can be seen from DN 9:33.21, where the same phrase refers to the four noble truths.

dn16:6.2.1.pli: Yathā kho panānanda, etarahi bhikkhū aññamaññaṃ āvusovādena samudācaranti, na kho mamaccayena evaṃ samudācaritabbaṃ.
dn16:6.2.1.eng: After my passing, mendicants ought not address each other as ‘reverend’, as they do today.
dn16:6.2.1.comm: Āvuso is from the root āyu (“age”) and thus has a respectful sense and does not mean “friend” as it is often translated. Like bhante, it is an indeclinable vocative of address that may be used with or without the name (see eg. MN 5:31.2).

dn16:6.2.2.pli: Theratarena, ānanda, bhikkhunā navakataro bhikkhu nāmena vā gottena vā āvusovādena vā samudācaritabbo.
dn16:6.2.2.eng: A more senior mendicant ought to address a more junior mendicant by name or clan, or by saying ‘reverend’.

dn16:6.2.3.pli: Navakatarena bhikkhunā therataro bhikkhu ‘bhante’ti vā ‘āyasmā’ti vā samudācaritabbo.
dn16:6.2.3.eng: A more junior mendicant ought to address a more senior mendicant using ‘sir’ or ‘venerable’.
dn16:6.2.3.comm: I render bhante as “sir” when it stands alone and “honorable” when it prefixes a name. | Unlike bhante, āyasmā (“venerable”) is declinable, so it is used in parts of speech other than direct address. It is from the same root as āvuso but with a slightly more respectful tone, perhaps because it sounds more Sanskritic.

dn16:6.3.1.pli: Ākaṅkhamāno, ānanda, saṅgho mamaccayena khuddānukhuddakāni sikkhāpadāni samūhanatu.
dn16:6.3.1.eng: If it wishes, after my passing the Saṅgha may abolish the lesser and minor training rules.
dn16:6.3.1.comm: These are not defined here, and the senior monks at the First Council were unable to agree on them (Kd 21:1.9.3). Nonetheless, the Pali Vinaya consistently labels the Pācittiya rules as “lesser” (khuddaka; Bu Pc 92:2.2.22, Bi Pc 96:2.2.22, Pvr 1.1:219.3), which would make the Pātidesanīyas “minor” (anukhuddaka). The Sekhiya rules are also “minor”, but they were not at this point reckoned among the training rules for recitation.

dn16:6.4.1.pli: Channassa, ānanda, bhikkhuno mamaccayena brahmadaṇḍo dātabbo”ti.
dn16:6.4.1.eng: After my passing, give the divine punishment to the mendicant Channa.”
dn16:6.4.1.comm: “Divine punishment” is brahmadaṇḍa. Channa features often in the Vinaya as a monk who refuses correction and acts disrespectfully. The Sangha had already imposed an act of “ejection” (ukkhepanīyakamma) on him due to his persistent bad behavior, but that was still not enough (Kd 1:25.1.1). The brahmadaṇḍa was imposed at the First Council (Kd 1:1.12.1), upon which Channa finally saw the error of his ways. Brahmadaṇḍa is encountered in a different sense at DN 3:1.23.21.

dn16:6.4.2.eng: “But sir, what is the divine punishment?”

dn16:6.4.3.pli: “Channo, ānanda, bhikkhu yaṃ iccheyya, taṃ vadeyya.

dn16:6.4.4.pli: So bhikkhūhi neva vattabbo, na ovaditabbo, na anusāsitabbo”ti.
dn16:6.4.4.eng: but the mendicants should not correct, advise, or instruct him.”
dn16:6.4.4.comm: Vattabba in such contexts means “advise, correct” rather than more generally “speak to”. Thus the brahmadaṇḍa is not the “silent treatment”.

dn16:6.5.1.eng: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants,

dn16:6.5.2.pli: “siyā kho pana, bhikkhave, ekabhikkhussāpi kaṅkhā vā vimati vā buddhe vā dhamme vā saṅghe vā magge vā paṭipadāya vā, pucchatha, bhikkhave, mā pacchā vippaṭisārino ahuvattha:
dn16:6.5.2.eng: “Perhaps even a single mendicant has doubt or uncertainty regarding the Buddha, the teaching, the Saṅgha, the path, or the practice. So ask, mendicants! Don’t regret it later, thinking:

dn16:6.5.3.pli: ‘sammukhībhūto no satthā ahosi, na mayaṃ sakkhimhā bhagavantaṃ sammukhā paṭipucchitun’”ti.
dn16:6.5.3.eng: ‘We were in the Teacher’s presence and we weren’t able to ask the Buddha a question.’”

dn16:6.5.4.pli: Evaṃ vutte, te bhikkhū tuṇhī ahesuṃ.
dn16:6.5.4.eng: When this was said, the mendicants kept silent.

dn16:6.6.2.eng: and a third time the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

dn16:6.6.3.pli: “siyā kho pana, bhikkhave, ekabhikkhussāpi kaṅkhā vā vimati vā buddhe vā dhamme vā saṅghe vā magge vā paṭipadāya vā, pucchatha, bhikkhave, mā pacchā vippaṭisārino ahuvattha:
dn16:6.6.3.eng: “Perhaps even a single mendicant has doubt or uncertainty regarding the Buddha, the teaching, the Saṅgha, the path, or the practice. So ask, mendicants! Don’t regret it later, thinking:

dn16:6.6.4.pli: ‘sammukhībhūto no satthā ahosi, na mayaṃ sakkhimhā bhagavantaṃ sammukhā paṭipucchitun’”ti.
dn16:6.6.4.eng: ‘We were in the Teacher’s presence and we weren’t able to ask the Buddha a question.’”

dn16:6.6.5.pli: Tatiyampi kho te bhikkhū tuṇhī ahesuṃ.
dn16:6.6.5.eng: For a third time, the mendicants kept silent.

dn16:6.6.6.eng: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants,

dn16:6.6.7.pli: “siyā kho pana, bhikkhave, satthugāravenapi na puccheyyātha. Sahāyakopi, bhikkhave, sahāyakassa ārocetū”ti.
dn16:6.6.7.eng: “Mendicants, perhaps you don’t ask out of respect for the Teacher. So let a friend tell a friend.”

dn16:6.6.8.pli: Evaṃ vutte, te bhikkhū tuṇhī ahesuṃ.
dn16:6.6.8.eng: When this was said, the mendicants kept silent.

dn16:6.6.9.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
dn16:6.6.9.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha,

dn16:6.6.10.pli: “acchariyaṃ, bhante, abbhutaṃ, bhante, evaṃ pasanno ahaṃ, bhante, imasmiṃ bhikkhusaṅghe, ‘natthi ekabhikkhussāpi kaṅkhā vā vimati vā buddhe vā dhamme vā saṅghe vā magge vā paṭipadāya vā’”ti.
dn16:6.6.10.eng: “It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing! I am quite confident that there is not even a single mendicant in this Saṅgha who has doubt or uncertainty regarding the Buddha, the teaching, the Saṅgha, the path, or the practice.”

dn16:6.6.11.pli: “Pasādā kho tvaṃ, ānanda, vadesi, ñāṇameva hettha, ānanda, tathāgatassa. Natthi imasmiṃ bhikkhusaṅghe ekabhikkhussāpi kaṅkhā vā vimati vā buddhe vā dhamme vā saṅghe vā magge vā paṭipadāya vā.
dn16:6.6.11.eng: “Ānanda, you speak out of faith. But the Realized One knows that there is not even a single mendicant in this Saṅgha who has doubt or uncertainty regarding the Buddha, the teaching, the Saṅgha, the path, or the practice.

dn16:6.6.12.pli: Imesañhi, ānanda, pañcannaṃ bhikkhusatānaṃ yo pacchimako bhikkhu, so sotāpanno avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo”ti.
dn16:6.6.12.eng: Even the last of these five hundred mendicants is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.”

dn16:6.7.1.eng: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants:

dn16:6.7.2.eng: “Come now, mendicants, I say to you all:

dn16:6.7.4.eng: These were the Realized One’s last words.
dn16:6.7.4.comm: The commentary says this line was added at the Council.

dn16:6.8.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajji, paṭhamajjhānā vuṭṭhahitvā dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajji, dutiyajjhānā vuṭṭhahitvā tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajji, tatiyajjhānā vuṭṭhahitvā catutthaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajji, catutthajjhānā vuṭṭhahitvā ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samāpajji, ākāsānañcāyatanasamāpattiyā vuṭṭhahitvā viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samāpajji, viññāṇañcāyatanasamāpattiyā vuṭṭhahitvā ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samāpajji, ākiñcaññāyatanasamāpattiyā vuṭṭhahitvā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samāpajji, nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasamāpattiyā vuṭṭhahitvā saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ samāpajji.
dn16:6.8.1.eng: Then the Buddha entered the first absorption. Emerging from that, he entered the second absorption. Emerging from that, he successively entered into and emerged from the third absorption, the fourth absorption, the dimension of infinite space, the dimension of infinite consciousness, the dimension of nothingness, and the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. Then he entered the cessation of perception and feeling.
dn16:6.8.1.comm: Even on his deathbed, the Buddha retains mastery over his mind.

dn16:6.8.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ etadavoca:
dn16:6.8.2.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda said to Venerable Anuruddha,

dn16:6.8.3.eng: “Honorable Anuruddha, has the Buddha become fully quenched?”
dn16:6.8.3.comm: Ānanda’s question is prompted by the fact that it is very difficult to tell the difference between one who is dead and who has attained cessation (MN 43:25.1). Anuruddha can answer due to his mastery of psychic powers. | Note that Ānanda and Anuruddha have immediately adopted the forms of address recommended by the Buddha above.

dn16:6.8.4.eng: “No, Reverend Ānanda. He has entered the cessation of perception and feeling.”

dn16:6.9.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā saññāvedayitanirodhasamāpattiyā vuṭṭhahitvā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samāpajji, nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasamāpattiyā vuṭṭhahitvā ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samāpajji, ākiñcaññāyatanasamāpattiyā vuṭṭhahitvā viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samāpajji, viññāṇañcāyatanasamāpattiyā vuṭṭhahitvā ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samāpajji, ākāsānañcāyatanasamāpattiyā vuṭṭhahitvā catutthaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajji, catutthajjhānā vuṭṭhahitvā tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajji, tatiyajjhānā vuṭṭhahitvā dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajji, dutiyajjhānā vuṭṭhahitvā paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajji, paṭhamajjhānā vuṭṭhahitvā dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajji, dutiyajjhānā vuṭṭhahitvā tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajji, tatiyajjhānā vuṭṭhahitvā catutthaṃ jhānaṃ samāpajji, catutthajjhānā vuṭṭhahitvā samanantarā bhagavā parinibbāyi.
dn16:6.9.1.eng: Then the Buddha emerged from the cessation of perception and feeling and entered the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. Emerging from that, he successively entered into and emerged from the dimension of nothingness, the dimension of infinite consciousness, the dimension of infinite space, the fourth absorption, the third absorption, the second absorption, and the first absorption. Emerging from that, he successively entered into and emerged from the second absorption and the third absorption. Then he entered the fourth absorption. Emerging from that the Buddha immediately became fully extinguished.

dn16:6.10.1.pli: Parinibbute bhagavati saha parinibbānā mahābhūmicālo ahosi bhiṃsanako salomahaṃso. Devadundubhiyo ca phaliṃsu.
dn16:6.10.1.eng: When the Buddha was fully quenched, along with the full extinguishment there was a great earthquake, awe-inspiring and hair-raising, and thunder cracked the sky.

dn16:6.10.2.pli: Parinibbute bhagavati saha parinibbānā brahmāsahampati imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
dn16:6.10.2.eng: When the Buddha was fully quenched, the divinity Sahampati spoke this verse:

dn16:6.10.3.comm: Each of these characters reveal something of themselves in their verses. Sahampati, as a royal deity, emphasizes the universal nature of the teaching and the grandeur of the Buddha.

dn16:6.10.4.eng: must lay down this bag of bones.
dn16:6.10.4.comm: “Bag of bones” is a loose rendering of samussaya.

dn16:6.10.5.eng: For even a Teacher such as this,

dn16:6.10.7.eng: the Realized One, attained to power,
dn16:6.10.7.comm: The ten powers of a Realized One are detailed at AN 10.21 and MN 12:9.1.

dn16:6.10.9.pli: Parinibbute bhagavati saha parinibbānā sakko devānamindo imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
dn16:6.10.9.eng: When the Buddha was fully quenched, Sakka, lord of gods, spoke this verse:

dn16:6.10.10.comm: Less creative than Brahmā, Sakka repeats a famous verse spoken by the Buddha at SN 15.20:8.1 and DN 17:2.17.5.

dn16:6.10.11.eng: their nature is to rise and fall;

dn16:6.10.14.pli: Parinibbute bhagavati saha parinibbānā āyasmā anuruddho imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
dn16:6.10.14.eng: When the Buddha was fully quenched, Venerable Anuruddha spoke this verse:

dn16:6.10.15.comm: Anuruddha was a reclusive meditator who specialized in mindfulness of breathing. Here he remarks on the fact that, since breathing ceases in the fourth absorption (SN 36.11:2.19), the Buddha’s breathing had already stopped before he died.

dn16:6.10.16.eng: for the unaffected one of steady heart.

dn16:6.10.18.eng: the sage has done his time.

dn16:6.10.19.eng: He put up with painful feelings

dn16:6.10.22.eng: was like the extinguishing of a lamp.”

dn16:6.10.23.pli: Parinibbute bhagavati saha parinibbānā āyasmā ānando imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
dn16:6.10.23.eng: When the Buddha was fully quenched, Venerable Ānanda spoke this verse:

dn16:6.10.24.comm: Ānanda has the most emotional reaction. While Anuruddha speaks only of peace, Ānanda empathizes with those who were distraught.

dn16:6.10.26.eng: When the Buddha, endowed with all fine qualities,

dn16:6.10.28.pli: Parinibbute bhagavati ye te tattha bhikkhū avītarāgā appekacce bāhā paggayha kandanti, chinnapātaṃ papatanti, āvaṭṭanti vivaṭṭanti, “atikhippaṃ bhagavā parinibbuto, atikhippaṃ sugato parinibbuto, atikhippaṃ cakkhuṃ loke antarahito”ti.
dn16:6.10.28.eng: When the Buddha was fully quenched, some of the mendicants there who were not free of desire, with arms raised, falling down like their feet were chopped off, rolling back and forth, lamented: “Too soon the Blessed One has become fully quenched! Too soon the Holy One has become fully quenched! Too soon the Eye of the World has vanished!”
dn16:6.10.28.comm: Text omits “with hair disheveled” (kese pakiriya) when describing the shaven-headed monks.

dn16:6.10.29.pli: Ye pana te bhikkhū vītarāgā, te satā sampajānā adhivāsenti:
dn16:6.10.29.eng: But the mendicants who were free of desire endured, mindful and aware, thinking,

dn16:6.10.30.eng: “Conditions are impermanent. How could it possibly be otherwise?”

dn16:6.11.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā anuruddho bhikkhū āmantesi:

dn16:6.11.2.eng: “Enough, reverends, do not grieve or lament.

dn16:6.11.3.pli: Nanu etaṃ, āvuso, bhagavatā paṭikacceva akkhātaṃ:
dn16:6.11.3.eng: Did the Buddha not prepare us for this when he explained that

dn16:6.11.4.eng: we must be parted and separated from all we hold dear and beloved?

dn16:6.11.5.pli: Taṃ kutettha, āvuso, labbhā. ‘Yaṃ taṃ jātaṃ bhūtaṃ saṅkhataṃ palokadhammaṃ, taṃ vata mā palujjī’ti, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
dn16:6.11.5.eng: How could it possibly be so that what is born, created, conditioned, and liable to wear out should not wear out?

dn16:6.11.7.pli: “Kathaṃbhūtā pana, bhante, āyasmā anuruddho devatā manasi karotī”ti?
dn16:6.11.7.eng: “But sir, what kind of deities are you thinking of?”

dn16:6.11.8.pli: “Santāvuso ānanda, devatā ākāse pathavīsaññiniyo kese pakiriya kandanti, bāhā paggayha kandanti, chinnapātaṃ papatanti, āvaṭṭanti, vivaṭṭanti:
dn16:6.11.8.eng: “There are, Ānanda, deities—both in space and on the earth—who are aware of the earth. With hair disheveled and arms raised, they fall down like their feet were chopped off, rolling back and forth, lamenting:

dn16:6.11.9.pli: ‘atikhippaṃ bhagavā parinibbuto, atikhippaṃ sugato parinibbuto, atikhippaṃ cakkhuṃ loke antarahito’ti.
dn16:6.11.9.eng: ‘Too soon the Blessed One has become fully quenched! Too soon the Holy One has become fully quenched! Too soon the Eye of the World has vanished!’

dn16:6.11.10.pli: Santāvuso ānanda, devatā pathaviyā pathavīsaññiniyo kese pakiriya kandanti, bāhā paggayha kandanti, chinnapātaṃ papatanti, āvaṭṭanti, vivaṭṭanti:

dn16:6.11.11.pli: ‘atikhippaṃ bhagavā parinibbuto, atikhippaṃ sugato parinibbuto, atikhippaṃ cakkhuṃ loke antarahito’ti.

dn16:6.11.12.pli: Yā pana tā devatā vītarāgā, tā satā sampajānā adhivāsenti:
dn16:6.11.12.eng: But the deities who are free of desire endure, mindful and aware, thinking:

dn16:6.11.13.eng: ‘Conditions are impermanent. How could it possibly be otherwise?’”

dn16:6.11.14.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ca anuruddho āyasmā ca ānando taṃ rattāvasesaṃ dhammiyā kathāya vītināmesuṃ.
dn16:6.11.14.eng: Ānanda and Anuruddha spent the rest of the night talking about Dhamma.

dn16:6.12.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā anuruddho āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:

dn16:6.12.2.pli: “gacchāvuso ānanda, kusināraṃ pavisitvā kosinārakānaṃ mallānaṃ ārocehi:
dn16:6.12.2.eng: “Go, Ānanda, into Kusinārā and inform the Mallas:

dn16:6.12.3.eng: ‘Vāseṭṭhas, the Buddha has become fully quenched.

dn16:6.12.5.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando āyasmato anuruddhassa paṭissutvā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya attadutiyo kusināraṃ pāvisi.
dn16:6.12.5.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied Ānanda. Then, in the morning, he robed up and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Kusinārā with a companion.

dn16:6.12.6.pli: Tena kho pana samayena kosinārakā mallā sandhāgāre sannipatitā honti teneva karaṇīyena.
dn16:6.12.6.eng: Now at that time the Mallas of Kusinārā were sitting together at the town hall still on the same business.
dn16:6.12.6.comm: “Still on the same business” (teneva karaṇīyena) calls back to DN 16:5.20.1, where they were said to be “on some business” (kenacideva karaṇīyena). They had been discussing all night.

dn16:6.12.7.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena kosinārakānaṃ mallānaṃ sandhāgāraṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā kosinārakānaṃ mallānaṃ ārocesi:
dn16:6.12.7.eng: Ānanda went up to them, and announced,

dn16:6.12.8.eng: “Vāseṭṭhas, the Buddha has become fully quenched.

dn16:6.12.10.pli: Idamāyasmato ānandassa vacanaṃ sutvā mallā ca mallaputtā ca mallasuṇisā ca mallapajāpatiyo ca aghāvino dummanā cetodukkhasamappitā appekacce kese pakiriya kandanti, bāhā paggayha kandanti, chinnapātaṃ papatanti, āvaṭṭanti, vivaṭṭanti:
dn16:6.12.10.eng: When they heard what Ānanda had to say, the Mallas, their sons, daughters-in-law, and wives became distraught, saddened, and grief-stricken. And some, with hair disheveled and arms raised, falling down like their feet were chopped off, rolling back and forth, lamented,

dn16:6.12.11.pli: “atikhippaṃ bhagavā parinibbuto, atikhippaṃ sugato parinibbuto, atikhippaṃ cakkhuṃ loke antarahito”ti.
dn16:6.12.11.eng: “Too soon the Blessed One has become fully quenched! Too soon the Holy One has become fully quenched! Too soon the Eye of the World has vanished!”

dn16:6.13.0.eng: 37. The Rites of Venerating the Buddha’s Corpse

dn16:6.13.1.pli: Atha kho kosinārakā mallā purise āṇāpesuṃ:
dn16:6.13.1.eng: Then the Mallas ordered their men,

dn16:6.13.2.pli: “tena hi, bhaṇe, kusinārāyaṃ gandhamālañca sabbañca tāḷāvacaraṃ sannipātethā”ti.
dn16:6.13.2.eng: “So then, my men, collect fragrances and garlands, and all the musical instruments in Kusinārā.”

dn16:6.13.3.pli: Atha kho kosinārakā mallā gandhamālañca sabbañca tāḷāvacaraṃ pañca ca dussayugasatāni ādāya yena upavattanaṃ mallānaṃ sālavanaṃ, yena bhagavato sarīraṃ tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavato sarīraṃ naccehi gītehi vāditehi mālehi gandhehi sakkarontā garuṃ karontā mānentā pūjentā celavitānāni karontā maṇḍalamāḷe paṭiyādentā ekadivasaṃ vītināmesuṃ.
dn16:6.13.3.eng: Then—taking those fragrances and garlands, all the musical instruments, and five hundred pairs of garments—they went to the Mallian sal grove at Upavattana and approached the Buddha’s corpse. They spent the day honoring, respecting, revering, and venerating the Buddha’s corpse with dance and song and music and garlands and fragrances, and making awnings and setting up pavilions.
dn16:6.13.3.comm: An uplifting response to tragedy, full of beauty and celebration.

dn16:6.13.5.pli: “ativikālo kho ajja bhagavato sarīraṃ jhāpetuṃ, sve dāni mayaṃ bhagavato sarīraṃ jhāpessāmā”ti.
dn16:6.13.5.eng: “It’s too late to cremate the Buddha’s corpse today. Let’s do it tomorrow.”

dn16:6.13.6.pli: Atha kho kosinārakā mallā bhagavato sarīraṃ naccehi gītehi vāditehi mālehi gandhehi sakkarontā garuṃ karontā mānentā pūjentā celavitānāni karontā maṇḍalamāḷe paṭiyādentā dutiyampi divasaṃ vītināmesuṃ, tatiyampi divasaṃ vītināmesuṃ, catutthampi divasaṃ vītināmesuṃ, pañcamampi divasaṃ vītināmesuṃ, chaṭṭhampi divasaṃ vītināmesuṃ.
dn16:6.13.6.eng: But they spent the next day the same way, and so too the third, fourth, fifth, and sixth days.
dn16:6.13.6.comm: It seem unlikely that everyone simply forgot. It was probably the custom to wait seven days before the cremation.

dn16:6.14.1.pli: Atha kho sattamaṃ divasaṃ kosinārakānaṃ mallānaṃ etadahosi:
dn16:6.14.1.eng: Then on the seventh day they thought,

dn16:6.14.2.pli: “mayaṃ bhagavato sarīraṃ naccehi gītehi vāditehi mālehi gandhehi sakkarontā garuṃ karontā mānentā pūjentā dakkhiṇena dakkhiṇaṃ nagarassa haritvā bāhirena bāhiraṃ dakkhiṇato nagarassa bhagavato sarīraṃ jhāpessāmā”ti.
dn16:6.14.2.eng: “Honoring, respecting, revering, and venerating the Buddha’s corpse with dance and song and music and garlands and fragrances, let us carry it to the south of the town, and cremate it there outside the town.”

dn16:6.14.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aṭṭha mallapāmokkhā sīsaṃnhātā ahatāni vatthāni nivatthā:
dn16:6.14.3.eng: Now at that time eight of the leading Mallas, having bathed their heads and dressed in unworn clothes, said,
dn16:6.14.3.comm: “Unworn” is ahata, as at DN 14:1.33.9 and Kd 1:1.6.2.

dn16:6.14.4.pli: “mayaṃ bhagavato sarīraṃ uccāressāmā”ti na sakkonti uccāretuṃ.
dn16:6.14.4.eng: “We shall lift the Buddha’s corpse.” But they were unable to do so.

dn16:6.14.5.pli: Atha kho kosinārakā mallā āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ etadavocuṃ:

dn16:6.14.6.pli: “ko nu kho, bhante anuruddha, hetu ko paccayo, yenime aṭṭha mallapāmokkhā sīsaṃnhātā ahatāni vatthāni nivatthā:
dn16:6.14.6.eng: “What is the cause, Honorable Anuruddha, what is the reason why these eight Mallian chiefs are unable to lift the Buddha’s corpse?”

dn16:6.14.7.pli: ‘mayaṃ bhagavato sarīraṃ uccāressāmā’ti na sakkonti uccāretun”ti?

dn16:6.14.8.pli: “Aññathā kho, vāseṭṭhā, tumhākaṃ adhippāyo, aññathā devatānaṃ adhippāyo”ti.
dn16:6.14.8.eng: “Vāseṭṭhas, you have one plan, but the deities have a different one.”

dn16:6.15.1.eng: “But sir, what is the deities’ plan?”

dn16:6.15.3.pli: ‘mayaṃ bhagavato sarīraṃ naccehi gītehi vāditehi mālehi gandhehi sakkarontā garuṃ karontā mānentā pūjentā dakkhiṇena dakkhiṇaṃ nagarassa haritvā bāhirena bāhiraṃ dakkhiṇato nagarassa bhagavato sarīraṃ jhāpessāmā’ti;
dn16:6.15.3.eng: carry the Buddha’s corpse to the south of the town while venerating it with dance and song and music and garlands and fragrances, and cremate it there outside the town.

dn16:6.15.5.pli: ‘mayaṃ bhagavato sarīraṃ dibbehi naccehi gītehi vāditehi mālehi gandhehi sakkarontā garuṃ karontā mānentā pūjentā uttarena uttaraṃ nagarassa haritvā uttarena dvārena nagaraṃ pavesetvā majjhena majjhaṃ nagarassa haritvā puratthimena dvārena nikkhamitvā puratthimato nagarassa makuṭabandhanaṃ nāma mallānaṃ cetiyaṃ ettha bhagavato sarīraṃ jhāpessāmā’”ti.
dn16:6.15.5.eng: carry the Buddha’s corpse to the north of the town while venerating it with heavenly dance and song and music and garlands and fragrances. Then they plan to enter the town by the northern gate, carry it through the center of the town, leave by the eastern gate, and cremate it there at the Mallian shrine named Coronation.”
dn16:6.15.5.comm: “Coronation” is makuṭabandhana, “the binding of the crown”. The commentary says there was, fittingly, an auspicious decorative royal hall there; perhaps too the name was felt to pun with muktabandhana, “freedom from ties”.

dn16:6.15.6.eng: “Sir, let it be as the deities plan.”

dn16:6.16.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena kusinārā yāva sandhisamalasaṅkaṭīrā jaṇṇumattena odhinā mandāravapupphehi santhatā hoti.
dn16:6.16.1.eng: Now at that time the whole of Kusinārā was covered knee-deep with the flowers of the Flame Tree, without gaps even on the filth and rubbish heaps.
dn16:6.16.1.comm: I think sandhi here means “covered without gaps”.

dn16:6.16.2.pli: Atha kho devatā ca kosinārakā ca mallā bhagavato sarīraṃ dibbehi ca mānusakehi ca naccehi gītehi vāditehi mālehi gandhehi sakkarontā garuṃ karontā mānentā pūjentā uttarena uttaraṃ nagarassa haritvā uttarena dvārena nagaraṃ pavesetvā majjhena majjhaṃ nagarassa haritvā puratthimena dvārena nikkhamitvā puratthimato nagarassa makuṭabandhanaṃ nāma mallānaṃ cetiyaṃ ettha ca bhagavato sarīraṃ nikkhipiṃsu.
dn16:6.16.2.eng: Then the deities and the Mallas of Kusinārā carried the Buddha’s corpse to the north of the town while venerating it with heavenly and human dance and song and music and garlands and fragrances. Then they entered the town by the northern gate, carried it through the center of the town, left by the eastern gate, and deposited the corpse there at the Mallian shrine named Coronation.

dn16:6.17.1.pli: Atha kho kosinārakā mallā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavocuṃ:
dn16:6.17.1.eng: Then the Mallas said to Ānanda,

dn16:6.17.2.pli: “kathaṃ mayaṃ, bhante ānanda, tathāgatassa sarīre paṭipajjāmā”ti?
dn16:6.17.2.eng: “Honorable Ānanda, how do we proceed when it comes to the Realized One’s corpse?”

dn16:6.17.3.pli: “Yathā kho, vāseṭṭhā, rañño cakkavattissa sarīre paṭipajjanti, evaṃ tathāgatassa sarīre paṭipajjitabban”ti.
dn16:6.17.3.eng: “Proceed in the same way as they do for the corpse of a wheel-turning monarch.”

dn16:6.17.4.pli: “Kathaṃ pana, bhante ānanda, rañño cakkavattissa sarīre paṭipajjantī”ti?
dn16:6.17.4.eng: “But how do they proceed with a wheel-turning monarch’s corpse?”

dn16:6.17.5.pli: “Rañño, vāseṭṭhā, cakkavattissa sarīraṃ ahatena vatthena veṭhenti, ahatena vatthena veṭhetvā vihatena kappāsena veṭhenti, vihatena kappāsena veṭhetvā ahatena vatthena veṭhenti.
dn16:6.17.5.eng: “They wrap a wheel-turning monarch’s corpse with unworn cloth, then with uncarded cotton, then again with unworn cloth.

dn16:6.17.6.pli: Etena upāyena pañcahi yugasatehi rañño cakkavattissa sarīraṃ veṭhetvā āyasāya teladoṇiyā pakkhipitvā aññissā āyasāya doṇiyā paṭikujjitvā sabbagandhānaṃ citakaṃ karitvā rañño cakkavattissa sarīraṃ jhāpenti.
dn16:6.17.6.eng: In this way they wrap the corpse with five hundred double-layers. Then they place it in an iron casket filled with oil and close it up with another casket. Then, having built a funeral pyre out of all kinds of aromatics, they cremate the corpse.

dn16:6.17.7.eng: They build a monument for the wheel-turning monarch at the crossroads.

dn16:6.17.8.pli: Evaṃ kho, vāseṭṭhā, rañño cakkavattissa sarīre paṭipajjanti.
dn16:6.17.8.eng: That’s how they proceed with a wheel-turning monarch’s corpse.

dn16:6.17.9.pli: Yathā kho, vāseṭṭhā, rañño cakkavattissa sarīre paṭipajjanti, evaṃ tathāgatassa sarīre paṭipajjitabbaṃ.
dn16:6.17.9.eng: Proceed in the same way with the Realized One’s corpse.

dn16:6.17.10.eng: A monument for the Realized One is to be built at the crossroads.

dn16:6.17.11.pli: Tattha ye mālaṃ vā gandhaṃ vā cuṇṇakaṃ vā āropessanti vā abhivādessanti vā cittaṃ vā pasādessanti, tesaṃ taṃ bhavissati dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
dn16:6.17.11.eng: When someone there lifts up garlands or fragrance or powder, or bows, or inspires confidence in their heart, that will be for their lasting welfare and happiness.”

dn16:6.18.1.pli: Atha kho kosinārakā mallā purise āṇāpesuṃ:
dn16:6.18.1.eng: Then the Mallas ordered their men,

dn16:6.18.2.pli: “tena hi, bhaṇe, mallānaṃ vihataṃ kappāsaṃ sannipātethā”ti.
dn16:6.18.2.eng: “So then, my men, collect uncarded cotton.”

dn16:6.18.3.pli: Atha kho kosinārakā mallā bhagavato sarīraṃ ahatena vatthena veṭhetvā vihatena kappāsena veṭhesuṃ, vihatena kappāsena veṭhetvā ahatena vatthena veṭhesuṃ.
dn16:6.18.3.eng: So the Mallas wrapped the Buddha’s corpse,

dn16:6.18.4.pli: Etena upāyena pañcahi yugasatehi bhagavato sarīraṃ veṭhetvā āyasāya teladoṇiyā pakkhipitvā aññissā āyasāya doṇiyā paṭikujjitvā sabbagandhānaṃ citakaṃ karitvā bhagavato sarīraṃ citakaṃ āropesuṃ.
dn16:6.18.4.eng: and placed it in an iron casket filled with oil. Then, having built a funeral pyre out of all kinds of aromatics, they lifted the corpse on to the pyre.
