dn16:6.19.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā mahākassapo pāvāya kusināraṃ addhānamaggappaṭipanno hoti mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi.
dn16:6.19.1.eng: Now at that time Venerable Mahākassapa was traveling along the road from Pāvā to Kusinārā together with a large Saṅgha of five hundred mendicants.
dn16:6.19.1.comm: With the passing of Sāriputta and Moggallāna, Mahākassapa was the most senior of the remaining leading mendicants. As a solitary recluse, it was unusual for him to be travelling with such a large group, or with anyone at all really. He was to cite the events depicted here at the start of the First Council (Kd 1:1.1.1).

dn16:6.19.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahākassapo maggā okkamma aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle nisīdi.
dn16:6.19.2.eng: Then he left the road and sat at the root of a tree.

dn16:6.19.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññataro ājīvako kusinārāya mandāravapupphaṃ gahetvā pāvaṃ addhānamaggappaṭipanno hoti.
dn16:6.19.3.eng: Now at that time a certain Ājīvaka ascetic had picked up a Flame Tree flower in Kusinārā and was traveling along the road to Pāvā.
dn16:6.19.3.comm: A follower of the Bamboo-staffed Ascetic Gosāla (DN 2:19.1). | This may be an inspiration for the so-called “Flower Sermon”, a medieval Zen story that depicts the Buddha holding up a flower and Mahakassapa smiling.

dn16:6.19.4.pli: Addasā kho āyasmā mahākassapo taṃ ājīvakaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ, disvā taṃ ājīvakaṃ etadavoca:
dn16:6.19.4.eng: Mahākassapa saw him coming off in the distance and said to him,

dn16:6.19.5.eng: “Reverend, might you know about our Teacher?”

dn16:6.19.6.eng: “Yes, reverend. Seven days ago the ascetic Gotama was fully quenched.

dn16:6.19.7.eng: From there I picked up this Flame Tree flower.”

dn16:6.19.8.pli: Tattha ye te bhikkhū avītarāgā appekacce bāhā paggayha kandanti, chinnapātaṃ papatanti, āvaṭṭanti, vivaṭṭanti:
dn16:6.19.8.eng: Some of the mendicants there who were not free of desire, with arms raised, falling down like their feet were chopped off, rolling back and forth, lamented,

dn16:6.19.9.pli: “atikhippaṃ bhagavā parinibbuto, atikhippaṃ sugato parinibbuto, atikhippaṃ cakkhuṃ loke antarahito”ti.
dn16:6.19.9.eng: “Too soon the Blessed One has become fully quenched! Too soon the Holy One has become fully quenched! Too soon the Eye of the World has vanished!”

dn16:6.19.10.pli: Ye pana te bhikkhū vītarāgā, te satā sampajānā adhivāsenti:
dn16:6.19.10.eng: But the mendicants who were free of desire endured, mindful and aware, thinking,

dn16:6.19.11.eng: “Conditions are impermanent. How could it possibly be otherwise?”

dn16:6.20.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena subhaddo nāma vuddhapabbajito tassaṃ parisāyaṃ nisinno hoti.
dn16:6.20.1.eng: Now at that time a monk named Subhadda, who had gone forth when old, was sitting in that assembly.

dn16:6.20.2.pli: Atha kho subhaddo vuddhapabbajito te bhikkhū etadavoca:

dn16:6.20.3.pli: “alaṃ, āvuso, mā socittha, mā paridevittha, sumuttā mayaṃ tena mahāsamaṇena. Upaddutā ca homa:
dn16:6.20.3.eng: “Enough, reverends, do not grieve or lament. We’re well rid of that Great Ascetic. And we are harried:
dn16:6.20.3.comm: Compare Bu Pc 72. The syntax is clumsy here, perhaps deliberately so.

dn16:6.20.4.pli: ‘idaṃ vo kappati, idaṃ vo na kappatī’ti.
dn16:6.20.4.eng: ‘This is allowable for you; this is not allowable for you.’

dn16:6.20.5.pli: Idāni pana mayaṃ yaṃ icchissāma, taṃ karissāma, yaṃ na icchissāma, na taṃ karissāmā”ti.
dn16:6.20.5.eng: Well, now we shall do what we want and not do what we don’t want.”

dn16:6.20.6.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahākassapo bhikkhū āmantesi:
dn16:6.20.6.eng: Then Venerable Mahākassapa addressed the mendicants,

dn16:6.20.7.eng: “Enough, reverends, do not grieve or lament.

dn16:6.20.8.pli: Nanu etaṃ, āvuso, bhagavatā paṭikacceva akkhātaṃ:
dn16:6.20.8.eng: Did the Buddha not prepare us for this when he explained that

dn16:6.20.9.eng: we must be parted and separated from all we hold dear and beloved?

dn16:6.20.10.pli: Taṃ kutettha, āvuso, labbhā. ‘Yaṃ taṃ jātaṃ bhūtaṃ saṅkhataṃ palokadhammaṃ, taṃ tathāgatassāpi sarīraṃ mā palujjī’ti, netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī”ti.
dn16:6.20.10.eng: How could it possibly be so that what is born, created, conditioned, and liable to wear out should not wear out, even the Realized One’s body?”

dn16:6.21.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena cattāro mallapāmokkhā sīsaṃnhātā ahatāni vatthāni nivatthā:
dn16:6.21.1.eng: Now at that time four of the leading Mallas, having bathed their heads and dressed in unworn clothes, said,

dn16:6.21.2.pli: “mayaṃ bhagavato citakaṃ āḷimpessāmā”ti na sakkonti āḷimpetuṃ.
dn16:6.21.2.eng: “We shall light the Buddha’s funeral pyre.” But they were unable to do so.

dn16:6.21.3.pli: Atha kho kosinārakā mallā āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ etadavocuṃ:

dn16:6.21.4.pli: “ko nu kho, bhante anuruddha, hetu ko paccayo, yenime cattāro mallapāmokkhā sīsaṃnhātā ahatāni vatthāni nivatthā:
dn16:6.21.4.eng: “What is the cause, Venerable Anuruddha, what is the reason why these four Mallian chiefs are unable to light the Buddha’s funeral pyre?”

dn16:6.21.5.pli: ‘mayaṃ bhagavato citakaṃ āḷimpessāmā’ti na sakkonti āḷimpetun”ti?

dn16:6.21.6.eng: “Vāseṭṭhas, the deities have a different plan.”

dn16:6.21.7.eng: “But sir, what is the deities’ plan?”

dn16:6.21.9.pli: ‘ayaṃ āyasmā mahākassapo pāvāya kusināraṃ addhānamaggappaṭipanno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi.
dn16:6.21.9.eng: Venerable Mahākassapa is traveling along the road from Pāvā to Kusinārā together with a large Saṅgha of five hundred mendicants.

dn16:6.21.10.pli: Na tāva bhagavato citako pajjalissati, yāvāyasmā mahākassapo bhagavato pāde sirasā na vandissatī’”ti.
dn16:6.21.10.eng: The Buddha’s funeral pyre shall not burn until he bows with his head at the Buddha’s feet.”

dn16:6.21.11.eng: “Sir, let it be as the deities plan.”

dn16:6.22.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahākassapo yena kusinārā makuṭabandhanaṃ nāma mallānaṃ cetiyaṃ, yena bhagavato citako tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekaṃsaṃ cīvaraṃ katvā añjaliṃ paṇāmetvā tikkhattuṃ citakaṃ padakkhiṇaṃ katvā bhagavato pāde sirasā vandi.
dn16:6.22.1.eng: Then Venerable Mahākassapa arrived at the Mallian shrine named Coronation at Kusinārā and approached the Buddha’s funeral pyre. Arranging his robe over one shoulder and raising his joined palms, he respectfully circled the Buddha three times, keeping him on his right, and bowed with his head at the Buddha’s feet.

dn16:6.22.2.pli: Tānipi kho pañcabhikkhusatāni ekaṃsaṃ cīvaraṃ katvā añjaliṃ paṇāmetvā tikkhattuṃ citakaṃ padakkhiṇaṃ katvā bhagavato pāde sirasā vandiṃsu.
dn16:6.22.2.eng: And the five hundred mendicants did likewise.

dn16:6.22.3.pli: Vandite ca panāyasmatā mahākassapena tehi ca pañcahi bhikkhusatehi sayameva bhagavato citako pajjali.
dn16:6.22.3.eng: And when Mahākassapa and the five hundred mendicants bowed the Buddha’s funeral pyre burst into flames all by itself.

dn16:6.23.1.pli: Jhāyamānassa kho pana bhagavato sarīrassa yaṃ ahosi chavīti vā cammanti vā maṃsanti vā nhārūti vā lasikāti vā, tassa neva chārikā paññāyittha, na masi;
dn16:6.23.1.eng: And when the Buddha’s corpse was cremated no ash or soot was found from outer or inner skin, flesh, sinews, or synovial fluid.

dn16:6.23.2.comm: Here sarīrāneva is plural and so must mean “relics”, whereas previously it was singular, “corpse”.

dn16:6.23.3.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma sappissa vā telassa vā jhāyamānassa neva chārikā paññāyati, na masi;
dn16:6.23.3.eng: It’s like when ghee or oil blaze and burn, and neither ashes nor soot are found.

dn16:6.23.4.pli: evameva bhagavato sarīrassa jhāyamānassa yaṃ ahosi chavīti vā cammanti vā maṃsanti vā nhārūti vā lasikāti vā, tassa neva chārikā paññāyittha, na masi;
dn16:6.23.4.eng: In the same way, when the Buddha’s corpse was cremated no ash or soot was found from outer or inner skin, flesh, sinews, or synovial fluid.

dn16:6.23.6.pli: Tesañca pañcannaṃ dussayugasatānaṃ dveva dussāni na ḍayhiṃsu yañca sabbaabbhantarimaṃ yañca bāhiraṃ.
dn16:6.23.6.eng: And of those five hundred pairs of garments only two were not burnt: the innermost and the outermost.

dn16:6.23.7.pli: Daḍḍhe ca kho pana bhagavato sarīre antalikkhā udakadhārā pātubhavitvā bhagavato citakaṃ nibbāpesi.
dn16:6.23.7.eng: But when the Buddha’s corpse was consumed the funeral pyre was extinguished by a stream of water that appeared in the sky,
dn16:6.23.7.comm: As when he was born (DN 14:1.28.1).

dn16:6.23.8.eng: by water dripping from the sal trees,

dn16:6.23.9.pli: Kosinārakāpi mallā sabbagandhodakena bhagavato citakaṃ nibbāpesuṃ.
dn16:6.23.9.eng: and by the Mallas’ fragrant water.

dn16:6.23.10.pli: Atha kho kosinārakā mallā bhagavato sarīrāni sattāhaṃ sandhāgāre sattipañjaraṃ karitvā dhanupākāraṃ parikkhipāpetvā naccehi gītehi vāditehi mālehi gandhehi sakkariṃsu garuṃ kariṃsu mānesuṃ pūjesuṃ.
dn16:6.23.10.eng: Then the Mallas made a cage of spears for the Buddha’s relics in the town hall and surrounded it with a buttress of bows. For seven days they honored, respected, revered, and venerated them with dance and song and music and garlands and fragrances.

dn16:6.24.1.pli: Assosi kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto:
dn16:6.24.1.eng: King Ajātasattu of Magadha, son of the princess of Videha, heard
dn16:6.24.1.comm: Ajātasattu would have learned of the news from spies. It is a 600 km round trip to Rājagaha and back, which a mounted messenger could make in fourteen days.

dn16:6.24.2.eng: that the Buddha had become fully quenched at Kusinārā.

dn16:6.24.3.pli: Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto kosinārakānaṃ mallānaṃ dūtaṃ pāhesi:
dn16:6.24.3.eng: He sent an envoy to the Mallas of Kusinārā:

dn16:6.24.4.pli: “bhagavāpi khattiyo ahampi khattiyo, ahampi arahāmi bhagavato sarīrānaṃ bhāgaṃ, ahampi bhagavato sarīrānaṃ thūpañca mahañca karissāmī”ti.
dn16:6.24.4.eng: “The Buddha was an aristocrat and so am I. I too deserve a share of the Buddha’s relics. I will build a monument for them and conduct a memorial service.”
dn16:6.24.4.comm: A bold move, considering that his designs on the Vajjis were no secret. Perhaps he was seeking a pretext for war. The justification for taking a share of relics is caste, rather than practice of the Dhamma.

dn16:6.24.5.eng: The Licchavis of Vesālī also heard

dn16:6.24.6.eng: that the Buddha had become fully quenched at Kusinārā.

dn16:6.24.7.pli: Atha kho vesālikā licchavī kosinārakānaṃ mallānaṃ dūtaṃ pāhesuṃ:
dn16:6.24.7.eng: They sent an envoy to the Mallas of Kusinārā:

dn16:6.24.8.pli: “bhagavāpi khattiyo mayampi khattiyā, mayampi arahāma bhagavato sarīrānaṃ bhāgaṃ, mayampi bhagavato sarīrānaṃ thūpañca mahañca karissāmā”ti.
dn16:6.24.8.eng: “The Buddha was an aristocrat and so are we. We too deserve a share of the Buddha’s relics. We will build a monument for them and conduct a memorial service.”

dn16:6.24.9.eng: The Sakyans of Kapilavatthu also heard

dn16:6.24.10.eng: that the Buddha had become fully quenched at Kusinārā.

dn16:6.24.11.pli: Atha kho kapilavatthuvāsī sakyā kosinārakānaṃ mallānaṃ dūtaṃ pāhesuṃ:
dn16:6.24.11.eng: They sent an envoy to the Mallas of Kusinārā:

dn16:6.24.12.pli: “bhagavā amhākaṃ ñātiseṭṭho, mayampi arahāma bhagavato sarīrānaṃ bhāgaṃ, mayampi bhagavato sarīrānaṃ thūpañca mahañca karissāmā”ti.
dn16:6.24.12.eng: “The Buddha was our foremost relative. We too deserve a share of the Buddha’s relics. We will build a monument for them and conduct a memorial service.”

dn16:6.24.13.eng: The Bulis of Allakappa also heard
dn16:6.24.13.comm: Both the tribe and the town are exceedingly obscure, mentioned nowhere else in early texts. They must have been a small clan nearby.

dn16:6.24.14.eng: that the Buddha had become fully quenched at Kusinārā.

dn16:6.24.15.pli: Atha kho allakappakā bulayo kosinārakānaṃ mallānaṃ dūtaṃ pāhesuṃ:
dn16:6.24.15.eng: They sent an envoy to the Mallas of Kusinārā:

dn16:6.24.16.pli: “bhagavāpi khattiyo mayampi khattiyā, mayampi arahāma bhagavato sarīrānaṃ bhāgaṃ, mayampi bhagavato sarīrānaṃ thūpañca mahañca karissāmā”ti.
dn16:6.24.16.eng: “The Buddha was an aristocrat and so are we. We too deserve a share of the Buddha’s relics. We will build a monument for them and conduct a memorial service.”

dn16:6.24.17.eng: The Koliyans of Rāmagāma also heard
dn16:6.24.17.comm: The Koliyans were south-eastern neighbors of the Sakyans, and several of their towns and people feature in the early texts.

dn16:6.24.18.eng: that the Buddha had become fully quenched at Kusinārā.

dn16:6.24.19.pli: Atha kho rāmagāmakā koḷiyā kosinārakānaṃ mallānaṃ dūtaṃ pāhesuṃ:
dn16:6.24.19.eng: They sent an envoy to the Mallas of Kusinārā:

dn16:6.24.20.pli: “bhagavāpi khattiyo mayampi khattiyā, mayampi arahāma bhagavato sarīrānaṃ bhāgaṃ, mayampi bhagavato sarīrānaṃ thūpañca mahañca karissāmā”ti.
dn16:6.24.20.eng: “The Buddha was an aristocrat and so are we. We too deserve a share of the Buddha’s relics. We will build a monument for them and conduct a memorial service.”

dn16:6.24.21.eng: The brahmin of Veṭhadīpa also heard
dn16:6.24.21.comm: This brahmin is mentioned nowhere else.

dn16:6.24.22.eng: that the Buddha had become fully quenched at Kusinārā.

dn16:6.24.23.pli: Atha kho veṭṭhadīpako brāhmaṇo kosinārakānaṃ mallānaṃ dūtaṃ pāhesi:
dn16:6.24.23.eng: He sent an envoy to the Mallas of Kusinārā:

dn16:6.24.24.pli: “bhagavāpi khattiyo ahampismi brāhmaṇo, ahampi arahāmi bhagavato sarīrānaṃ bhāgaṃ, ahampi bhagavato sarīrānaṃ thūpañca mahañca karissāmī”ti.
dn16:6.24.24.eng: “The Buddha was an aristocrat and I am a brahmin. I too deserve a share of the Buddha’s relics. I will build a monument for them and conduct a memorial service.”

dn16:6.24.25.eng: The Mallas of Pāvā also heard

dn16:6.24.26.eng: that the Buddha had become fully quenched at Kusinārā.

dn16:6.24.27.pli: Atha kho pāveyyakā mallā kosinārakānaṃ mallānaṃ dūtaṃ pāhesuṃ:
dn16:6.24.27.eng: They sent an envoy to the Mallas of Kusinārā:

dn16:6.24.28.pli: “bhagavāpi khattiyo mayampi khattiyā, mayampi arahāma bhagavato sarīrānaṃ bhāgaṃ, mayampi bhagavato sarīrānaṃ thūpañca mahañca karissāmā”ti.
dn16:6.24.28.eng: “The Buddha was an aristocrat and so are we. We too deserve a share of the Buddha’s relics. We will build a monument for them and conduct a memorial service.”

dn16:6.25.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, kosinārakā mallā te saṅghe gaṇe etadavocuṃ:
dn16:6.25.1.eng: When they had spoken, the Mallas of Kusinārā said to those various groups:

dn16:6.25.2.pli: “bhagavā amhākaṃ gāmakkhette parinibbuto, na mayaṃ dassāma bhagavato sarīrānaṃ bhāgan”ti.
dn16:6.25.2.eng: “The Buddha was fully quenched in our village district. We will not give away a share of his relics.”
dn16:6.25.2.comm: Dassāma (“we shall give”) is the future second plural of dadati.

dn16:6.25.3.pli: Evaṃ vutte, doṇo brāhmaṇo te saṅghe gaṇe etadavoca:
dn16:6.25.3.eng: Then Doṇa the brahmin said to those various groups:
dn16:6.25.3.comm: The brahmin Doṇa appears suddenly in the narrative, a reminder that there were many more people than the ones who are mentioned. The suttas record two encounters with a brahmin of this name: one is the wondrous story of seeing the Buddhas footprints (AN 4.36), while the other discusses the five kinds of brahmin (AN 5.192).

dn16:6.25.4.eng: “Hear, sirs, a single word from me.

dn16:6.25.6.eng: It would not be good to fight over
dn16:6.25.6.comm: The fear of war was justified and the resolution achieved by Doṇa probably marks the last time these parties achieved a diplomatic outcome. The relative peace that had lasted most of the Buddha’s life was crumbling. We hear of war or threats of war between the Kosalans and the Magadhans, the Magadhans and the Vajjis, the Sakyans and the Koliyans, the Kosalans and the Mallas, and the Kosalans and the Sakyans. It is probably because of the latter two conflicts that Viḍūḍabha—Pasenadi’s son and the newly crowned king of Kosala—did not send an emissary to the funeral. By sparking conflicts with former allies the Sakyans and Mallas, Viḍūḍabha undid the successes of his father and fatally weakened the Kosalan Empire. When the dust cleared a few decades later, all these lands had been consumed by Magadha.

dn16:6.25.7.eng: a share of the supreme individual’s relics.

dn16:6.25.8.eng: Let us make eight portions, good fellows,

dn16:6.25.10.eng: Let there be monuments far and wide,
dn16:6.25.10.comm: Thus begins the practice of establishing Buddhism by interring relics in a stupa.

dn16:6.25.11.eng: so many folk may gain faith in the Clear-eyed One!”

dn16:6.25.12.pli: “Tena hi, brāhmaṇa, tvaññeva bhagavato sarīrāni aṭṭhadhā samaṃ savibhattaṃ vibhajāhī”ti.
dn16:6.25.12.eng: “Well then, brahmin, you yourself should fairly divide the Buddha’s relics in eight portions.”

dn16:6.25.13.pli: “Evaṃ, bho”ti kho doṇo brāhmaṇo tesaṃ saṅghānaṃ gaṇānaṃ paṭissutvā bhagavato sarīrāni aṭṭhadhā samaṃ suvibhattaṃ vibhajitvā te saṅghe gaṇe etadavoca:
dn16:6.25.13.eng: “Yes, worthy sirs,” replied Doṇa to those various groups. He divided the relics as asked and said to them,

dn16:6.25.14.pli: “imaṃ me bhonto tumbaṃ dadantu ahampi tumbassa thūpañca mahañca karissāmī”ti.
dn16:6.25.14.eng: “Sirs, please give me the urn, and I shall build a monument for it and conduct a memorial service.”

dn16:6.25.15.pli: Adaṃsu kho te doṇassa brāhmaṇassa tumbaṃ.
dn16:6.25.15.eng: So they gave Doṇa the urn.

dn16:6.26.1.comm: The Moriyas were a minor clan of the region, unmentioned outside of this passage, but their obscurity was not to last long. About a century after these events, Chandragupta the Moriyan, having won the Magadhan crown from the Nandas, proceeded to route the Greeks in the west. His empire, which covered most of northern India, was further expanded to the south by his son Bindusara and grandson Ashoka, under whom the Mauryan Empire became the greatest of all Indian empires. Thus Ajātasattu’s expansionist dreams were ultimately fulfilled beyond his imagining.

dn16:6.26.2.eng: that the Buddha had become fully quenched at Kusinārā.

dn16:6.26.3.pli: Atha kho pippalivaniyā moriyā kosinārakānaṃ mallānaṃ dūtaṃ pāhesuṃ:
dn16:6.26.3.eng: They sent an envoy to the Mallas of Kusinārā:

dn16:6.26.4.pli: “bhagavāpi khattiyo mayampi khattiyā, mayampi arahāma bhagavato sarīrānaṃ bhāgaṃ, mayampi bhagavato sarīrānaṃ thūpañca mahañca karissāmā”ti.
dn16:6.26.4.eng: “The Buddha was an aristocrat, and so are we. We too deserve a share of the Buddha’s relics. We will build a monument for them and conduct a memorial service.”

dn16:6.26.5.pli: “Natthi bhagavato sarīrānaṃ bhāgo, vibhattāni bhagavato sarīrāni.
dn16:6.26.5.eng: “There is no portion of the Buddha’s relics left, they have already been portioned out.

dn16:6.27.1.pli: Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto rājagahe bhagavato sarīrānaṃ thūpañca mahañca akāsi.
dn16:6.27.1.comm: The commentary says this summary was added at the Council.

dn16:6.27.2.pli: Vesālikāpi licchavī vesāliyaṃ bhagavato sarīrānaṃ thūpañca mahañca akaṃsu.

dn16:6.27.3.pli: Kapilavatthuvāsīpi sakyā kapilavatthusmiṃ bhagavato sarīrānaṃ thūpañca mahañca akaṃsu.

dn16:6.27.4.pli: Allakappakāpi bulayo allakappe bhagavato sarīrānaṃ thūpañca mahañca akaṃsu.

dn16:6.27.5.pli: Rāmagāmakāpi koḷiyā rāmagāme bhagavato sarīrānaṃ thūpañca mahañca akaṃsu.

dn16:6.27.6.pli: Veṭṭhadīpakopi brāhmaṇo veṭṭhadīpe bhagavato sarīrānaṃ thūpañca mahañca akāsi.

dn16:6.27.7.pli: Pāveyyakāpi mallā pāvāyaṃ bhagavato sarīrānaṃ thūpañca mahañca akaṃsu.

dn16:6.27.8.pli: Kosinārakāpi mallā kusinārāyaṃ bhagavato sarīrānaṃ thūpañca mahañca akaṃsu.

dn16:6.27.9.pli: Doṇopi brāhmaṇo tumbassa thūpañca mahañca akāsi.

dn16:6.27.10.pli: Pippalivaniyāpi moriyā pippalivane aṅgārānaṃ thūpañca mahañca akaṃsu.
dn16:6.27.10.eng: and the Moriyas of Pippalivana built monuments for them and conducted memorial services.

dn16:6.27.11.pli: Iti aṭṭha sarīrathūpā navamo tumbathūpo dasamo aṅgārathūpo.
dn16:6.27.11.eng: Thus there were eight monuments for the relics, a ninth for the urn, and a tenth for the embers.

dn16:6.27.12.eng: That is how it was in the old days.
dn16:6.27.12.comm: The commentary says this line was added at the Third Council, which was held about 150 years after the Buddha under Ashoka. The Buddha’s life was already fading into legend.

dn16:6.28.1.eng: There were eight shares <j>of the Clear-eyed One’s relics.
dn16:6.28.1.comm: According to the commentary, the remainder of the text was added by the monks of Sri Lanka. Note, however, that this verse and the next are fairly similar to those in the Sanskrit text. Since that is a northern text, it seems unlikely these verses were composed in Sri Lanka.

dn16:6.28.2.eng: Seven were worshipped in the Black Plum Tree Land.

dn16:6.28.3.eng: But one share of the most excellent of men

dn16:6.28.4.eng: was worshipped in Rāmagāma by a dragon king.

dn16:6.28.5.eng: One tooth is venerated by the gods of the Third Heaven,
dn16:6.28.5.comm: The tidiva was the realm of Indra/Sakka (DN 21:1.12.22, DN 30:2.27.12, Thag 10.1:8.4), as it was from the time of the Vedas (Rig Veda 9.113.9, Atharva Veda 10.9.5, 17.1.10). In Buddhist cosmology, this agrees with the fact that Sakka’s realm is the third of the heavens (after the earth gods and the four great kings). Thus the Third Heaven is the heaven of the Thirty-Three. Both ideas spring from an old association of Indra, or divinity generally, with the number three. Agni Purāṇa lists tridiva as a synonym for “heaven”, as does Amarakośa 1.1.11. Kṣīrasvāmin clarifies that three here means “third”, while also adding that some connect it with the Brahmā realm (Amarakośodghāṭana 1.1.6; see SN 7.18:4.2).

dn16:6.28.6.eng: and one is worshipped in the city of Gandhāra;

dn16:6.28.7.eng: another one in the realm of the Kaliṅga King,

dn16:6.28.8.eng: and one is worshipped by a dragon king.

dn16:6.28.9.eng: Through their glory this rich earth

dn16:6.28.10.eng: is adorned with the best of offerings.

dn16:6.28.12.eng: is well honored by the honorable.

dn16:6.28.13.eng: It’s venerated by lords of gods, dragons, and spirits;

dn16:6.28.14.eng: and likewise venerated by the finest lords of men.

dn16:6.28.15.eng: Honor it with joined palms when you get the chance,

dn16:6.28.16.eng: for a Buddha is rare even in a hundred eons.

dn16:6.28.18.eng: and the body hair and head hair,

dn16:6.28.19.eng: were carried off individually by gods
